story:
Short Summary

The Kakophonium was a popular jamming and musical workshop tent at the Borderland last year, this year we are returning, but need some help to unleash it's full potential.


What We Need & What You Get

we have recieved an artgrant that would cover a little more than a third of the desired budget. The huge success last year was all the people bringing their instruments, which we still rely on, but there was also lending us a PA last minute and carpets that we managed to borrow.. So at the moment we have one or two carpets that basically covers a corner, a few chairs that I hope we will be able to fit in the van to Denmark and hopefully a table, plus the instruments I will be able to borrow and bring

what we will bring:

  • Workshops - Pipe-instruments, Moop-music with soldering contact microphones, a place to come and hold a musical workshop
  • A really cozy place to jam 
  • odd instruments and a fantastic crowd
  • a P-A if you fund us
  • Elctro-acid solo!

Risks & Challenges

Last year I personally funded about 11000 SEK for tent, instruments, furniture and lights, of which the 5000 Sek art grant was payed out after the festival, and 700 SEK was gifted from others, this year I am not so fortunate to have so much cash available or the luxury of having most of the things in the vicinity to the site and a few days before to go shopping for fun instruments and furniture.  We need to transport everything that we had from Gotland to Denmark, and will most likely rent a van to do so, but we also want to improve on the experience from last year and also bring PA equipment

Other Ways You Can Help

Bring instruments, bring love! also if you have carpets that you can lend us or a PA to borrow, spread the word and the music :)

story:
Art and Community

Some fourteen local artists and writers, neighbors for forty years or more at the head of the lovely Morgan Bay in Surry, ME have welcomed my little neighborhood Gallery space within which to show their work, hopefully for years to come.
But with the tiny space bursting at the seams , it needs help to expand a little.
The Gallery is nestled in a meadow within view of the storied Bay , and walking distance of the shore and nature preserves.
The setting beside my house is peaceful, surrounded by vegetable and flower gardens, meadows and a view of the Bay.
Some artists in their sixties and seventies have been working at their skills for decades, some are young starting out, happy to be involved, all neighbors. For years we have been talking about creating a space such as this.

I am a retired art teacher in my early seventies, work at the Blue Hill Public Library and am heavily involved in its art and performance functions , curating shows and co- coordinating big art fundraisers.
Now I want to pay attention to my own backyard. In the middle of this specially harsh winter I suddenly realized that my cabin would be perfect for this dream. The Little Gallery has great potential as a venue for local, Morgan Bay art and small cultural events.
This summer sees its first season, its walls and shelves filled with oil paintings, jewelled bags, fine textiles, felted hats, lovely pottery, birch bark boxes.
I am hoping that the infusion of funds will help to make it a more accommodating space. My pension and part time income from the Library would not be able to achieve this.

story:
About us

eeodo is a fledgling publisher making artist’s books. While supporting invention and speculation we are committed to developing a broad audience and promoting the idea that art, whilst innovative and esoteric is also an everyday human exchange.

In publishing our first titles, Where is That Light Now? and Cash or Smash, we developed an exemplary approach to the design, production and distribution of artist’s books. 

As a nonprofit organisation, we are presently establishing firmer foundations, along with a variety of funding sources. As well as preparing Technologies of Romance (Part 1) we are planning a series of small publications to be commissioned from guest artists.

About the book

Technologies of Romance (Part 1) is an illustrated paperback in which personalised research and memoir is balanced with a historical perspective. 

It forms the first of a series of three books that will bring an array of 'technologies' into productive dialogue with varying notions of 'romance’.

Based on the author’s long-running undergraduate seminar of the same title, the series will provide an imaginative means of exploring cultural history in the context of current technologies.

Technologies of Romance (Part 1) will be launched in early Spring 2017 when a roster of influential artists and academics will respond to the title during a day-long symposium.

About the author

Paul O'Kane is an artist, writer and lecturer who, having worked for 30 years across fine art, popular music, photography and writing, published (as one third of eeodo) his first book Where Is That Light Now? in 2014.

Paul completed a PhD in History at Goldsmiths in 2009 and teaches in London’s leading Fine Art colleges. He publishes in leading art journals and exhibits as an artist working with a history of technologies.

Why Crowdfunding?

This is the first time eeodo has used crowdfunding. While pursuing conventional sources we became interested in the way crowdfunding publicly shares in the fundraising process. As such, it offers new possibilities for contact with an expanding audience, and potentially influences the outcome of a project.

We are also interested in the way that the 21st century 'crowd' might exist in a dynamic form online, capable of changing the world of ideas, society, art and politics. These are themes that resonate with the content of this book and previous eeodo publications.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Elvie Schooley. I have a Masters degree in social work administration/nonprofit development. In 2004 West African drum and dance changed my life. This art form has provided me with an avenue of positive connection to my ancestral heritage.

In 2015 I created DRUM the Program as a teaching platform to share my passion. We provide a service of art experience that builds self-esteem, cultural diversity awareness, and community.

The original Congo Square took place in New Orleans, Louisiana. Congo Square is now known as Louis Armstrong Park. It was the first gathering space in the United States that celebrated and hosted diverse cultures. Recreating Congo Square with an intention for celebrating cultural diversity will bring together the communities surrounding the Vortex theater. We believe that engaging in indigenous art forms provide a space  for individuals to grow, increase understanding, and participate in community.

Each day of this free event will offer drum class, a journey in history, entertainment, and audience participation. The goal is for audience members to walk away with inspiration to engage in diverse cultural experiences that create bridges to building community. This outcome will in-turn support indigenous art programs and expand the awareness of the participant. 

What We Need & What You Get

Join us in raising $4000. This campaign will provide financial support to meet the budgetary requirements of presenting Congo Square. Funds will go to pay performing groups, provide for video documentation, and support future Congo Square events.

Cool perks include:

  •  DRUM the Program t-shirts. The front of the shirt sports the DRUM the Program logo. The back of the shirt contains a line from our positive affirmation “My Culture Is Unique.”
  • Original stain glass piece.
  • Bogolan African fabric and leather handbags
  • Hand carved African mask imported from Guinea West Africa.

All funds will support performing artist, video documentation, and future Congo Square events.

The Impact

We are inundated daily through the media with images and messages that speak to a lack of value for others because they are different in some way than the majority in power. This type of propaganda serves to de-sensitizes us to the suffering experienced by the victim. Within our country we have a history of human atrocities that have never been spoken too. Even our education system has been redesigned to not teach the truth of our history. But, if we are to grow as a conscious living breeding society we must teach about the past and educate our youth on how not to re-create a future civilization that has grown numb to the sight of human atrocities.

We advocate that the engagement in diverse cultural experiences will broaden the mind and consciousness of participants. All cultures hold the constructs of identity. Components such as, language, music, dance, style of dress, and family traditions are found inside of every culture. When we  reach to explore and experience diverse cultures we grow in our awareness and humanity.

Congo Square is a cultural event that offers education through the experience of folk art. This event will showcase four indigenous communities. Participants will walk away spiritually uplifted, and inspired to engage and explore diverse cultures. Indigenous arts hold the history, and build community through providing enriched human experiences.

 

Risks & Challenges

Challenges with this type of project are with management and organization. My approach to this event is to empower my Project Manager Princess Jenkins with the responsibility of logistical oversight. Her tasks will be to coordinate the flow of the public and artisan market. My responsibilities will include masters of ceremony and tell the history of Congo Square as it is connected each indigenous group. Other support with this event will be provided by members of the Vortex staff.

Other Ways You Can Help

I am beyond grateful for this opportunity to share my love and knowledge of the benefits to engaging in cultural diversity and how it impacts awareness. I am also thankful to each of you who have taken the time to read and support this event.

The true success of this project is not just in reaching our financial goal but, it is in the lives that stand to be impacted by the experience. If you find value in what we have shared with you, then share this with others. Email the Indiegogo link to your family and friends. Use the Indiegogo share tools. Post this to you FaceBook, use the hash tag #CongoSquareATX on twitter, and promote on social media inviting others to support. Come to the Congo Square event and share this magical space with us.

story:
What's in issue #2?

"Politics" encompasses more than just the fight for governmental power, and is not constrained just to current events.

In this issue you'll find a collection of work directly and indirectly covering power struggles, such as the historic and contemporary roles of women in society, terrorism and dealing with tragedy, dictatorship and the right to vote,  religion and prayer, the power of protest, patriotism, and more. 

60 full color pages of art and writing! Our second issue includes:

Poet Jordan Franklin and comic artist Vic Priano collaborate on a moving reflection on the 2014 murder of Micheal Brown in Ferguson, Missouri and the ensuing protests. The abstract and haunting imagery of Franklin’s poem is highlighted by Priano’s fantastical and si-fi influenced watercolor illustrations.

Gerry Visco takes us back to 1971 when, at the tender age of 16, she was arrested on May Day in Washington DC for protesting the Vietnam War. Wire tapping, hippies, and Abbie Hoffman’s call for revolution shape Visco through an important moment in her coming of age.

Poetry by Sara Cress, Saquina Karla Guiam, June Inuzuka, and Kat Meads.

3 Women, a work of short fiction by Olivia Mardwig.

GChats With Claire: Claire talks with Mary Nally, founder of Drop Everything, about removing politics from her contemporary cultural biennial by holding it on the edge of the Atlantic on Inis Oírr in Galway, Ireland.

Jessica Epstien recalls her childhood growing up in Chile under President Pinochet, and the excitement of voting for the first time in the 2016 American primaries. Her excitement turns to fear when a reality TV personality, whose views seem reminiscent of the former Chilean dictator, emerges as the GOP front runner.  Can't make this up.

Judy T. Oldfield reflects on tragedy in a deeply moving piece of “flash non-fiction."

Through surprisingly beautiful data visualizations, Lily Gist blurs the line between scientific analysis and artistic expression. In her series, Metrics, she explores new ways to measure, study, and share experiences to account for the biases and blindspots in our self perception.

Sy Abudu explores black identity in America through stark collages utilizing historical images from the library of congress photo archive.

Also featuring the beautiful pencil illustrations of Harley Kinberg, the graphic design prowess of Nicole Ruggiero, and a special Suffragette City collaborative project.

Perks!

Our bleach print t-shirts and screen printed tote bags are handmade with <3

What is Suffragette City?

Suffragette City is a volunteer run, DIY community made up of artists, writers, and musicians aiming to break up the cis male dominated creative scenes. As well as publishing a high quality annual zine of art and writing we produce regular events. Our shows are booked by women, feature all female fronted bands, and we encourage the venues we work with to hire and staff women for all roles—from working the soundboard, to running the door.

Suffragette City is here to support your work, to offer career advice, to workshop something new, and to provide a platform to get your voice heard.

Why does a zine cost $20?

$20 was the lowest we could price our zine to be able to cover the cost of creating it. We are advertisement free and funded entirely by amazing people like you. We're proud to be a sponsored project of the non-profit organization Fractured Atlas, which means your donation is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

It is extremely important that the women involved in this project be able to use the zine as a portfolio piece and resume builder.  That is why we print Suffragette City with a high quality magazine print shop, instead of Kinkos. Heavy-weight coated paper and top-of-the-line digital printers ensure the work inside is presented as rich and vibrant as possible, giving the finished piece a beautiful, tactile feel. These techniques result in a true, professional-level portfolio piece for everyone involved to use, to help further their careers.   

 

Sufragette City is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Sufragette City must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Your support is vital to help us continue bringing the Mushrooms to the playa

Building and maintaining an art car is a labor of love, and a very expensive one at that. We have spent thousands of dollars and hundreds of hours just this year alone renewing the car almost completely. The foam is cushy and new, the fur is funky and fresh, and the new sound is amazing. We are by no means a "sound" car, but we think you will be very impressed with our new experience. Did I mention the lights? Six years of LED technology advancements since our original build have allowed us to make them brighter, richer, and more complex than ever before. 

What your support means

The Mushroom Patch is not a big spectacle art car, but we think our homey little pad is one of the most unique and intimate cars out there. We really love sharing the gift with you; it is why we do this. If 200 people can show us some love in return giving $20 dollars, we will have more than met our goal. We love the love you give us on playa, but we would really appreciate some financial love if you are able.

Perks, Schwag, Gifts, Etc.

We will be offering limited gifts for the fundraiser as we do not believe in making trinkets that people will barely use, if at all. T-shirts and necklaces are fun when you get them, but do you ever really use them? Yeah, neither do we. We will have two big prizes: both private tours on the Mushroom Patch you are helping us to rebuild!  The big tour will be 3-4 hours long, and you can coordinate 15 people to bring with you! The 1 hour tours will be scheduled into the spaces left after the big tour winner has chosen their time. Tours will be scheduled for Tuesday night after 9pm and the others will be Thursday day or night, your choice!

story:
Captain Stargo's log. Stardate 06.2017.

We are two months away from our mission. It has been a long journey since we left the Yarn Galaxy. A million nap years away, we have lost all communications and our rockets have burned out. We are trapped in this large human box in the meantime. We have not travelled far since we returned from the Litter Laser city, regardless our humans says it is time for repair and refit. They have assured us they can build a new rocket and Q, Floyd and I have undergone surgery these past several weeks. Our modifications have made us stronger, we feel more alive and alert. Our mission remains to return to Litter Laser City. Daft Punk disappointed us last year. We waited. We waited 9 days at the trash fence but they were a no show. It has been our priority from the beginning to see them. And it is not over until we do. We are coming back. Harder, Better, Faster, Stronger. 

_________________________________________________________________

About Spacecats 

Animal companions play an important role in many people’s lives, and although one can find many things in BRC, animals are absent. Studies have shown owning a pet helps anxiety, depression, stress, lowers blood pressure, and regulates heart rate.  For some people, just interacting with the sculptural representation of a cat can be a nice reminder of the animals back home while their guardian is on Playa.

Originally this project started when I had lost my pet Margo. The three cats are based off cats that I have known in real life that have decided to travel with the stars. The rocket had a subtle message engraved on it alongside with 70 pet names. At first we weren't sure what the reaction would be. But as the week went on some people started referring to the install as the “Cat Temple,” and as I silently observed people interact with the build I noticed that many people had came back with their friends and would write on the rocket for the pets they have missed. And for many others, it was just a fun photo prop on the way up the trash-fence to point 3, a frozen moment that faded away in their bike mirrors like a little cat mirage.


 

This year we are bringing back the same cats in new suits, new bag packs and a new rocket. 

  • New suits

Barbarella meets Star Trek. Silver, 60's, retro. We have recently sculpted and fiberglassed over their noodle shaped bodies from last year giving them a figure that brings out their characters. New body = New costumes! 

 

  • New bag packs and helmets

We are still sticking with the theme, radical self reliance. Last year Stargo carried an aquarium bag with faux goldfish in it. (Food + water). Floyd had faux plant and sand (litterbox) and Q had Catnip and cat toys. Cat essentials! This year, we want to do it better using more durable materials. As for their helmets, Q's broke last year start of the week :(. This year we have new designs for it. Stay tuned. 

 

  • New Rocket

We burned last year's Rocket. This year instead of having a CNC cut rocket we are building a larger sculpture that is also climbable. 

 

 

Traveling from Chicago to BRC takes a lot of rocket fuel. All the donations will go towards the project. 

Cats,
Rocket,
Lighting, &
Transportation

Can you help us get the cats back to the trash fence?
story_txt: Captain Stargo's log. Stardate 06.2017.We are two months away from our mission. It has been a long journey since we left the Yarn Galaxy. A million nap years away, we have lost all communications and our rockets have burned out. We are trapped in this large human box in the meantime. We have not travelled far since we returned from the Litter Laser city, regardless our humans says it is time for repair and refit. They have assured us they can build a new rocket and Q, Floyd and I have undergone surgery these past several weeks. Our modifications have made us stronger, we feel more alive and alert. Our mission remains to return to Litter Laser City. Daft Punk disappointed us last year. We waited. We waited 9 days at the trash fence but they were a no show. It has been our priority from the beginning to see them. And it is not over until we do. We are coming back. Harder, Better, Faster, Stronger. _________________________________________________________________About Spacecats Animal companions play an important role in many people’s lives, and although one can find many things in BRC, animals are absent. Studies have shown owning a pet helps anxiety, depression, stress, lowers blood pressure, and regulates heart rate.  For some people, just interacting with the sculptural representation of a cat can be a nice reminder of the animals back home while their guardian is on Playa.Originally this project started when I had lost my pet Margo. The three cats are based off cats that I have known in real life that have decided to travel with the stars. The rocket had a subtle message engraved on it alongside with 70 pet names. At first we weren't sure what the reaction would be. But as the week went on some people started referring to the install as the “Cat Temple,” and as I silently observed people interact with the build I noticed that many people had came back with their friends and would write on the rocket for the pets they have missed. And for many others, it was just a fun photo prop on the way up the trash-fence to point 3, a frozen moment that faded away in their bike mirrors like a little cat mirage. This year we are bringing back the same cats in new suits, new bag packs and a new rocket. New suitsBarbarella meets Star Trek. Silver, 60's, retro. We have recently sculpted and fiberglassed over their noodle shaped bodies from last year giving them a figure that brings out their characters. New body = New costumes!  New bag packs and helmetsWe are still sticking with the theme, radical self reliance. Last year Stargo carried an aquarium bag with faux goldfish in it. (Food + water). Floyd had faux plant and sand (litterbox) and Q had Catnip and cat toys. Cat essentials! This year, we want to do it better using more durable materials. As for their helmets, Q's broke last year start of the week :(. This year we have new designs for it. Stay tuned.  New RocketWe burned last year's Rocket. This year instead of having a CNC cut rocket we are building a larger sculpture that is also climbable.   Traveling from Chicago to BRC takes a lot of rocket fuel. All the donations will go towards the project. Cats,Rocket,Lighting, &TransportationCan you help us get the cats back to the trash fence?

story:
The Mural

Blood In, Blood Out is an iconic film and a big part of American Latino history. This mural is featured in one of the best scenes of the film.

 Many people believe the mural is in Los Angeles but, it is actually in a storage in San Antonio, Texas. It has been falling apart little by little over the last 2 decades. Adan Hernandez is the artist who painted all the artwork Cruzito(Jesse Borrego) does in the film. He has gone on to do much more since then but, these pieces have helped launch his career and put him in front of young Chicanos. This mural is a key piece of the artwork from the film, which helps create discussion among Latinos on growing up in the barrio, choosing your path, and using their talents to achieve things they may have thought impossible.

We need your help to bring the mural back to life

Our goal is $50,000 is the first step in bringing the Chicano art tour to as many cities as we can. 

  • $12,000 for workspace to restore the mural
  • $18,000 to pay the artists and living expenses for them to dedicate the time to restoring the mural
  • $2,500 for insurance, legal documents, security, etc.
  • $10,000 for supplies, construction material, and storage
  • $7,500 for perks, video, opening night, and creating documentary.


If we do not hit our goal we will still do everything we can to restore this mural and put it on tour, so we can help get out there and speak to young(and old) about our beautiful culture in there own neighborhoods. 

Preserving the Arte and Cultura

By restoring the mural, we can show how we as a people value our artwork and appreciate the talent of others. You would be a part of history. You would bring an educational tool into the communities where it belongs.

We have already reached out in the San Antonio area with exhibitions, workshops, and Q&A's. We need more help so, we can insure the safety of the art and also, spread the word.


We hope to visit as many communities in the US, just like the barrios where we grew up. Who knows, we could help influence the next Jesse Borrego or Adan Hernandez.

Risks & Challenges

We face the risk of damaging the mural further if it is not restored properly and also, damage to the other pieces of art. This would be a great loss to the art world. Who better to take care of these issues than the original artist, Adan Hernandez, and his film presence, Cruzito aka Jesse Borrego. No one has a bigger appreciation nor love for the arte as they do.



Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us with this great campaign, by contributing. Whether it's money, or time we need you. Help us by getting the word out and bringing attention to our campaign. Remember to use the indiegogo tools to share our campaign


Gracias,

Jesse Borrego, Adan Hernandez, and David Reyes

story:
UPDATE: 2/1/16
What would you do if I told you we can make a NECK PILLOW size Rainbow Cat? Well it's REAL but I need your help to get there!



STRETCH GOAL #1 ------$8,800 

Rainbow Cat NECK PILLOW
If we unlock the Neck pillow, backers will unlock new reward tiers where they can get the Neck Pillow for a special discounted price!

This includes the production costs to make it, the freight shipping, and Indiegogo/Paypal fees!

STRETCH GOAL #2 ------$13,385 

"Neko Maki" Sushi Cat Plushie

This includes the production costs to make it, the freight shipping, and Indiegogo/Paypal fees!  The above image is the Prototype. The final version may very slightly. 

The Plushies are only going to get cuter from this point forward!



___________________________________________________

MY STORY:
My names Heather Bloss, but many know me as Cloe! I'm an artist/designer who has been duped by the cuteness of Cats. Since graduating in 2010. I've had the pleasure of working as a contract freelancer on SKULLGIRLS, designing mascots for anime conventions, Winning New York Anime Festival's 2010 Mascot Contest and being featured as a top contestant in Chiquita Banana's sticker contest. WHO KNEW RIGHT? I love all the crazy different projects I've worked on, but something kept calling out to me...Besides the random cats I rescue off the streets..

I think we all get to a point in our lives where we decide. "What really makes me feel happy and complete?" My answer came to two things: CATS and ART!


That's when Rainbow Cat was created!  


Along with other dorky cute cat designs, I set out to share my love with cats and their funny/bizarre personalities with the world. That's how Spoonful of Cats started!


I'm SO CLOSE to achieving a huge goal, and that goal is making my very first design; RAINBOW CAT, into a plush toy!


Front and Back view so you can see it's cute lil tush and tail also~

LOOK AT THOSE PAW PADS AND THAT CUTE FACE! Both Squish-able and Hug-gable of course~

___________________________________________________

HOW CAN I GET A RAINBOW CAT PLUSH

___________________________________________________

Just click "Contribute Now" and pledge the amount for the reward you want!

___________________________________________________
HERE'S WHAT YOU CAN DO TO HELP
___________________________________________________
Thanks to early preorders on our website and our supporters at conventions we've raised about 2/3rds of the money we need to cover production costs!! To help keep costs low I'm having each backer pay for shipping.

HOWEVER, we still need that final push to help cover the remaining 3rd of costs as well as air freight shipping costs!! Every little bit helps and you can make up your own amount that you wish to contribute if you want to pledge more or less!
I've decided to work with DHL as our global shipping agent to ensure a timely and safe delivery. Shipping alone will cost close to $2,000 due to the distance they must travel, customs fees, and broker fees, etc. Another $300 accounts for the Indiegogo fees.

___________________________________________________

What if I Pre-ordered before the Indiegogo?

___________________________________________________

No worries! You're still set to receive a Rainbow Cat plush then! You don't need to pre-order again if you pre-ordered prior to this, UNLESS you wish to get a 2nd Rainbow Cat plush!
____________________________________________________________________________

They're estimated to arrive this March, hopefully before EastCoast's most exciting anime convention: ANIME BOSTON which they would debute at!

___________________________________________________
DETAILS ABOUT PRODUCTION
___________________________________________________

I have been working with a great factory overseas in China. This has developed into a wonderful relationship with the factory, who has worked very hard to bring Rainbow Cat to life. I believe in quality, and after 4-5 revisions we created the perfect Rainbow Cat plush. Seriously, it has pawpads and everything!
Check out the process we went through to create her below!

___________________________________________________

Risks & Challenges
___________________________________________________

The plush have already completed production and are waiting to be shipped out! The risks we may face will be if customs takes longer to process our shipment, as this is something that normally happens. 
Air Freight is generally much faster however and normally goes through customs faster as well which is why we've chosen to use Air Freight Shipping vs. Ocean Freight shipping which can take 1-2 months to be delivered. 
By working with DHL to handle our shipment of Rainbow Cat Plush toys we know they'll be delivered in a timely manner.
_____________________________________________________________________________

I Don't have money D: ! How else can I help??

_____________________________________________________________________________

The internet is an amazing thing. You can help us out a lot by sharing the indiegogo campaign on any social media outlets while the campaign is running.


_____________________________________________________________________________

What happens if you exceed the goal?

_____________________________________________________________________________

If that happens we actually have a Neck pillow size of Rainbow Cat, as well as some other cute plush designs. If that road gets crossed I'll post up a few stretch goals I've been cooking up :)

story: I want the temple to be a place of healing reflection and remembrance. for thousands of years ancient civilizations have utilized the power of crystals and "Gem Stones"to release mental,physical,and spiritual blockages. thus facilitating the free flow of thought throughout the body. on a cellular level our bodies and quartz crystals are both made up of mineral silicon dioxide.Because of this we are naturally receptive to the vibrations of crystals as they transmit,reflect,store light and receive energy. this is why I want to call this year's "Temple" The Gem Stone The design and shape already takes its own name cause it really does look like a gem. The way the lighting is going to be programmed will make it sparkle with all the gem qualities it has.

story:
About "Color Me Resisting"

Last year, For The People Artists Collective and the Chicago Childcare Collective partnered on a coloring book to uplift grassroots resistance to state violence in Chicago.   We sold out the same day of our first printing, and over the course of the year distributed hundreds of copies across the country.   So we're at it again, with a coloring book that documents the stories and struggles of Black, Arab, Latinx, Trans & Queer, and fabulous actions, campaigns, and efforts to demand justice and liberation.  This is your chance to pre-order a copy (or copies) and help us raise the funds we need to send the book to print!

For the People Artists Collective is a radical squad of Black artists and artists of color in Chicago. "As artists who organize, it is our duty to create work that uplifts and projects struggle, resistance, liberation, and survival within and for our marginalized communities and movements in our city and our world."

The Chicago Childcare Collective is a group of volunteers who play with kids to support parent and caregivers' participation in racial and economic justice organizing in the city.

We selected around 20 different campaigns, actions, and efforts that spanned the past 11 months.  From numerous Train Takeovers to locking down major streets, from Freedom Square to RonnieMan Park, Sandra Bland's family's commitment to keep her spirit alive to the fight to get Bresha out of jail - these pages tell stories of loss, love, collective healing & resistance.  

Artists include Leila Abdelrazaq, Monica Trinidad, Tita Thomas,  Jireh L. Drake, Ruby Pinto, Vicko Alvarez Vega, Melisa Stephen, Johannil Napoleon, Naimah Thomas, Nicole Trinidad, and more...

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise funds for printing, and you need to make sure you can get a copy.  If last year taught us anything, it's that these are gonna go quick!

This is your chance to pre-order the coloring book! This year, we will have two options for you to get your coloring book:

1. In person, at the FTP December Showcase on 12/10 from 5-9pm at Experimental Station.

2. VIA Shipping - within the US only.  

We're printing a limited number of coloring books for a great deal.  But since Indiegogo takes out some fees, and we want to be able to pay someone to ship the books this year, we're trying to raise $800!  

We also want to save lots of copies to use freely with the kids and families we work with, and intend to donate a number of free copies to Assata's Daughters, Organized Communities Against Deportations, and Black Lives Matter - Chicago.

Once printed, we will be distributing any unsold, remaining books for a sliding scale rate, and a link to download some pages will be made available online.

You really want to be a part of this.  Really.

16 artists submitted pages, and this is the one year anniversary project of For The People Artists Collective!

Amazing volunteers are currently translating the entire book so that it can be accessible in English and Spanish!

These pages honor the work, love, life, passion, commitment and determination of organized communities in Chicago.  We are beyond excited to share them with you.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not able to donate right now?  No worries!  There are always other ways to support.

Share this link on Facebook or twitter or tumblr or another one of those interwebs sites!  Help us make some noise!

Download the pages for free once we post it online, and distribute them widely!  

Bring crayons with you wherever you go.  Because crayons.

Continue to practice community care.

Thank you!

story:
Ballet Hawaii gives cast, audience, students, families, and supporters a brand new Nutcracker.

The Nuts and Bolts of Grandeur

In keeping with our mission, Ballet Hawaii has been enriching Hawaii's cultural environment by teaching, presenting, producing, and promoting dance since 1976.  One way Ballet Hawaii promotes dance is through its Angel Program which makes it possible for 2,000 "Title 1" children to see ballet productions. This December children-in-need and military families will be mesmerized by the beauty and grandeur of the new Nutcracker. The Angel Program provides transportation and free admission to the performance. As a non-profit organization we appeal to a world-wide audience to help us continue our work.

Septime Webre, choreographer and former artistic director with the Washington Ballet, is creating a Nutcracker for Hawaii audiences.  They will enjoy all of the holiday tradition but with historical characterizations of Washington Place resident Mary Dominis and Hawaii’s beloved Queen Lili’uokalani. In this production, the flowers are Hibiscus, birds are I’iwi and new island animal performers are introduced such as the Ho’nu (sacred Hawaiian turtle). The toy soldier uniforms are patterned after those of the Royal Guard and the famous waltz of the snowflakes takes place high upon the slopes of Mauna Kea.  The production will be accompanied by the Hawaii Symphony Orchestra and feature dancers from major ballet companies from across the United States as well as hundreds of local dancers.  Your support will make possible an extraordinary set of performances on December 16th through 18th at the Neal S. Blaisdell Concert Hall.  Hawaii will enjoy this new production for years to come. 

The Production’s Dream Team

Septime Webre – Choreographer

Ann Krinitsky – Conductor

Christine Darch & Kini Zamora – Costume Design

Holly Highfill – Scenery Design

Gary Flowers – Property Design

Trad A. Burns – Lighting Design

Production Notes:  Hawaii's own, Kini Zamora, from Project Runway, has designed our new Hawaii-themed opening party scene costumes. Christine Darch has created gorgeous and playful costumes for the rest of the production. Holly Highfill, set-designer, has designed exquisite sets with an homage to Hawaiian history. Trad Burns lights up the new Nutcracker.

 

Septime Webre, choreographer, and students during Nutcracker rehearsal

story:
TORO TARANTULA Is an limited edition book. In which we show you the adventures of Demsky and Sawe through a journey through Japanese Lands.

 

 

 

DEMSKY

Since the day he fell in the graffiti world at the beginning of the 90´s, Dems hasn´t stopped altering, trasnsforming, forming and deforming, destructing and constructing the alphabet.The lines of his pieces emerge and take form in a complex game of superpositions and color combinations.

Born in a smalltown full of palm trees, flooding his oasis  and surroundings with unique typographies, sometimes illegible, many times in codes, but always extremely elaborate and wildly precise.

Dems stands out directly for his pictorical universe, clearly influenced by New York
graffiti and scifi movies, with preference over those “Z” movies of the 80´s.
His style sound like Jupiter8, the mythic synthesizer of the fluor epoque. Forms 
challenge themselves in harmony, always composed in several levels finely suited in
urban aesthetics converted in his artistic signature.

Working with no rest, he follows to torture the letters that form his name,
always searching a new way to devour space.

www.jdemsky.com

 

SAWE

Barcelona illustrator and insatiable explorer introduces us to his vast imagination, in which we find a mixture of an adventure-filled life in the city and his own science fiction comic, fantasy world.

In order to prepare this recipe Sawe counts on a large selection of techniques and mediums which he combines by means of his sense for control verses looseness, that is characteristic of his work. The equilibrium of these opposites allow him to investigate the limits of illustration, animation, painting, murals, and graffiti, while maintaining his own signature style. Currently adventurous in 

 www.manson.st 

 

INFINITY Art Project

Gives name to more than 25 years of graffiti in a city not only known for its palm trees.

Rosh 333, Demsky, Roice 183 and Fonsmote, are part of the cornerstones they embrace a large trajectory full of Art, Respect and Style.

In this platform we show some of their study works.

www.infinityartproject.com

 

 

 

This book gathers the adventures of Demsky333 and Sawe in Japan. In analogue correspondence with the prophecy, their arrival in Japanese lands could mean nothing more than danger, adrenaline and fun. Toro and Tarantula are the live representation of brute force and wit. The Wagyu or Japanese Bull "Toro" symbolizes strength, dexterity and harmony whilst the Tarantula was used by the King of the Epire as the first of biological weapons against his enemies. What we will find through these pages is the story of how the characters assaulted Japan, consumed all the information it offered and ran every corner of its geography via the Shinkansen (Japanese High Speed Train), leaving as much trails as they could behind.

story:
Short Summary

Metamor City is the award-winning science fiction/urban fantasy universe that took the podcast world by storm in 2008. In 2009 the first novel, MAKING THE CUT, won the Parsec Award for Outstanding Long-Form Audio Drama. In Fall 2013, the new Metamor City novel THINGS UNSEEN debuts in ebook and audio, with a trade paperback edition to follow. Now head author Chris Lester is hard at work on the third novel in the series, THE LOST AND THE LEAST, and he needs your help to bring it to life.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $830 to pay for new top-of-the-line cover art for the third novel. The new cover artist is David Auden Nash, reknowned for his excellent artwork on properties for SHADOWRUN, GAME OF THRONES, WARHAMMER 40,000 and CALL OF CTHULHU.

$750 goes to Mr. Nash for his artwork; the remaining 9% is overhead from Indiegogo. If we make our target, however, Indiegogo's share drops to 4%, and Chris will use the difference to produce a special thank-you product for everyone who contributed.

The Impact

Chris makes his living as a high school teacher, so paying for top-quality artwork is difficult on his salary. By contributing to this campaign, you're helping make it possible to get more awesome art for the world of Metamor City, which translates to cooler mugs, posters, and (of course) book covers.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation right now, here are some other ways you can help:

  • Share this campaign on your Facebook page or Twitter feed.
  • Subscribe to Metamor City and listen to the podcast, and encourage others to do the same.
  • Consider buying the Metamor City ebooks at http://www.smashwords.com/books/search?query=metamor+city

Thank you for your support, and as they say in Metamor City: Keep it on the bright side!

story:
My name is Maquette and together with other artists and business owners, we volunteer to be the permit-holding, service providers for a once renegade art festival that happens monthly on our neighborhood mainstreet in the Alberta Arts District of Portland, Oregon. 

For the past fifteen years, once a month, especially in the warm ones, our street fills with artists selling their work hanging from chain-link fences or on card tables. Buskers and musicians line the street. Kissing booths gather dollars while a parade of stilt-walking bathers in a tub dance by. The fire performers gather and the food carts billow with steam. Welcome to Last Thursday.

Friends of Last Thursday volunteers are the host of the party. Besides carrying the permit and holding the insurance, we provide the services including the security personnel, a friendly crew of neighborhood ambassadors, toilets, trash and recycling, and street closure. Last Thursday is free for attendees and all artists, performers, buskers, musicians and creatives to participate and vend. We pay for all of this by holding fundraisers, seek out grants, find volunteers and ask for donations. We do not allow direct corporate sponsorship so as not to change the nature of this grassroots, low barrier, micro-business generating, truly creative event. Oh, and did I mention that we had 20,000 visitors to our street for two of the summer months last year?

It is our Street Operations Team that is on site at each of the peak summer events (May-September). They build the street closure signs and barricades to city specs, maintain these in working condition, and place them on each of the 32 side street entrances. Street Ops set out garbage/recycling bins and oversee port-o-potty placement. At 10:00 the event ends and the team opens the street as they remove all of the above via a borrowed truck and trailer.

FoLT is wanting to purchase a used box truck for our Street Operations Team. We will take that box trailer and retro-fit it to carry all of the barricades, street signs, and garbage/recycling bins and what they get filled with at the end of the night. FoLT will then lend out the trailer to other community groups at low cost, with the funds helping FoLT to become more financially sustainable.

Your contribution would support all of the people mentioned in the previous paragraphs. This box trailer can help us support a multicultural community's economic engine, grassroots art, creative thinking, performance opportunities, personal expression, dreaming, et al. Your contribution may be tax deductible. Our fiscal sponsor is the Non-Profit Association of Oregon.

Other Ways:

Shoot, if you don't have $ to give, please take a moment to pass this along to friends and help us get the word out!

You can also volunteer for a Last Thursday! info@LastThursdayonAlberta.com

story:
Painting with Raney television art instruction show

I have been a professional artist in the field of painting since 1981.  After five years of teaching elementary school art classes I decided to dedicate myself to full time painting and began teaching privately and in workshops throughout the southeastern US.  I also began painting plein air while travelling abroad.  I work in oils, acrylics, watercolors and pastels.  My style is representational with an emphasis on naturalist techniques for wildlife, landscapes, still lifes and portraits.  I have studied under many master painters such as Robert Bateman and Daniel Greene.  In 1994 I opened the first art gallery in my town where I still own the Acorn Gallery and write arts articles for newspapers and magazines.

It is my belief that we are all spiritual beings with a creative gift to hone and honor which can be applied to all aspects of our lives for a more authentic and soulful journey.  My purpose is to encourage and guide others to find their own special gift and use it to enhance their lives and the lives of those around them, an art "ripple" effect of sorts.

In the desire to reach out to others I decided that the media of television was the best way to achieve this so I produced a "Sizzle Reel" for PBS which was given positive reviews and encouragement to produce thirteen thirty minute shows, which is the minimum required for air time on the station.  Because PBS is publicly supported, all projects come to the station already fully funded and ready for broadcast.   I have been given the chance to create a new venue of art instruction with my show "Painting with Raney", a fun, educational and interactive experience for viewers of all ages.

Producing a television show is neither easy or inexpensive.  Each show will cost approximately thirteen thousand dollars to produce.  Then there is the cost of studio space, travel, lodging and food for a crew of six and props, as well as marketing and clerical expenses.  Your contribution to help in producing these next thirteen shows will enable me to generate viewership, contract for ongoing shows with future syndication and open possibilities for air time on other networks.  Name recognition for me through the shows will further promote and generate sales of my art, all of which will allow me to continue to nurture and promote the joy of creativity in others, which brings joy into my own life as well.

In thanks of your contribution I am offering perks at different levels which are designed to enhance the appreciation of art, for novice collector to art patron, some of which also include participation in the studio as an art student on my show.  Reaching my goal will allow production of all thirteen shows, which will create the minimum needed for a quarter year's air time schedule.  If I am unable to meet production for all thirteen shows, I will still produce as many episodes as possible to create viewership and the potential for future investment by sponsorship on another network.

I have seen how encouragement of the creative spirit has changed people's lives and made them more confident, joyful and unique and I believe that these are the qualities which create a world of wonder, discovery and belief for a more fulfilling life in each of us.  We are all creative individuals with something to offer and art is the truest expression of ourselves that we can give.  To produce this show will allow the expression of encouragement to others anywhere, anytime.

With your help I know that this dream can become a reality.  If you are unable to contribute to this campaign you may also spread this wonderful opportunity to your friends and family by using the Indiegogo "share tools".  Check out the perks offered and see what you might like to have in a gracious "thank you" for recognition of your participation and support.

"Cheers" and I look forward to seeing you on the "Painting with Raney" show!

(All expenses, including travel, are the responsibility of the contributor except when included as part of a specific event.  For perks that have no receipt date entered, contact between a "Painting with Raney" team member and the contributor will confirm date of perk delivery.)

story:
Hi and welcome to the abcSkydivers Indigogo sponsorship page, below you will find some information about what abcSkydivers are all about and also the whole background of this project.

 

abcSkydivers are a selected few of The Orchard gang who are trying to fundraise money for their degree show in May this year.

We will be plucking up the courage to take the jump and skydive from 13,000ft. Skydiving isn’t something we normally do, so please help us by supporting the success of the abcSkydivers in their goal to raise money for their degree show through a donation. We’d appreciate it so much and would more than happy to keep you updated with whats happening to your money at The Orchard, which you can read more about below.

Our abcSkydivers are Walid Ali, Denica Alleyne, Chris Atease, Katie Hopkins and Danny Pallett.

Thank you. 

 

The Orchard

The Orchard is how we have branded ourselves as a class of students graduating from the University for the Creative Arts, Farnham with a BA(HONS) in Advertising & Brand Communication. We’re big on ideas, creativity, problem solving and strategic thinking. We work hard and approach everything in a creative way. Each of us have a thorough understanding of the key areas of the industry, but we individually specialise in the areas of Advertising and Branding that we love the most.


We are as a group trying to fundraise to put our final year degree show on in London. This degree show is all self funded by the students of The Orchard as we have no help from our university with funding, so we are constantly trying to fundraise! So far we have carried out events such as a night at our student union sponsored by Dominos pizza, a craft stall at the local christmas market, cake sales, a Just Dance competition and the latest event The Pitch - a ad-industry football tournament that we put together. 

 

We’re excited to announce that during May we’ll be presenting the best of our work to our industry and the public at The Dray Walk Gallery, The Old Truman Brewery in Shoreditch. The Grad Show is the best opportunity to showcase our finest creativity in Traditional and Digital Advertising, Branding, Strategy, Social Media and Planning. We can’t wait to show you what we’re capable of and would love for you to visit us.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are always looking for sponsors and help toward our degree show and if there is anything you feel could help please feel free to get in touch. We currently are trying to fund the printing of leaflets/mini-magazine, banners and our work. We’re also looking for catering and drinks for our private viewing and launch. 

 

How to find us...

Contact us on twitter @abcOrchard

Email contact@abcorchard.com

or check out our Website www.abcorchard.com

story:
I found jewelry making by accident

I took metalsmithing/jewelry design as an elective toward my degree in art in college. One time melting precious metal and I was hooked for life.  I've been making jewelry in one form or another for more than 20 years, from lost wax casting and fabrication, chain maille, beading, and then Art Clay Silver

Like many artists, I've worked a vast array of jobs while dreaming of the day I could actually support myself with my art.  I've been looking for a new form, new media to work in, something that could make the dream of supporting myself with my jewelry possible.  By using a old technique with new materials, I've created something different, new, and very exciting.

The wire weaving is also supported by Art Clay Silver work, and more traditional cast silver like the celtic knot pendent below.

Also with pearl and gem beaded jewelry.

 

How your contributions Help:

To move this from an 'after work' hobby to a sustainable business, I've written a business plan which include the development of a visual identity and website for LisaGems Jewelry Design, the registration of the business, purchase of materials and display, and an aggressive schedule of shows and sales visits to area boutiques.

There are many expenses related to the start up of a new business, but for a craft based business, perhaps the largest expense is the up-front cost of show registration.  The better the show the larger the registration cost.  The three primary shows I'm focused on are The Renegade Craft Fair in Chicago, Custer's Last Stand in Evanston, and the One of a Kind show in Chicago.  Each is a unique show.  Renegade brings artists from all over the country with a focus on a younger audience.  Custer's is an long established show with a large audience.  The One of a Kind Show is a high-end gift show that has been rated as one of the top 200 shows in the country.

I am confident of my ability to win jury approval for each of these shows.  The woven wire bracelet line is unlike anything I seen in my research at any of these show, or at smaller local shows.  Your contributions will help cover the registration and table costs.

I am well on my way to having sufficient stock for the first of these shows, but it is time to restock the materials for making more, and also those to build a unique display unit designed to make it easy for the shopper to see the bracelets and to get the bracelet to try on.

What your help to me gets you!

Every contribution helps move this campain to its goal however small or large, and I am grateful for any assistance, but getting goodies for your help doesn't hurt.

For a $15 contribution, you'll receive a semi-precious gems stretchy bracelet. (random selection)  Each bracelet comes with a thank you card, explaining what the gemstone is and what it's properties are.

 

For $25 you'll receive a woven wire pendent. (random color selection)

 

For a $50 contribution, you'll receive a custom, four strand, 1 or 2 color woven bracelet.  Contributor may specify colors, and give wrist size for comfortable fit.  Available colors are:  magenta; red; orange; yellow; lime green; dark green; sapphire blue; purple; brown; black; and raw copper.

 

For $75, contributors will receive a custom, six strand, 2 or 3 color woven bracelet.  Contributor may specify colors, and give wrist size for comfortable fit.  Available colors are:  magenta; fuchsia; pink; red; orange; yellow; lime green; dark green; ice blue; peacock blue; sapphire blue; dark blue; lavender; purple; brown; amber; antique bronze; hematite; black; and raw copper.

 

At $100, contributors receive an eight color, 3 wire per color, woven bracelet in a rainbow.  Contributor may request frame and wrap colors, and provide wrist measurement for comfortable fit.

 

A contribution of $250 brings a bracelet woven in Sterling Silver or Sterling Silver and Gold-filled wire.  The more traditional version of this technique makes a lovely versatile accessory.

 

For the contributor who is able to give $500, I will make a bracelet with a technique I am still teaching myself, but will have mastered by the end of the month.  A The basket weave is a more difficult technique, using more wire and producing a right angle weave.  It it possible to create intricate patterns and designs within the weave just from the placement of the wire.

An example:

 

Even if the entire goal of this campaign in not reached, any funding received will go toward show registration and materials.  If I can get into that first show, LisaGems Jewelry Design has a chance.

The Difference You Can Make!

Every artist dreams of living by their art, and almost every artist stuggles to make ends meet.  Success in art is a much a matter of good fortune as it is hard work, determination, and (or course) talent.  The right action at the right time can make all the difference in the world.  A helping hand from the community can turn dreams into doing.  This is just the right time for a little bit of help to make a large impact.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know times are difficult for everyone, but especially for artists, performers, and independent business people.  Not everyone who may want to is able to contribute financially, but you can still help.  Please, Launch LisaGems Jewelry Design with the world! Whether you follow us on Twitter (https://twitter.com/lisagems), like my jewelry page on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/pages/LisaGems-Jewelry...), or just want to send us a positive message (LisaGems@hotmail.com), I appreciate any support you can provide. Thank you so much,
story_txt:
I found jewelry making by accident
I took metalsmithing/jewelry design as an elective toward my degree in art in college. One time melting precious metal and I was hooked for life.  I've been making jewelry in one form or another for more than 20 years, from lost wax casting and fabrication, chain maille, beading, and then Art Clay Silver
Like many artists, I've worked a vast array of jobs while dreaming of the day I could actually support myself with my art.  I've been looking for a new form, new media to work in, something that could make the dream of supporting myself with my jewelry possible.  By using a old technique with new materials, I've created something different, new, and very exciting.



The wire weaving is also supported by Art Clay Silver work, and more traditional cast silver like the celtic knot pendent below.

Also with pearl and gem beaded jewelry.

 
How your contributions Help:
To move this from an 'after work' hobby to a sustainable business, I've written a business plan which include the development of a visual identity and website for LisaGems Jewelry Design, the registration of the business, purchase of materials and display, and an aggressive schedule of shows and sales visits to area boutiques.
There are many expenses related to the start up of a new business, but for a craft based business, perhaps the largest expense is the up-front cost of show registration.  The better the show the larger the registration cost.  The three primary shows I'm focused on are The Renegade Craft Fair in Chicago, Custer's Last Stand in Evanston, and the One of a Kind show in Chicago.  Each is a unique show.  Renegade brings artists from all over the country with a focus on a younger audience.  Custer's is an long established show with a large audience.  The One of a Kind Show is a high-end gift show that has been rated as one of the top 200 shows in the country.I am confident of my ability to win jury approval for each of these shows.  The woven wire bracelet line is unlike anything I seen in my research at any of these show, or at smaller local shows.  Your contributions will help cover the registration and table costs.
I am well on my way to having sufficient stock for the first of these shows, but it is time to restock the materials for making more, and also those to build a unique display unit designed to make it easy for the shopper to see the bracelets and to get the bracelet to try on.
What your help to me gets you!
Every contribution helps move this campain to its goal however small or large, and I am grateful for any assistance, but getting goodies for your help doesn't hurt.
For a $15 contribution, you'll receive a semi-precious gems stretchy bracelet. (random selection)  Each bracelet comes with a thank you card, explaining what the gemstone is and what it's properties are.

 
For $25 you'll receive a woven wire pendent. (random color selection)

 
For a $50 contribution, you'll receive a custom, four strand, 1 or 2 color woven bracelet.  Contributor may specify colors, and give wrist size for comfortable fit.  Available colors are:  magenta; red; orange; yellow; lime green; dark green; sapphire blue; purple; brown; black; and raw copper.

 
For $75, contributors will receive a custom, six strand, 2 or 3 color woven bracelet.  Contributor may specify colors, and give wrist size for comfortable fit.  Available colors are:  magenta; fuchsia; pink; red; orange; yellow; lime green; dark green; ice blue; peacock blue; sapphire blue; dark blue; lavender; purple; brown; amber; antique bronze; hematite; black; and raw copper.

 
At $100, contributors receive an eight color, 3 wire per color, woven bracelet in a rainbow.  Contributor may request frame and wrap colors, and provide wrist measurement for comfortable fit.
 
A contribution of $250 brings a bracelet woven in Sterling Silver or Sterling Silver and Gold-filled wire.  The more traditional version of this technique makes a lovely versatile accessory.

 
For the contributor who is able to give $500, I will make a bracelet with a technique I am still teaching myself, but will have mastered by the end of the month.  A The basket weave is a more difficult technique, using more wire and producing a right angle weave.  It it possible to create intricate patterns and designs within the weave just from the placement of the wire.
An example:

 
Even if the entire goal of this campaign in not reached, any funding received will go toward show registration and materials.  If I can get into that first show, LisaGems Jewelry Design has a chance.


The Difference You Can Make!
Every artist dreams of living by their art, and almost every artist stuggles to make ends meet.  Success in art is a much a matter of good fortune as it is hard work, determination, and (or course) talent.  The right action at the right time can make all the difference in the world.  A helping hand from the community can turn dreams into doing.  This is just the right time for a little bit of help to make a large impact.


Other Ways You Can Help
I know times are difficult for everyone, but especially for artists, performers, and independent business people.  Not everyone who may want to is able to contribute financially, but you can still help.  Please, Launch LisaGems Jewelry Design with the world! Whether you follow us on Twitter (https://twitter.com/lisagems), like my jewelry page on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/pages/LisaGems-Jewelry...), or just want to send us a positive message (LisaGems@hotmail.com), I appreciate any support you can provide. Thank you so much,

story:
Summary:

I'm Shilo McCabe, queer feminist photographer and during May 2011 I celebrated National Masturbation Month with daily sex positive photos of people masturbating and sharing personal stories that completed the phorase "I masturbate..." (hence the name of the project) This project came about because, while speaking on a sex-positive panel at Mills College I was asked if I had any tips for becoming more sex-positive.  Without hesitation I said "Masturbate!" Everyone laughed at my response and I realized later that I really had much more to say on the subject. 

What did I learn from doing this project?

Masturbation is a safe place to let go of self criticism.
Day 11: "The pleasure and love I am showing my body helps keep my negative internal voices from being so harshly critical of the days actions and decisions."  

It's powerful self care.
Day 18: "Masturbation gives me some of my best orgasms. I love it for the orgasms alone, but I also do it to relieve pain, leg cramps, cranky moods, anxiety, and to help me get to sleep." 

Masturbation does not have to be a solo thing, it can foster a connection with partners.
Day 12:"I love being able to show my partner how I love me and how they can love me too. I love the intimacy of sharing something that is usually done in secret. I love letting my partner see something that really no one else (until now) really sees." 

It's a powerful way to undo negative conditioning and give ourselves permission to be as much as we are.
Day 13:  I masturbate because I never have to worry about being too much for myself. I have a high libido and a lifetime of conditioning has made me self-conscious about being too intense, too hungry, too sexual, too wet, or too kinky for even my most enthusiastic and generous lovers. 

It encourages sexual self confidence.
Day 25: Being aware of my carnal needs and then fulfilling them has been a blessing in helping me evolve into the independent and sexually self confident woman I am.

Reducing the stigma around masturbation is important because we are a culture of mixed messages - there is no unilateral message about masturbation, for some people there is a stigma about it, for others it is culturally accepted as a norm and even expected (as with heteronormative male, for example). Socially, we have multiple messages that change over time, and for the most part none of them really address the individual's right to create a sexual practice and life that is right and true for us as individuals. 

The "I masturbate..." photo project was hugely popular online, bringing in over 250,000 hits to my blog for the month of May 2011, and now it is coming, live and in person, to The Center for Sex and Culture in San Francisco in May of 2013. Never before has such a radically inclusive exhibition of photos of people masturbating been put together and I need your help to make it happen. The exhibition will also include some new photos that were not in the original online collection. 

What We Need & What You Get:

I need to raise $5000 for a variety of production costs to make this show happen.

In addition, I am funding the production of a limited edition hardcover book to feature the entire "I masturbate..." project, as well as bonus images and essays. Only 200 copies of this book will be printed, ever. This campaign is your first chance to get your hands on a signed and numbered copy of this limited edition monograph!

Here is the break down:

  • Photo Printing Costs = $750
  • Matting, Framing Costs = $1000
  • The Book = $2000 covers the cost of printing 50 copies of the book
  • Paying it Forward =  I will donate at least 5% of what I raise to the Center for Sex and Culture in San Francisco. Should I exceed my fundraising goal, I will donate up to 10% of my total! 

The balance of the funds cover the assorted costs of shipping perks to my sponsors as well as other varied expenses associated with putting a show like this together (promotional materials, sample books, advertising, reception costs, fundraising fees, etc.)

Stretch Goals:

Should I surpass my fundraising goal *fingers crossed* then I will use the funds to help me take the exhibition on the road!  I want to bring the exhibition to LA, Portland, Seattle - pretty much anywhere along the west coast.  You can make it happen. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can't contribute, please consider helping in other ways - flex your social networking power and share widely!  Tell your friends! 

Please like my facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/ShiloMcCabePhotography and follow me on twitter (@shibug and @sexposphoto) for all the latest news and updates as  the exhibition evolves.

Please like my facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/ShiloMcCabePhotography and follow me on twitter (@shibug and @sexposphoto) for all the latest news and updates as  the exhibition evolves.

story:
The Mash-up

I’m a dancer and choreographer living in Berlin, Germany. After completing an M.A. in choreography three years ago, I’ve done a lot of work and research with conscious erotic practices. Many of those experiences have been inspirational, transformative, and extremely beautiful.

My wish is to bring my worlds of art-making and healing together, and use tools I’ve developed in 10 years of making dances to create an art piece that is unlimited by ideas about what can and can’t be done in the realm of “serious” art.

I’d also like to change people’s ideas about how subtle, intelligent, and well-conceived erotic art can be. Despite films like Shortbus, and the groundbreaking work done by many queer and/or feminist artists, art that features any exploration of sensuality is still marginalized.

 

The Hard Facts

Berlin, Germany, besides being a dynamic and open-minded environment where people come to experiment artistically, has the advantage of still being one of the world’s more affordable cities. I’ve tried to keep production costs to a minimum, while still being able to work as professionally as possible. I feel that this project needs a certain production value in order to get its point across. I especially think that the performers involved, who are all passionate about the project, and bring years of professional dance experience to their work, should be paid fairly, especially since they are willing to really challenge their boundaries and explore new territory. This is how it breaks down:

5 performers for 8 days of rehearsal/research/shooting: € 4000

Cameraperson, editing, ca. 4 weeks of postproduction: € 2000

Musicians, soundtrack producer, studio rental: € 2000

Location rental for 8 days of shooting: € 1000

Equipment rental, costumes, props: € 1000

If we don’t reach our funding goal, we still plan to go ahead with the project. I will dip deeply into my savings and try to work something out, reduce the days of shooting, or pay off my debt to the cast & crew over the course of the next year. My research so far, including the rehearsal weekend that appears in some scenes of the pitch video, has been entirely self-funded, but I need your help to make sure this project is made in the best possible quality! (without putting me into debt...)

In exchange for your contribution, You’ll receive unique and fantastic perks! Not to mention a chance to be on the right side of history as a supporter of this exciting project! Many of the perks involve needing to be in or near Berlin, but if You’re unable to travel there, and want to contribute anyway, message me! I love to travel, and we can most definitely work something out!

 

The Artistic Team

The dancers involved in the project are trained in various body-based practices such as performance art, bodywork, holotropic breathing, etc., that have healing as well as aesthetic qualities. This diverse set of skills will enable some truly revolutionary mash-ups which I intend to make accessible to others through the film.

See some of my recent choreographic work at http://vimeo.com/user8978572

More about me at http://davidbloom.info (currently under construction)

Johan Planefeldt will be our highly experienced DOP, who's sensitive sensual camera work will be invaluable for caputuring our intimate movements. http://www.pizzanfunk.com/

IndieGoGo video filmed and edited by Keith Lim: http://www.facebook.com/kidsthesedays

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If You love the idea, but are unable to scrape together the cash at this point, spread the word! Let all your friends know about the campaign, and use the indiegogo share tools as well!

Also contact me if You’re interested in donating goods and services, which we can use as attractive perks to get some more donations flowing!

Spread the love!

story:
You can still help in so many other ways:

  • Please help by spreading the word via Twitter and Facebook and use the SHARE THE CAMPAIGN button.

  • Join our Newsletter to keep updated! You can subscribe HERE

  • You can also keep updated and follow us on Twitter, Facebook, and Google+

     

Feedback, Comments, or Questions?

Please Get In Touch: contact@artblix.com 

 

 

Thanks so much for helping us out, and we hope you are as excited about this Venture as we are!

The Team

 

Press Release

Babson Blog: Featured Student Business 

http://blogs.babson.edu/news/2013/07/10/featured-student-business-artblix/

SBWire

http://www.sbwire.com/press-releases/artblix-group-of-social-entrepreneurs-from-guatemala-launches-indiegogo-fundraiser-to-help-local-artists-artisans-sell-their-artworks-in-the-online-market-279446.htm

 

Frequently Asked Questions:

Indiegogo Questions

Why Indiegogo?

We believe that Indiegogo is an excellent way to promote and get feedback on our venture. Indiegogo can take us a step closer to assuring that we can easily connect with artists & artisans and ship their undiscovered goods to every country in the world.

 

General Questions

Mission

Artblix is connecting local artists & artisans to the Global Market.  With Artblix we are helping local artists & artisans to sell their handmade goods online. Starting with Guatemala and spreading the good vibe all around the world. 

We believe we can change the lives of these undiscovered artists and artisans, and bring customers handmade products with authentic cultural backgrounds that they weren't able to find before.

What's your inpiration for Artblix?

Our inspiration is the many talented Artists & Artisans in Guatemala who don’t have the resources or the time to sell their handmade goods online. These Artists & Artisans create some of the most beautiful and unique handcrafts in the world, most of the time as their main source of income. However they are often times exploited for their work or they only sell their handcrafts locally to tourists that are lucky enough to find them.  We can change this! The Artblix team will change this by introducing their undiscovered products and their untold stories to the online market.

How the idea began?

The idea started by talking to tourists from the US who were visiting the handicraft markets in Guatemala. They were often amazed by the handmade products that they found for their uniqueness, rarity, and cultural background; goods you can’t find unless you are traveling inside Guatemala. It is cultural experience you can only get inside the country, and that is the same problem for many other countries around the world. Then the idea came: How do we bring these unique works of art and their creators not just to tourists, but to a global audience? That’s when we created Artblix.

Favorite Thing About The Business

Our favorite thing is definitely the change that we are making in the lives of all these artists & artisans. Creating social value and improving these people lives is our everyday motivation to improve and be the best we can be.

Most Recent Business Accomplishment

Artblix is currently participating in the Babson College renowned Summer Venture Program; a program that has really set organization, structure, and realistic goals for the venture. http://www.babson.edu/academics/centers/blank-center/venture-accelerator/summer-venture-program/pages/summer-venture-program.aspx

How does Artblix make money?                 

Artblix is a Social Venture, so our objective is to solve social issues through a business approach while also generating income. Our objective is to have a positive impact in each of our artists and artisans; increase their source of income by using fair trade as a tool. It is not a non-profit or charity organization. Artblix only adds a 4% sales commission to the products that will be on sale on the website.

When will the online platform be ready?

We expect the online platform to be ready during October, 2013. The date is subject to change based on how we can accelerate the programming and development of the site.

How does Artblix ensure the products will get to the purchaser?

Artblix will have a local infrastructure in each country it operates (starting with Guatemala). Our infrastructure is based on a strong offline community of artists & artisans recruiters. When an item is sold online, the recruiters will use the transferred funds to purchase the item from the artist or artisan, and mail it using the preferred shipping method. Once the item is shipped, a notification with tracking number will be sent to the customer.

How does Artblix decide the price of the products and the shipping?

Artblix does not participate in the pricing process. Our belief is that each artist or artisan has to name their own price and we respect their decisions. A 4% commission will be added to the price decided by the artist. The shipping is determined by the local post office and is based on international rules and tariffs.

In which way you differ from Etsy.com?

The main distinction is that Artblix has a strong offline component. The majority of local artists & artisans in Guatemala and the world still don’t have access to the global online market. At Artblix we know that economical exclusion comes as a result of lack of opportunity. To sell on Etsy.com you have to speak English, you have to be tech savvy and you have to have a bank account. Artblix gives the opportunity to the less tech-savvy artisans from remote areas of the world to be a part of global economy, even if they don’t have bank account and can’t speak English. This ensures customers that they will find artworks that they were not able to find before, and that each of these artworks will have an authentic cultural background.

What if I have more questions? 

We would love to hear from you. If you have questions related to the perks or a donation please feel free to email us at contact@artblix.com. If you just have a general comment on the campaign please feel free to express yourself on our Indiegogo comment page.
