story:
Metka Krašovec and former students, a bridge between Slovene cultural legacy and contemporary artistic creation 

The most recent large-scale exhibition in KIBLA PORTAL in Maribor, entitled Presences, which laid bare the artistic incubation of several generational and individual directions that were formed under the guidance and mentorship of Professor Metka Krašovec, has filled the industrial space of KIBLA PORTAL with a strong connective effect, interweaving the selected works in a mutually communicative fashion, as the open configuration of the exhibition space itself unveiled the presence of kindred, yet at the same time entirely different approaches to painting, drawing, animation and sculpture. The quality of the artworks has merged with the quality of the space into a single, unified whole.  

In the six years of intense activity in the largest Slovene contemporary exhibition venue KIBLA PORTAL, which offers over 2000 square meters of space under one roof, we have – under unenviable financial conditions, with individual and collective efforts, with maximum resourcefulness and plenty of precarious and voluntary work – created cutting-edge national and international projects. The funding of the largest exhibition space in Slovenia thus depends on the enthusiasm of a handful of persons from ACE KIBLA and on successfully applying our projects to (various) EU programmes.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are collecting 15.000 USD for specialised art catalogue, designed and produced in situ. Since Metka Krašovec is one of Slovenia's most renown painters, and since she passed away just after the exhibition Presences was opened in Maribor, we feel it is our sole duty and big responsibility to provide not only visitors but also collaborating artists and experts with full-color, hard cover exhibition catalogue with all accompanying texts and professional photographs (done by Damjan Švarc). Catalogue will consist of 141 pages and will include over 100 photos from the exhibition Presences.

  • We are only offering one perk, but this one is trully magnificent. We offer (for selling price of 29 USD + shipping) a unique art experience in the form of hard cover art catalogue from Presences exhibition (exhibition webpage) with over 100 high quality photographs presenting artworks by 32 artists, including Presences series (exhibited after very long period in it's entirety) by Metka Krašovec and all exhibited works by her former students, today also renown Slovenian painters and sculpturers.

  • Any funds we raise - this is also the reason why we decided to collect raised sum even if we don't succeed with full amount, will go for the production of mentioned Presences catalogue. If we don't raise full sum, we will provide the missing funds by other means, because it is our mission to publish this art catalogue no matter what. :)

The Impact

  • The exhibition PRESENCES at KIBLA PORTAL was the ultimate creative act by one of the greatest Slovene painters, Metka Krašovec, and though nationally based in its concept, it has proven as the proper initiative and the right kind of opportunity that could easily be measured within a wider European, if not global scope. This Slovene project, then, was created with the friendly support of all participating artists and the following: Equrna Gallery, private collections of Metka and Dušan Uršič, Marko Koršič, Arne Brejc, David Rjazancev, Andrej Čeč (IC Dom real estate), Novak Antiquities, Riko company, Factor bank (Bank Assets Management Company), NLB d.d., Official Gazette of the Republic of Slovenia, digital archives of the Museum of Modern Art Ljubljana and RTV Slovenija archives, Academy of Fine Arts and Design Ljubljana, Okvirji Zevnik d.o.o. (picture framing), Municipality of Maribor (partial co-financing of the catalog), Mides d. o. o. (Nada Jaklič Košir, sponsorship), and ACE KIBLA. 

  • KIBLA PORTAL opened its doors in 2012 as a partial outlet of the European Capital of Culture– Maribor and partner cities (EPK 2012), more specifically, with the international interdisciplinary exhibition Soft Control: Art, Science and the Technological Unconscious, which was part of an extensive European collaboration project bearing the same title. For six years, KIBLA PORTAL has served as an arena for festivals (KIBLIX, MED) and large-scale art exhibitions produced by the Association for Culture and Education KIBLA; between three and four large-scale events of national and international importance are created here each year. This actively operating space is the only new and sustainable cultural project that persists, with a high-quality program, in the city of Maribor following EPK 2012.  

    Among the most notable events in an ambitiously planned program were Materiality, which was organized and executed in collaboration with partners from Poland and Portugal, followed by Don't Be Afraid, You Are the Best, an exhibition of murals by artist and professor Petra Varl and selected artists, students of art education from the Faculty of Education, and later by the contemporary, Eastern-Europe-oriented exhibition Mundus Vadit Retro. In collaboration with the Museum of Contemporary Art Vojvodina from Novi Sad, we organized Memory of Violence – Dreams of the Future. Hungarian artist Gyula Várnai was presented through a retrospective of his works in 2015, and Matjaž Krivic with a photographic exhibition. In 2017 Macedonian sculptor Žarko Bašeski's works were on display, and later that same year works by Australian sculptor and interdisciplinary artist Patricia Piccinini. The exhibition venue also hosts four large-scale international interdisciplinary art shows, which are carried out as part of the project Risk Change: MIG 21 – Migratory Interdisciplinary Grid, Shelters of Babylon, and the upcoming Personal(2018) and Future World Atlas (2019).   

  • For the full PRESENCES web experience, visit official webpage prisotnosti.kiblaportal.org

  • Check all our activities at official KIBLA webpage: www.kibla.org/en

ACE KIBLA wants to thank all of the potential contributors already in advance. Your help will be most appreciated, and will be shown in the form of a beautiful art catalogue, including works by Prof. Metka Krašovec accompanied by 31 of the renown Slovenian painters of our time, former students of Prof. Krašovec.

Thank you. :)

In the six years of intense activity in the largest Slovene contemporary exhibition venue KIBLA PORTAL, which offers over 2000 square meters of space under one roof, we have – under unenviable financial conditions, with individual and collective efforts, with maximum resourcefulness and plenty of precarious and voluntary work – created cutting-edge national and international projects. The funding of the largest exhibition space in Slovenia thus depends on the enthusiasm of a handful of persons from ACE KIBLA and on successfully applying our projects to (various) EU programmes.

What We Need & What You Get

We are collecting 15.000 USD for specialised art catalogue, designed and produced in situ. Since Metka Krašovec is one of Slovenia's most renown painters, and since she passed away just after the exhibition Presences was opened in Maribor, we feel it is our sole duty and big responsibility to provide not only visitors but also collaborating artists and experts with full-color, hard cover exhibition catalogue with all accompanying texts and professional photographs (done by Damjan Švarc). Catalogue will consist of 141 pages and will include over 100 photos from the exhibition Presences.
We are only offering one perk, but this one is trully magnificent. We offer (for selling price of 29 USD + shipping) a unique art experience in the form of hard cover art catalogue from Presences exhibition (exhibition webpage) with over 100 high quality photographs presenting artworks by 32 artists, including Presences series (exhibited after very long period in it's entirety) by Metka Krašovec and all exhibited works by her former students, today also renown Slovenian painters and sculpturers.
Any funds we raise - this is also the reason why we decided to collect raised sum even if we don't succeed with full amount, will go for the production of mentioned Presences catalogue. If we don't raise full sum, we will provide the missing funds by other means, because it is our mission to publish this art catalogue no matter what. :)


The Impact

The exhibition PRESENCES at KIBLA PORTAL was the ultimate creative act by one of the greatest Slovene painters, Metka Krašovec, and though nationally based in its concept, it has proven as the proper initiative and the right kind of opportunity that could easily be measured within a wider European, if not global scope. This Slovene project, then, was created with the friendly support of all participating artists and the following: Equrna Gallery, private collections of Metka and Dušan Uršič, Marko Koršič, Arne Brejc, David Rjazancev, Andrej Čeč (IC Dom real estate), Novak Antiquities, Riko company, Factor bank (Bank Assets Management Company), NLB d.d., Official Gazette of the Republic of Slovenia, digital archives of the Museum of Modern Art Ljubljana and RTV Slovenija archives, Academy of Fine Arts and Design Ljubljana, Okvirji Zevnik d.o.o. (picture framing), Municipality of Maribor (partial co-financing of the catalog), Mides d. o. o. (Nada Jaklič Košir, sponsorship), and ACE KIBLA. 


KIBLA PORTAL opened its doors in 2012 as a partial outlet of the European Capital of Culture– Maribor and partner cities (EPK 2012), more specifically, with the international interdisciplinary exhibition Soft Control: Art, Science and the Technological Unconscious, which was part of an extensive European collaboration project bearing the same title. For six years, KIBLA PORTAL has served as an arena for festivals (KIBLIX, MED) and large-scale art exhibitions produced by the Association for Culture and Education KIBLA; between three and four large-scale events of national and international importance are created here each year. This actively operating space is the only new and sustainable cultural project that persists, with a high-quality program, in the city of Maribor following EPK 2012.  
Among the most notable events in an ambitiously planned program were Materiality, which was organized and executed in collaboration with partners from Poland and Portugal, followed by Don't Be Afraid, You Are the Best, an exhibition of murals by artist and professor Petra Varl and selected artists, students of art education from the Faculty of Education, and later by the contemporary, Eastern-Europe-oriented exhibition Mundus Vadit Retro. In collaboration with the Museum of Contemporary Art Vojvodina from Novi Sad, we organized Memory of Violence – Dreams of the Future. Hungarian artist Gyula Várnai was presented through a retrospective of his works in 2015, and Matjaž Krivic with a photographic exhibition. In 2017 Macedonian sculptor Žarko Bašeski's works were on display, and later that same year works by Australian sculptor and interdisciplinary artist Patricia Piccinini. The exhibition venue also hosts four large-scale international interdisciplinary art shows, which are carried out as part of the project Risk Change: MIG 21 – Migratory Interdisciplinary Grid, Shelters of Babylon, and the upcoming Personal(2018) and Future World Atlas (2019).   

For the full PRESENCES web experience, visit official webpage prisotnosti.kiblaportal.org
Check all our activities at official KIBLA webpage: www.kibla.org/en


ACE KIBLA wants to thank all of the potential contributors already in advance. Your help will be most appreciated, and will be shown in the form of a beautiful art catalogue, including works by Prof. Metka Krašovec accompanied by 31 of the renown Slovenian painters of our time, former students of Prof. Krašovec.
Thank you. :)

story:
Hey, soap is great, soap is easy, soap is fun.

 

Let's make some soap!!!

 

I have all of the equipment to make soap, stainless steel pot, hand mixer, candy thermometers, mold and lye. I just need to buy some oils. Mostly Palm and Coconut but some hemp and olive oils make a great bar of soap. I would also like to add some essential oils like lavender and citrus but they're expensive.

I would also like to try some experiments with some secret ingrediants and see how they turn out.

Cold Process soap can be made in minutes but need to sit and cure for 4-6 weeks. The soaps I've made in the past are sudsy and leave your skin feeling fresh and not oily.

 

So help a brudda out and LETS MAKE SOAP!!

So help a brudda out and LETS MAKE SOAP!!

story:
Short Summary

We are the CORE team representing the Utah Region for the 2013 Burning Man Festival. After taking the bodacious Bee Goddess out to the playa last year, we are excited to bring the PsycheDelicate Arch in 2013!

Our team brings the PsycheDelicate Arch as a beautiful offering to the Earth, and as an altar to be decorated with petroglyph-inspired images, portraits of superior beings from the stars and from other dimensions. We offer our good spirits and merriment to encourage these visitors to return.

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds for lumber and other building materials and to help with costs of getting the Arch out to the Black Rock Desert. We can work wonders with a shoestring budget (although we always like more) and we are very capable of using funds to their fullest potential. We appreciate any and every donation to help us with these goals!

We're excited to offer the following gifts to our wonderful donors:

$5 donation – a handcrafted petroglyph alien pin (and our thanks!)

$10 donation - embroidered Utah 2013 CORE patch (and our thanks!)

$20 donation - Utah 2013 CORE t-shirt (and our thanks!)

For donations of any larger size, you will receive a handcrafted pin and either a patch or a tee (whichever you'd like) and of course a huge thank you from everyone who's been working hard on the project.

The Impact

The Delicate Arch is one of the most recognizable of Utah's many natural wonders: an uncanny span of rock rising from a bare massif, it looks as if it were created for a purpose, not eroded into shape by mere chance. This archway begs the question -- is it a simple result of erosion, or perhaps a portal to other worlds? In the many canyons of Utah's deserts are petroglyphs showing round-headed alien figures. Many speculate that our wild places have been visited for eons by the denizens of other worlds, and sightings of UFOs are common. People have always sought to tempt the visitors back; in ancient times canyon residents created that same rock art to honor them.

Incorporating art inspired by these petroglyphs, and maybe even some aliens, the PsycheDelicate Arch brings the history of the past as well as the mystery of the future directly to participants. Curious visitors can climb up to the top observatory deck for panoramic playa viewing or cross through the natural portal created by the Arch itself!

Other Ways You Can Help

We love volunteers! Please feel free to come down and help make this project a reality. The workspace is in Sugarhouse at 550 East 2225 South.  Bring your work gloves, all those paper bags you've been saving, and a smile!

Also, please request PAPER GROCERY BAGS the next time you are at the store and SAVE THEM for us. We'll be using them to skin the entire PsycheDelicate Arch so we'll need a bunch!

story:
AFTER CAMPAIGN UPDATE:

A big giant THANK YOU to those who contributed to Art Break Day!  Your contributions, combined with our Art Angel (who matched every donation we received during the last 2 days of our campaign) and an art supply grant from the foundation Art4Moore are the reason Art Break Day will be happening this year.

YAY!

You can still contribute to Art Break Day HERE. 

--------------------------------------------------------

THE WHAT:

Art Break Day occurs annually on the first Friday of September.

It is the day we make art free.



What's an ART BREAK?

Think of a coffee break, just add some paint and brushes!

And, why should I take one?

We celebrate Art Break Day each year as a way to promote the positive impact art has in our lives and push the idea that it needs to be interwoven into the fabric of our daily lives.

Art Break Day not only benefits the individual by giving those who do not have access to art the tools they need to discover its benefit, it gets strangers to break bread with one another across a table filled with endless creativity and expressive possibilities.


THE WHO:

“Everyone is an artist.”

- Joseph Beuys

 

“Art is for everyone.”

- Art is Moving

We’re not kidding.  Art Break Day exists because we believe everyone needs and benefits from the act of making art.




THE WHY:

Everyone needs art...

  • It makes people happy
  • It makes the world a better place
  • It’s a form of communication
  • It helps us get to know ourselves
  • It helps us get to know our ancestors
  • It helps us tell our stories to future generations
  • It connects us with our community



and NOT everyone has access to it.

  •  3.9 Million Elementary Students in the United States have no access to Art Classes (source)

  • The above statistic is only talking about children.  Think about how many teens, adults and elders go without access to the arts.

Making art together creates positive change through artistic expression, social dialogue, and community engagement.



Everyone needs a break.

Life is manic.  Studies have shown that taking a break, “a little oasis of personal time,” from the daily grind does wonders for you. It increases your productivity, puts you in an overall better mood, and it lowers your stress level.

THE WHERE:

This year we have 13 locations across the world!

We need to send a HUGE BOX of awesome art supplies (paint, paint brushes, pencils, paper, markers, pastels, etc.) to each of our amazing Artists in Residence so they can let their community make art together.

 This year's locations: Fairbanks, AK / Berkeley, CA / Los Angeles, CA / Oakland, CA / San Francisco, CA / San Jose, CA / San Rafael, CA / St. Charles, MO / Columbus, IN (2 sites) / West Africa / India

 

THE HISTORY:

Art is Moving was formed in 2008 by two artists (Lauren Odell Usher and Lisa Rasmussen) who passionately believe in the power of art.  Through various community art projects, the Artist Duo have witnessed 1000’s of individuals in dozens of cities benefit from making art.



During one of their intense brainstorming sessions Lauren and Lisa had a utopian vision:

What would happen if the entire world sat down and made art together?  

They gasped and thought, “What would happen?”

The possibilities are endless.

World Peace.

Pure bliss.

Space for all people.



Lauren and Lisa knew that in order to make this vision a reality they would have to expand their wings and stretch their reach as far as they could imagine. And so, Art Break Day was born.

The first annual Art Break Day ocurred on September 2, 2011 in 5 cities across the Bay Area of California.  In 2011, the art site number increased to 7 and a new state was introduced into the mix.  Now in its 3rd year, Art Break Day has managed to grow even bigger and reach even further!  WE’VE GONE GLOBAL and expanded into 4 new states and 2 new countries!

This year on September 6, 2013 we expect to serve over 10,000 people from all walks of life.  We are so excited that our dreams are becoming more and more of a reality each year!  

If you believe art makes the world a better place, join our campaign!

THE HOW:

Art is Moving would not be where it is today without the generous support from those who believe in the power of art. Your support goes directly towards offering art to those who have no access to it otherwise.  Your helping communities around the world take a break and get to know one another across the art table.

Get involved in other ways too!

•   Spread the word! EVERYWHERE!

•   Volunteer at one of our 13 locations (Sign up here.)

Check out the awesome Indiegogo share tools and spread the art love my friends.  Don't be afraid to do it more than once.  Some of your family and friends may have missed it the first 3 or 4 times.

THE PERKS:

$1 - Virtual Hug

I think you get the picture.  Imagine Lisa and Lauren jumping up and down in joy as they receive another donation and wanting to burst through their moniters to give you a big hug.

$10 - Art Break Day Screensaver

Imagine stumbling to your computer early in the morning to log on to email, facebook, what have you, and seeing something similar to this lovely.  We hope it inspires you to take some time to yourself each day to take a break and make art!  Yay! 

$30 - I BREAK for ART! Bumber Sticker

Show the world how awesome you think art is.  And give them a reminder that they should join this global art movement to make art every single day.  We love the idea that folks out there will be sporting these stickers on their cars, bikes, laptops, iPads, and all sorts of other stuff.

$50 - Don't forget your ART BREAK Coffee Mug

Just a little reminder to take an art break every day.

$50 - Art Break Day Sketchbook

Another way to ensure you can always take an art break.  This sketchbook fits easily in a purse or backpack.  Now you can always have room in your day for an art break!

$100 - Practice Random Acts of Art Tshirt

Just a little way to show the world you support the arts.

$150 - ART is POWER hoodie

Stay warm and let your art voice be heard.  Show your support for art tell the world you believe in its power to do good in this world.

 

$250 - Give the gift of the Art in Your Pocket!

And you get one too.  Wow, look at you supporting two of Art is Moving's programs at once.  How cool is that? SO COOL!

 

$500 - Art Print of the Month Club

This is just a sample of some of the cool art that will show up in your mail box each month.  Art and Mail are so awesome and so are you!

I think you get the picture.  Imagine Lisa and Lauren jumping up and down in joy as they receive another donation and wanting to burst through their moniters to give you a big hug.

$50 - Don't forget your ART BREAK Coffee Mug
Just a little reminder to take an art break every day.

$50 - Art Break Day Sketchbook

$100 - Practice Random Acts of Art Tshirt

$150 - ART is POWER hoodie

$500 - Art Print of the Month Club
This is just a sample of some of the cool art that will show up in your mail box each month.  Art and Mail are so awesome and so are you!

story:
An introduction:

Hi I’m Nate Little, I’m an Artist, Designer, Toymaker, and part-time Mad Scientist. I actually do a lot of other things too, but your eyes would bleed if I tried to make you read the full list. I’m a fourth semester MFA Candidate at Claremont Graduate University, My MFA Thesis Show, called “(working title)” opens in early November. For this show I’m developing a “theme-park inspired” interactive, exploratory environment in the gallery space, “re-thinking the white box” as it were. The show will be comprised of a wide array of diffrent materials/media forms and techniques to help produce a more immersive experience. When you step through the galley doors, you step into the majestic land of Arboria: a somewhat familiar, but also strange world populated by all kinds of whimsical creatures.


Wait, you’re calling your show (working title)? Seriously?

You bet I am, using the term “working title” and its origins as a way to move forward with a project even when it doesn’t have a set, marketable, name seems to strangely fit the way I approach my art practice. My work is constantly evolving and taking on new aspects: everything is an experiment and/or a work in progress, the only reason I ever call things “finished” is because I have a show date set, or a deadline for a commission.

 

Also, I couldn’t come up with a ridiculous enough puns or bizarre enough sounding names that make the project seem more pretentious than it really is.

 

As this particular project has evolved, its proven to be an enromous undertaking: becoming more complex and sadly, more expensive. That’s where you come in:

The things I need, but ran out of funds for...  

I’m hoping to get about two thousand ($2,000) dollars to cover late-production expenses like Specialty lighting, AV equipment (like speakers and additional projectors),  set-dressing materials (from stuff to go inside the treehouse to things to help disguise my walls), and other things that really can’t be put together/used until very close to or during install of the show. Its also a way for me to actually give back to my closely-knit team of collaborators (shout out to my fellow Dream-Finders!) who are helping me tackle aspects of this show that I literally cannot do on my own.

 

This is a Partial Funding Campaign: even if this project doesn’t reach my goal, I’ll still be able to put whatever is pledged into the project. We’re talking about my MFA Thesis show, it is going to happen either way, I’m asking you to help me make it the best I can.

 

I’ll post stretch goals if we get close to meeting my goal before the campaign ends. For the most part it just means more cool stuff for you guys, and I’ll get to further improve the quality of this multimedia installation.


Speaking of you getting cool stuff:

I have a ton of rad perks for this project: 

Click here for the Perks Video!

At the lower levels I have some cool things specifically for my financially-challenged backers

 

  • $1: Gives you access to download the Arboria Tourism Board Digital Wallpaper Pack, this is included at all backer levels.

  • $5: Get on the mailing list for my actual Show Postcard, anyone who backs the project at a higher level also gets on the postcard mailing list.

 


Since I’m a Plush Toymaker, and a pretty good one at that, I have a bunch of levels that feature my Nonsense Monsters Plush Toys as rewards, every one is handmade by me. No two will be the same.
Most of these perks will be delivered well after this year’s holiday season (more likely sometime in early 2013), if you back early and at a higher level, a chance to snag one of my limited commission slots for this holiday season:

  • $25 Gets you a one-of-a-kind VooDoo Dude, Handmade by me. No two are the same, ever, shipped to you sometime around early 2013.

  • $55 Lets you Pre-Order a unique variation (no two will even use the same colored socks, much less look exactly the same) of one of my more popular Plush Designs, they are: Ashurbanipal, D-wayne, Slap-beast, Chunkasaur, Toe Lion, Toenoceros or Turtlebug. Shipped to you sometime around early 2013.

  • $65: Adopt your very own baby “Greater Maned Sky Serpent” a new monster developed for this show, included will be an adoption form from the Arboria Forestry Department. Shipped to you sometime around early 2013.

  • $75: Lets you reserve a Commission slot for a custom monster of your request (within reason, We’ll talk via e-mail) to be produced and shipped to you sometime around early 2013. You can check my plush archive on my facebook for examples.

  • $100: Lets you reserve a Commission slot for the 2012 holiday season, I’ll contact you via E-mail and we’ll discuss what you’d like and the deadline you’ll need your custom monster delivered by. You can check my plush archive on my facebook for examples.


By the way: I’m also in a book as a featured designer:

  • $45: Gets you a signed copy (by me, not the author) of “The Return of The Stupid Sock Creatures,” Which features my character Ashurbanipal.

 

  • $75: Gets you a signed copy (by me, not the author) of “The Return of The Stupid Sock Creatures,” and a plush of my featured character: Ashurbanipal, handmade by me, naturally.  


Although I doubt anyone will back at this level, I have some premium rewards for anyone who really really really wants to support my show:

  • $500: You’ll get your choice of a Puppet in the style of one of the characters featured in this show plus a popular monster or baby sky serpent, and a signed copy of Return of stupid creatures. Shipped to you sometime around early 2013.

  • $800: I’ll make a handmade one of a kind “muppet style” Puppet of you, plus give you a Holiday Commission Slot, a signed copy of The Return of The Stupid Sock Creatures and a VooDoo Dude. The commission and other stuff will show up by the 2012 holiday season. The puppet will be shipped to you sometime around early 2013.


I’m also making a few Add-Ons available, anyone who backs at any level can add them to their pledge:

  • + 10 for a special “Arboria Tourism Board” mailable postcard pack: 4(maybe more!) uniquely designed limited run postcards, that you can keep for yourself or mail to your friends.

  • + 25 Add a VooDoo dude to your order *delivered in early 2013

  • + 55 Add a Popular creature *delivered in early 2013

  • *for commission reserves only* + 60 Add a second Commissioned creature (Limit 1 additional commission per order, this includes holiday rush)


*Note, all my Perk Levels are set with shipping included for backers in the US, international backers will need to add an additional $10-15 depending on perk level.

I think that pretty much covers it:

Now, I realize this is a really short-run for a campaign, but I’ll need this funding to show up at least 2 weeks before the install date of my show, which is the weekend of November 10th-11th. And according to IndieGoGo’s system the only way to make sure that it happens is to end this campaign on October 12th. I hope to produce the best quality project I can, and I’m going to be thankful for every cent that comes in.

 

As the project continues I’ll be posting production update Vlogs to my Youtube Account, and other updates on the Mad Artisan Labs Facebook Page. And hopefully, quite a few of you will get to make it to the actual show, too!

 

I really look forward to letting people see Arboria come to life. I’ve spent the last 6 years making nonsensical monsters in both plush toy and puppet form, and I’ve run my own freelance Video and Graphic Design business for nearly 10 years now. In my recent MFA study I’ve had the opportunity to start exploring much bigger projects that bring all my interests and skills together into a unified installation practice. Lately I’ve been working on developing work that doesn’t naturally fall into what you typically see in a gallery space. This installation is very much about that; looking at the pop-culture space of the Theme Park, telling stories, letting people play. I'm turning the “space for quiet reflection” into “a space to let the imagination run wild.” Its also just the starting point for exploring Arboria: I already have new ideas for other projects using this setting, and I’m not talking about other gallery exhibitions.


Help Spread the word:

Like I mentioned before, this is a relatively short run for a Campaign, but its the only way for me to get my funds in time for them to actually help. So I’m going to need you to help spread the word. Tell your friends and family! Link people to this Campaign! And keep a close watch on my FB and Youtube. I can’t wait to see what comes from this! 

 

The future is bright. Fortunately, I have goggles.

-Nate Little
story_txt:
An introduction:
Hi I’m Nate Little, I’m an Artist, Designer, Toymaker, and part-time Mad Scientist. I actually do a lot of other things too, but your eyes would bleed if I tried to make you read the full list. I’m a fourth semester MFA Candidate at Claremont Graduate University, My MFA Thesis Show, called “(working title)” opens in early November. For this show I’m developing a “theme-park inspired” interactive, exploratory environment in the gallery space, “re-thinking the white box” as it were. The show will be comprised of a wide array of diffrent materials/media forms and techniques to help produce a more immersive experience. When you step through the galley doors, you step into the majestic land of Arboria: a somewhat familiar, but also strange world populated by all kinds of whimsical creatures.
Wait, you’re calling your show (working title)? Seriously? 
You bet I am, using the term “working title” and its origins as a way to move forward with a project even when it doesn’t have a set, marketable, name seems to strangely fit the way I approach my art practice. My work is constantly evolving and taking on new aspects: everything is an experiment and/or a work in progress, the only reason I ever call things “finished” is because I have a show date set, or a deadline for a commission. 
 
Also, I couldn’t come up with a ridiculous enough puns or bizarre enough sounding names that make the project seem more pretentious than it really is.
 
As this particular project has evolved, its proven to be an enromous undertaking: becoming more complex and sadly, more expensive. That’s where you come in:
The things I need, but ran out of funds for...  
I’m hoping to get about two thousand ($2,000) dollars to cover late-production expenses like Specialty lighting, AV equipment (like speakers and additional projectors),  set-dressing materials (from stuff to go inside the treehouse to things to help disguise my walls), and other things that really can’t be put together/used until very close to or during install of the show. Its also a way for me to actually give back to my closely-knit team of collaborators (shout out to my fellow Dream-Finders!) who are helping me tackle aspects of this show that I literally cannot do on my own. 
 
This is a Partial Funding Campaign: even if this project doesn’t reach my goal, I’ll still be able to put whatever is pledged into the project. We’re talking about my MFA Thesis show, it is going to happen either way, I’m asking you to help me make it the best I can. 
 
I’ll post stretch goals if we get close to meeting my goal before the campaign ends. For the most part it just means more cool stuff for you guys, and I’ll get to further improve the quality of this multimedia installation. 
Speaking of you getting cool stuff:
I have a ton of rad perks for this project: 
Click here for the Perks Video!
At the lower levels I have some cool things specifically for my financially-challenged backers
 

$1: Gives you access to download the Arboria Tourism Board Digital Wallpaper Pack, this is included at all backer levels. 


$5: Get on the mailing list for my actual Show Postcard, anyone who backs the project at a higher level also gets on the postcard mailing list. 

 
Since I’m a Plush Toymaker, and a pretty good one at that, I have a bunch of levels that feature my Nonsense Monsters Plush Toys as rewards, every one is handmade by me. No two will be the same.Most of these perks will be delivered well after this year’s holiday season (more likely sometime in early 2013), if you back early and at a higher level, a chance to snag one of my limited commission slots for this holiday season:

$25 Gets you a one-of-a-kind VooDoo Dude, Handmade by me. No two are the same, ever, shipped to you sometime around early 2013.


$55 Lets you Pre-Order a unique variation (no two will even use the same colored socks, much less look exactly the same) of one of my more popular Plush Designs, they are: Ashurbanipal, D-wayne, Slap-beast, Chunkasaur, Toe Lion, Toenoceros or Turtlebug. Shipped to you sometime around early 2013. 


$65: Adopt your very own baby “Greater Maned Sky Serpent” a new monster developed for this show, included will be an adoption form from the Arboria Forestry Department. Shipped to you sometime around early 2013.



$75: Lets you reserve a Commission slot for a custom monster of your request (within reason, We’ll talk via e-mail) to be produced and shipped to you sometime around early 2013. You can check my plush archive on my facebook for examples. 


$100: Lets you reserve a Commission slot for the 2012 holiday season, I’ll contact you via E-mail and we’ll discuss what you’d like and the deadline you’ll need your custom monster delivered by. You can check my plush archive on my facebook for examples.

By the way: I’m also in a book as a featured designer:

$45: Gets you a signed copy (by me, not the author) of “The Return of The Stupid Sock Creatures,” Which features my character Ashurbanipal. 
 

$75: Gets you a signed copy (by me, not the author) of “The Return of The Stupid Sock Creatures,” and a plush of my featured character: Ashurbanipal, handmade by me, naturally.  

Although I doubt anyone will back at this level, I have some premium rewards for anyone who really really really wants to support my show:


$500: You’ll get your choice of a Puppet in the style of one of the characters featured in this show plus a popular monster or baby sky serpent, and a signed copy of Return of stupid creatures. Shipped to you sometime around early 2013.


$800: I’ll make a handmade one of a kind “muppet style” Puppet of you, plus give you a Holiday Commission Slot, a signed copy of The Return of The Stupid Sock Creatures and a VooDoo Dude. The commission and other stuff will show up by the 2012 holiday season. The puppet will be shipped to you sometime around early 2013.

I’m also making a few Add-Ons available, anyone who backs at any level can add them to their pledge: 


+ 10 for a special “Arboria Tourism Board” mailable postcard pack: 4(maybe more!) uniquely designed limited run postcards, that you can keep for yourself or mail to your friends.


+ 25 Add a VooDoo dude to your order *delivered in early 2013


+ 55 Add a Popular creature *delivered in early 2013



*for commission reserves only* + 60 Add a second Commissioned creature (Limit 1 additional commission per order, this includes holiday rush)

*Note, all my Perk Levels are set with shipping included for backers in the US, international backers will need to add an additional $10-15 depending on perk level. I think that pretty much covers it:
Now, I realize this is a really short-run for a campaign, but I’ll need this funding to show up at least 2 weeks before the install date of my show, which is the weekend of November 10th-11th. And according to IndieGoGo’s system the only way to make sure that it happens is to end this campaign on October 12th. I hope to produce the best quality project I can, and I’m going to be thankful for every cent that comes in.
 
As the project continues I’ll be posting production update Vlogs to my Youtube Account, and other updates on the Mad Artisan Labs Facebook Page. And hopefully, quite a few of you will get to make it to the actual show, too! 
 
I really look forward to letting people see Arboria come to life. I’ve spent the last 6 years making nonsensical monsters in both plush toy and puppet form, and I’ve run my own freelance Video and Graphic Design business for nearly 10 years now. In my recent MFA study I’ve had the opportunity to start exploring much bigger projects that bring all my interests and skills together into a unified installation practice. Lately I’ve been working on developing work that doesn’t naturally fall into what you typically see in a gallery space. This installation is very much about that; looking at the pop-culture space of the Theme Park, telling stories, letting people play. I'm turning the “space for quiet reflection” into “a space to let the imagination run wild.” Its also just the starting point for exploring Arboria: I already have new ideas for other projects using this setting, and I’m not talking about other gallery exhibitions. 
 Help Spread the word:
Like I mentioned before, this is a relatively short run for a Campaign, but its the only way for me to get my funds in time for them to actually help. So I’m going to need you to help spread the word. Tell your friends and family! Link people to this Campaign! And keep a close watch on my FB and Youtube. I can’t wait to see what comes from this!  
 
The future is bright. Fortunately, I have goggles.
-Nate Little

story:
Jazzy Blues

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
THE CONTEXT

There is more to Afghanistan than war and violence. There is a rich and diverse culture that news and media seem to forget. There are artists, craftsmen, designers, musicians who struggle everyday to preserve a sense of normality that allows for the expression of their creativity. The Little Book of Kabul is a book project that aims to reveal this hidden face of the city. A book of photos and words, of visual and textual snapshots that wants to tell the story of Kabul from a different angle.

 

THE BOOK

After long discussions, we chose to work with  film photography: in black and white, small and medium format. Drawings and pencil/ink sketches are the main source of inspiration. The same goes for the text: not a lengthy essay, but a collection of snapshots, of small portraits of details that combine into a complex collage of the daily reality that creative people experience in Kabul.

 

THE POINT OF VIEW

The Little Book of Kabul wants to look towards the future, towards the 2014 transition. There is a lot of international interest in questions of youth, art and culture in Afghanistan. Foreign governments and NGOs are investing in these fields, but very few people are thinking about the sustainability of this model. We want to take a critical stand on this and try and look what is there beyond the international circles. Hence the main question of the book is what is it that is going to be left after 2014? And what can cultural practices really contribute to this political phase?

 

SPENDING TIME WITH ARTISTS

To answer these questions, The Little Book of Kabul follows the daily activities of a number of creative people who live in Kabul. We will spend time with them, ask questions, share time and experiences that will be then collected in small poetic fragments and portraits.

 

YOUR SUPPORT

We are really excited about the project and we have received a lot of encouraging feedback and moral support. We only need now a bit of financial backing to keep the field research going: working in Kabul is really expensive and at the moment this phase of the project is completely self funded. Your donation can therefore really make a difference and will help covering travel costs, accommodation and translation. With 59 $, we ask you to trust us and buy the book in advance - a book that will be both an engaging reading and a beautiful object to keep. A book that will be the hidden prize of our exciting treasure hunt. 

 

OUR BLOG

We are keeping a diary of our research on our blog so that you can see how we progress and feel part of this endeavour that you are contributing to make possible.

 

Thanks, 

Francesca and Lorenzo

 

------------ 

IL CONTESTO

In Afghanistan non ci sono solo guerre e violenza, c'è una cultura ricca e complessa che media e telegiornali sembrano ignorare. Ci sono artisti, artigiani,designer, musicisti che giorno dopo giorno cercano di preservare un senso di normalità tale da consentire l'espressione della propria creatività. The Little Book of Kabul è il progetto di un libro che vuole rivelare questo volto nascosto della città. Un libro di istanti, di parole e immagini che vuole raccontare Kabul da una prospettiva diversa. 

 

IL LIBRO

Dopo averci pensato a lungo, abbiamo deciso di lavorare in pellicola: fotografie in bianco e nero di piccolo e medio formato. L'ispirazione viene da disegni e schizzi a matita e inchiostro, tanto per le foto che per i testi: non un lungo saggio, ma una raccolta di istantanee, di dettagli e piccoli ritratti che ricostruiscono il complesso collage della vita quotidiana della Kabul creativa. 

 

IL PUNTO DI VISTA

The Little Book of Kabul guarda al futuro, alla transizione del 2014. C'è un grande interesse internazionale per le questioni legate ai giovani, all'arte e alla cultura, ma in pochi si interrogano sulla sostenibilità di lungo periodo degli investimenti stranieri in questo settore. Il nostro interesse è quello di costruire una prospettiva critica che guardi al di là dei circoli internazionali. La domanda principale che il libro si pone è legata al poi, a ciò che resterà dopo il 2014 e a quale possa essere il ruolo della produzione culturale in questa fase di cambiamento politico. 

 

SEGUIRE GLI ARTISTI

Per rispondere a queste domande, in The Little Book of Kabul seguiamo una serie di artisti che vivono a Kabul, passiamo del tempo con loro, ci facciamo raccontare delle storie, che vogliamo ricostruire attraverso piccoli ritratti e frammenti poetici. 

 

IL TUO SOSTEGNO

Siamo entusiasti di questo progetto e finora abbiamo ricevuto tanto incoraggiamento e sostegno. Ora abbiamo solo bisogno di un po' di solidità finanziaria per continuare la ricerca: lavorare a Kabul è molto costoso e al momento il nostro progetto è completamente autofinanziato. La tua donazione può davvero fare la differenza e aiutarci a coprire le spese vive: viaggi, trasporti e traduzioni. Con 59 $, ti chiediamo di fidarti di noi e comperare il libro in anticipo - un libro che sarà una lettura interessante e un bell'oggetto da conservare. Un libro che sarà il premio nascosto di questa emozionante caccia al tesoro!

 

IL BLOG

Seguici sul nostro blog per avere un racconto quotidiano di come procede questa avventura che stai contribuendo a rendere possibile. 

 

Grazie

Francesca e Lorenzo

story:
Hello Beautiful People!!! 

My name is Stephanie Pounds and I am currently a Theatre Arts-Acting Major at Howard University! I was recently admitted to the Stella Adler Studio of Acting Summer Conservatory from May 31st to August 5, 2012. I would like to request your assistance towards the funding for my summer plans in New York City!

Honestly, I believe this program will increase my knowledge and expertise as a performing artist. I will be trained in:

  • Voice
  • Character Scene Study
  • Movement 
  • Shakespeare
  • Television, and film.     
  • Master Classes in Character and Acting for Film & Television are given to supplement the training. 
  • The program begins with an orientation and ends with a presentation of contemporary and classical scene work.                                                                                                                                                                  
The Summer Conservatory is a foundation-building course which approximates a full term of our NYU Tisch School of the Arts program. It is officially approved by the National Association of Schools of Theatre as a summer training program. It is a 10 week (20 hours per week) program.


One of core beliefs at Stella Adler Studio of Acting is that your growth as an actor and as a human being are synonymous. It is said that it is in the time of adversity when one shows their true character. I am grateful for all of the blood, sweat, and tears that were shed. I would not be the person I am today. I am constantly learning, growing, and evolving. I am content with everything that has happened in my life.
 
As I am matriculating through Howard University I have realized that my major in Theatre Arts-Acting is more than a future career but a lifestyle. What better way to follow this lifestyle to manifest itself than to continue training over the summer in NYC!

Every penny counts! If you are not able to donate you can still help! Please spread the word!!! Thanks!
 
Again, thank you for your time and consideration. Please feel free to contact me if you have any further questions.

 

Best regards,

 

Stephanie Pounds

story:
'For The Time Being' is a one-day pop-up project bringing NYC-based creatives together to produce a zine and gallery show at Bishop Gallery in Brooklyn, NY. 


The Goal:

The pop-up gallery show will be curated by Mathea Millman, a Brooklyn-based curator and art director currently working as a Photo Assistant at Allure Magazine. The goal of the project is to bring creatives together to concept, create, and produce a zine and a gallery show in one day. The artists involved are professionals working around NYC in a variety of industries who will work together in an innovative and collaborative way. 


The Gallery Show - Saturday, November 15th 2014:

The day of the gallery show the group of selected artists will collaborate, edit and produce content for the zine and gallery show. Everything will be made the day-of and will culminate in an event open to the public from 7-10pm at the Bishop Gallery located at 916 Bedford Ave in Brooklyn, NY. Feel free to check out their website. The gallery is located near the Bedford-Nostrand G train. 

Why Are We Doing This?

In the digital age everyone can find a community online. This project explores the concept of community as a departure from our evolving technological idea of community. It is about coming together as a physical community in order to understand our own individual presence in relation to something larger than ourselves, and to facilitate spontaneous collaboration with a specific time restraint. 

The Artists Involved:

A.E. Kieren - Illustrator 
Ally Lindsay - Fashion Photographer/Painter
Amy Obarski - Cinematographer
Blake Horn - Filmmaker
Busra Erkara - Senior Editor, NYLON + NYLON Guys  
Devon Swartz - Student
Erin FM - DJ 
Gabe Millman - Musician/Composer
James Orlando - Fashion Photographer/Creative Director 
Jonathan Wing - Film Director/Editor
Kamal Naeem - Founder of Blank Slate Records 
Leo Oliva - Visual Artist
Lin Laurin - Actor/Producer
Mathea Millman - Photo Assistant, Allure
Maxwell Losgar - Assistant to the Managing Editor, Teen Vogue
Richard Perez - Photographer/Artist
Sarah Bachman - Junior Art Director, VS + CO
Seymour Glass - Fashion Editor
Travis Rainey - Filmmaker 

What the Money Will Be Used For:

  • Fees for gallery space 
  • Printing costs for the zine and posters for the gallery show 
  • Craft services to be able to provide lunch and dinner for the participating artists
  • Production design and props for specific projects being worked on throughout the day


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute to the project financially then there are still ways that you can help. 

    • Share our campaign on social media and use the share tools to let other people know about what we are doing. 
    • Spread the word and tell people via word of mouth to check out our campaign! 


    Photo by Richard Perez
story_txt:
'For The Time Being' is a one-day pop-up project bringing NYC-based creatives together to produce a zine and gallery show at Bishop Gallery in Brooklyn, NY. 

The Goal: The pop-up gallery show will be curated by Mathea Millman, a Brooklyn-based curator and art director currently working as a Photo Assistant at Allure Magazine. The goal of the project is to bring creatives together to concept, create, and produce a zine and a gallery show in one day. The artists involved are professionals working around NYC in a variety of industries who will work together in an innovative and collaborative way. 

The Gallery Show - Saturday, November 15th 2014:
The day of the gallery show the group of selected artists will collaborate, edit and produce content for the zine and gallery show. Everything will be made the day-of and will culminate in an event open to the public from 7-10pm at the Bishop Gallery located at 916 Bedford Ave in Brooklyn, NY. Feel free to check out their website. The gallery is located near the Bedford-Nostrand G train. 

Why Are We Doing This?
In the digital age everyone can find a community online. This project explores the concept of community as a departure from our evolving technological idea of community. It is about coming together as a physical community in order to understand our own individual presence in relation to something larger than ourselves, and to facilitate spontaneous collaboration with a specific time restraint. 

The Artists Involved:

A.E. Kieren - Illustrator 

Ally Lindsay - Fashion Photographer/Painter


Amy Obarski - Cinematographer


Blake Horn - Filmmaker

Busra Erkara - Senior Editor, NYLON + NYLON Guys  

Devon Swartz - Student


Erin FM - DJ 
Gabe Millman - Musician/Composer


James Orlando - Fashion Photographer/Creative Director 


Jonathan Wing - Film Director/Editor

Kamal Naeem - Founder of Blank Slate Records 

Leo Oliva - Visual Artist
Lin Laurin - Actor/Producer

Mathea Millman - Photo Assistant, Allure


Maxwell Losgar - Assistant to the Managing Editor, Teen Vogue


Richard Perez - Photographer/Artist
Sarah Bachman - Junior Art Director, VS + CO

Seymour Glass - Fashion Editor
Travis Rainey - Filmmaker 

What the Money Will Be Used For:
 
Fees for gallery space 

Printing costs for the zine and posters for the gallery show 
 Craft services to be able to provide lunch and dinner for the participating artists
Production design and props for specific projects being worked on throughout the day




  Other Ways You Can Help If you can't contribute to the project financially then there are still ways that you can help.  
Share our campaign on social media and use the share tools to let other people know about what we are doing.  Spread the word and tell people via word of mouth to check out our campaign!  
 Photo by Richard Perez

story:
Art Involves

I became a maker of functional art because it connects people through objects, it involves both potter and user in an intimate connected space.  You can see the story of the making in wood-fired pots and the narrative draws you in.  The process is also a community effort, days of shifts tending the kiln bringing it to temperature as well as the processing of cords and cords of wood are what bring the work of many artists simultaneously into being.

I have been making pots for 25 years.  As a creator and  builder the utility of an object resonates.  This passion has built Mill Creek Pottery, a full time studio with three wood fired kilns, and two apprentices.   We make work, we build and teach, and fail and learn.   What we learn here has ripples in the community.  My apprentices and I write, travel, and teach.  Recently we built two kilns for the China Academy of the Arts in Hangzhou, bringing Asian technology that has incubated and changed in the US back to Asia.

The Campaign

Mill Creek Pottery has been in Gresham, Wisconsin for 16 years.  Over that time we have seen the arts community in the area grow, and we have made many friends.   So many wonderful people have come to fire, buy pottery, visit, work and contribute in their own way.   We are at a time when we need some major maintenance and re-building of our kilns.  We need some new tools, bricks, a brick saw, and a large bisque kiln.   We are re-building the front of the anagama and the cross draft kiln from the ground up.
I realize more than ever that the work I make is dependent of the efforts of many; my family, friends, apprentices, and the many wonderful customers I have met over the years.   I am asking you to consider joining us.

What We Need & What You Get

The perks are thank you's but also match the value of each contribution.  I am pretty excited about what we came up with.

  • Thank You Cards: $10 contribution.  Shipping in the US included.

 


  • Diner Mug: $50 donation. Shipping in the US included. 
  • Photo Book, $100 contribution. Free shipping in the US.  These are the pots that I have been saving for my children over the years.  It is a growing collection of over 60 pots that I am now documenting.  

  


  • 30' x 20" Archival Framed Prints, $200 Contribution. Free Shipping in the US.  Choice of any one of 4 images.

  

"Ring"                                       "Orbit"

  

"Butterfly"                                       "Landscape"

  • The Fire Perk

Want to wood-fire without all the fuss and muss?  For a contribution of $100 to the Mill Creek Build and Burn Campaign.  I will fire 3 of your pots in my anagama kiln!
Here is the deal.  For $100 I will email you my clay and glaze recipes, plus a pretty good chocolate chip cookie recipe.  Use any High temp clay you like, make and bisque 3 high fire pots.  Glaze interiors only.  Ship them to me, and I will fire them in the re-built Mill Creek anagama Kiln, repack them and ship them back to you.  All for the insanely low price of $100!


  1. Work must fit in 1 (one) Medium US Flat rate Shipping box.  8.5" x 11" x 5.5"


  2. Work must be high temperature (Cone 10-12) Stoneware or Porcelain


  3. Work must be signed for easy identification post firing. 


  4. Glaze Interiors only


  5. Work must be packed to survive shipping


  6. Maximum of 3 pieces.


  • Week Long Anagama Firing Workshop, $1000 

    THE BIG PERK!  I will be holding two week long anagama loading and firing workshops here at my home in Gresham Wisconsin; one in the fall of 2015 and one in the spring of 2016.  Slots are limited to 6 people per workshop.  Though I have taught workshops at Arrowmont, Haystack, Peter's Valley and Anderson Ranch, never have I had the pleasure of teaching here at my own home.  This will be fun!  *scroll to the bottom for more information!

Firing the Arrowmont Anagama, 2012.

  • Pick of the kiln!  $10,000.  The Crazy Perk.

This is something I have never done before; let someone come in while we are unloading and have first choice.  I love to sit with the pots, and when we unload the anagama I usually have about 500 pots to sit with.   We have had collectors come and still I hoard.  But no longer.  Just for fun I am offering some generous contributor the chance to pick any three (3) pots of mine from the next anagama firing.  This could be anything from a large cauldron, and two big bowls, to a couple mugs and a pitcher.   The pick of the kiln!   Our next firing is August 2nd, 2015.  The unloading will be Saturday August 15th.  Are you going to be the one?


  • Where do the funds go if I don't reach my goal?  Well they will go to the same place.  They will help pay for a new bisque kiln, repairs on the anagama, and rebuilding the cross draft kiln.  There just will be less funding.

The Impact

A life dedicated to art has brought many people here, as well as lead me to travel and teach techniques we have developed at Mill Creek Pottery.   My apprenticeship program has had 14 apprentices and counting, who have gone on to get degrees, awards, residencies, and make their own contributions to the art world.   

Shawano County has a new fall art tour, at the core of it is an emergence of art in the county.  It was started by David Rand, a retired school teacher, who got into pottery after retiring and built a scaled down model of my cross draft kiln.  I now find myself president of the board as we plan our fifth fall tour bringing art to, and energizing art within, our community.  

In the fall of 2014 two of my apprentices and I traveled to China to build a kiln that was designed here at Mill Creek Pottery.  The ideas and innovations we are committed to developing ripple outwards.    Help us deepen and broaden the ripples.

     

Apprentice Kelsie Rudolph loading the front of the Mill Creek Anagama.  And building a train kiln for China Academy of the Arts in Hangzhou, China.


Other Ways You Can Help

Money is tight.  And there was a time I couldn't afford to help others.  People, friends and teachers who were more established than I helped me so I could become established myself.  And when I started my apprenticeship program I built it around what I would have liked to have had at that stage of my life.  I hope you feel inspired to join us, even if you don't have money there are ways you can help and stay in touch.

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Go to my website and subscribe to my mailing list.
  • Come visit and say hello.


* WORKSHOP DETAILS

2 workshops are planned.   Oct. 25th - Nov. 1st 2015. and May 21st - May 28th 2016.  To maximize the amount of work participants can fire, and to ensure high quality instruction, I am limiting each workshop to only 6 participants.

Workshop attendees will get individual instruction on loading and firing techniques.  They will bring bisque ware and share the kiln space of my 150 cubic foot anagama.  Instruction, glaze, materials and wood and food will be included with tuition.  Housing will not, although we will work with all attendees to find reasonable housing options.

Three days will be spent loading the kiln, and 4-days firing.  This will complete the workshop.  The kiln will cool for 5 days and be unloaded on the 6th.  Attendees are welcome to return to the unloading, or shipping arrangements can be made to return your work to you. 

Because of the limited size of these classes expect a lot of intense learning and the opportunity to fire a sizable amount of work.  Also expect to work hard, this is definitely a learn-by-doing class.  Participants will fire the kiln, with guidance and help from me and my two apprentices.

story:
Hello, I'm Tina Guay. I am building a community darkroom at Engine, a nonprofit arts organization in downtown Biddeford, Maine.

In the 5th grade I had the opportunity to shoot a couple rolls of black and white film in a family friends studio. I was able see how the film was processed to create beautiful images. This experience inspired me to pursue this art form through high school and college. I still remember the curiosity I experienced upon developing and printing my first images.

I continued that pursuit of curiosity through my education at the New Hampshire Institute of Art. While attending my main focus was on the handmade process of black and white film. In 2012 I graduated with a Fine Arts degree in Photography.

Engine is providing the space and the utility costs for the darkroom. I will be responsible for the fit-up and equipment used in the darkroom. The fit up includes electrical, plumbing work, installing ventilation, along with purchasing various darkroom equipment for the proper disposal of chemistry. No dumping chemistry down the drain...we are stewards of our environment! The cost of this work will be $3000. If successful in raising the funding, we will be able to open the darkroom in early 2016.

I'm building this space because I love the ability to make something with my hands. To express how I feel into a physical, tactile form is a process I want to share with others seeking to learn and or have the same passion. I would like to be able to pay forward the opportunity I was able to receive to others–kids, adults, artists! $3,000 will make it possible to build a space not only for black and white photography, but a place to create learn and grow. Please consider a donation today. Thank you.

Please help promote my campaign by sharing with your friends and family on facebook, twitter, instagram and email.

story:
BIO -

Airbush artist Travis Vagner has spent 2 years airbrushing murals around Vancouver, Canada - most notably a mural at the BC Children’s Hospital, to public acclaim. Brush Strokes Travis Vagner is a webisode series that was born from this mural, in an effort to share the love.


Vagner now works internationally, recently completing donated works in Cambodia for local sustainable enterprises, with Indonesia, Australia and the US next on the list.


Vagners goal is to take his airbrushes far and wide across the globe to continue to connect with people and their stories of healing, producing art to assist in the healing process which reflects our collective traumatic experiences and the strength it takes to overcome these.


You contribution will ensure Vagners work continues to inspire people across the world. And, as a personal bonus to you, Travis will gift you a personally signed limited edition print.


Viewers are taken through the entire journey starting with the project concept and ending with the often-emotional project unveil. A typical episode starts with me meeting the individual(s) who have a canvas/mural idea so they can share their story. We then plan out the project and I get to work. I build the frame and stretch the canvas by hand, then move into airbrushing, and finish the episode with the reveal. The realization in their eyes is heartwarming.


A typical episode is 6-8 minutes long but we know people want to watch the full story, so we now present a consistent 10 minute episode... and almost always includes some bumps along the way.


These webisodes have broad appeal. You don’t have to appreciate art to be drawn into the depth and variety of the human interest stories I engage with.


About this project -

Brush Strokes will take you on various journeys; most of which begin with trauma and grief and result in healing. All stories are personal. All will impact your world.

Starting with the project concept and ending with the often-emotional project unveil, a typical episode starts with me meeting with individuals who have a canvas/mural idea they want to use to explore and share their unique story. 

We then plan out the project together, and I get to work. I build the frame and stretch the canvas by hand, then move into airbrushing. The episode always finishes with the reveal. The surprise, realization, sometimes tears - and always joy - in the eyes of those I work with, is why I do what I do. 

A typical episode is 6-8 minutes long. But, we know people want the full story! We now present a consistent 9 minute episode... which always features heart-centred stories, and usually includes some bumps along the way.

You don’t have to appreciate art to be drawn into the depth and variety of the human-interest stories I engage with. Trials n Tribulations has broad appeal, although the series also captures deep connections as they are being made. Some people write to me and ask me for my help. Sometimes friends recommend a particular person’s story and know they will benefit from sharing it. My mission is to capture more of these stories, and share them with you. Your support will guarantee that I can.


Risks and challenges -

The most positive and negative experience of making these works is realizing the need. Positive in the sense that people are willing to play a role in their own healing and expose themselves enough to reveal their trauma; owning their experiences and reaching out for ways to move through it. The dark side? The sheer magnitude of requests that flood in, from all corners of the earth. 

Your contribution will play a part in responding to this vulnerability and allowing them the opportunity to connect with someone that will give of their time freely, give their talent freely and give a product of this connection – for free. 

Sharing this page will only spread the goodwill. The key to sharing my work, however, is the webseries, and you all know making this costs dollars. 

I am currently taking requests from people that have either seen my webseries (see below), found my page (also see below), or through other beneficiaries’ hopeful stories. To support my ability to respond, I am raising money to be able to take their requests, meet with these families, offer my works to them, tell their stories - and keep up the fight.

Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/TravisVagner

story:
RAGNARÖK is a Campaign to fund a short serie of scale figures to assemble and paint based in the nordic mythology.

We want to release 3 FIGURES of 1:24 scale (about 75 mm size) inspired in THOR, LOKI and FREYA of the norse mythology. 

These figures has already been sculpted in 3D by the great artists Farhad Nojumi and Ali Jalali under direction of Jesús Martin, designer and alma mater of Nocturna models.

Now we have to make it real printing and making the production of these figures, including painting the boxart ot these fantastic miniatures. Jesús will paint the master pieces, and we will be updating every step of this complete process with videos and pictures.

We had the great collaboration of some other artists to make the incredible Goals that can be gifts for you during this campaign. They are one big Ice Giant (by Daniel Bel), a Dvergr warrior dwarf style ( by Arun Nagar) and an incredible Fenrir wolf (by Caleb Nefzen). These figures will be printed and produced in 30 mm scale for all of you. It means that the Giant and the Wolf can be not so small...

Are you interested in participate in this project helping us to make it real?

WHAT DO YOU GET BACKING US??

Here you can find a detailed list of what you get backing us. There are three levels: NIFLHEIM (one figure), VALHALLA (two figures) and RAGNARÖK (three figures). You can combine them they way you like and purchase with friends!




NOCTURNA MODELS is the company ruled by the guys who brought you the most impressive figures of the last years in every scale.

We are leading a new style of scale modeling. Our designs are made by the best ones, like our current MALEFIC TIME serie by the illustrators Luis Royo and Romulo Royo. May be you know us for the lines of FAIRY TALE GIRLS, our EPIC 30 mm serie, the classic and original HEROES AND LEGENDS 54 mm figures, or the historic miniatures of HISTORICART.

All of our figures are available in resin kits to assemble and paint with our registered denomination of quality HD cast.


Know more about us and our Figures

Join us in Facebook


                     

How does it work?  

Our Perks are divided in three groups: NIFLHEIM, VALHALLA and RAGNARÖK. Just choose one, two or three of our figures in the combination that you prefer and contribute! Simple as Tanngrisnir!

SHIPPING COSTS WORLDWIDE ARE INCLUDED!

                      

These 30 mm miniatures and 75 mm accesories are EXCLUSIVE for the backers of this campaign. 


It´s a way to say THANK YOU for your help. We think that they are THE BEST GOALS we have been able to release, not simple low quality gifts.

Each Perk, NIFLHEIM, VALHALLA and RAGNARÖK gives you acces to a different level of GOALS. Read it in the description of each Perk.
story_txt:
RAGNARÖK is a Campaign to fund a short serie of scale figures to assemble and paint based in the nordic mythology.


We want to release 3 FIGURES of 1:24 scale (about 75 mm size) inspired in THOR, LOKI and FREYA of the norse mythology. 
These figures has already been sculpted in 3D by the great artists Farhad Nojumi and Ali Jalali under direction of Jesús Martin, designer and alma mater of Nocturna models.
Now we have to make it real printing and making the production of these figures, including painting the boxart ot these fantastic miniatures. Jesús will paint the master pieces, and we will be updating every step of this complete process with videos and pictures.
We had the great collaboration of some other artists to make the incredible Goals that can be gifts for you during this campaign. They are one big Ice Giant (by Daniel Bel), a Dvergr warrior dwarf style ( by Arun Nagar) and an incredible Fenrir wolf (by Caleb Nefzen). These figures will be printed and produced in 30 mm scale for all of you. It means that the Giant and the Wolf can be not so small...
Are you interested in participate in this project helping us to make it real?
WHAT DO YOU GET BACKING US??
Here you can find a detailed list of what you get backing us. There are three levels: NIFLHEIM (one figure), VALHALLA (two figures) and RAGNARÖK (three figures). You can combine them they way you like and purchase with friends!










NOCTURNA MODELS is the company ruled by the guys who brought you the most impressive figures of the last years in every scale.

We are leading a new style of scale modeling. Our designs are made by the best ones, like our current MALEFIC TIME serie by the illustrators Luis Royo and Romulo Royo. May be you know us for the lines of FAIRY TALE GIRLS, our EPIC 30 mm serie, the classic and original HEROES AND LEGENDS 54 mm figures, or the historic miniatures of HISTORICART.
All of our figures are available in resin kits to assemble and paint with our registered denomination of quality HD cast.






Know more about us and our Figures
Join us in Facebook


                     How does it work?  Our Perks are divided in three groups: NIFLHEIM, VALHALLA and RAGNARÖK. Just choose one, two or three of our figures in the combination that you prefer and contribute! Simple as Tanngrisnir!SHIPPING COSTS WORLDWIDE ARE INCLUDED!

miniatures and 75 mm accesories are EXCLUSIVE for the backers of this campaign.

able to release, not simple low quality gifts.

story:
Before I get started I would like to share with you how I first met Eric Botbyl. About 3 years ago, I randomly emailed him asking if he would be interested in represent my pots in his gallery. A few days later Eric called me and we had a great conversation, not just about pots, but also about everything else in life. At the end of the conversation he asked me if I would like to be the featured artist in June of 2016.  Since that point, Eric has become a good friend and mentor. For my thesis show he rounded up some of the Companion crew and drove over 4 hours to be at the opening reception. 

Since day one he has treated me like family and I have gained some amazing friends while being apart of Companion Gallery. So enough of my blabbering and time to get to the point. A little over a month ago Eric called me with an abrupt change of plans, I'll let you read it from his own words:

"So...after nearly 11 years at our current location... we are moving quite suddenly. Last year we purchased a fixer upper down the street with the thought of renovating it slowly over the next few years. Our Friends at the winery recently explained that to move forward with the next phase of their business they needed out current building. While the timeline is less than Ideal, we are in full support of their venture. So begins the renovation, New roof, driveway, windows, doors, plumbing, electrical... everything... hopefully by January. It is a daunting task ahead of us but this image brings me much comfort. My girls were babies during the last 2 renovations and moves, but they aren't babies anymore. They are strong, capable, and eager to help. With the help of the indispensable Buddy Mike and Andrew Clark we have begun construction already while we wait for good news back from the bank. Wish us luck. The new studio and future home of Companion Gallery are in the works. " Eric Botbyl

Knowing Eric is one that would never ask for help I called a few other artists in the gallery and we started to brainstorm. We decided would donate our pots and try to put a roof over his head much like he has for all of us over the years. In the following days this is the email that went out to Companion artists and friends. 

Hello Companion Gallery Crew!

This is being done without the participation of Eric Botbyl. He is very hesitant to ask or willing to accept help. Hopefully the email that follows will make us all think to a time time where Eric has given to us.

"In December 5, 2015, my daughter was born 8 weeks prematurely. This unexpected bump in the road came right as our family was gearing up for the busiest sales season of the year for a studio potter. Instead of making, and selling pots, we spent a month in the NICU as our daughter grew big enough to leave the hospital.

I'm telling you this story, because in the midst of this challenge for our family, Eric Botbyl decided to sell my pots on my behalf for the holiday season of 2015, withholding his own commission and sending 100% of sales my way. His generosity lifted my spirits, and my bank account at a time when I was struggling to keep both afloat.

I'm sure many of you have stories of your own about Eric's generosity and ongoing effort to build community around clay. His genuine care for others, and his own intentional interest in cultivating positive relationships are why he, and Companion Gallery, feel like family to many of us." -Justin Rothshank

Several of us are interested in helping Eric continue to build the Companion Gallery. As you may know, he's purchased a property to expand the gallery and studio. But lack of a new roof on this building has prevented him from moving forward on the project. In addition, he was recently been asked if he could move by the new year. He hopes to be there by the deadline but he is undertaking a large financial burden to do so. 

Here is where you come in . . . 

As artists working with Companion Gallery, we're hoping to raise $12,000 thru a crowdfunding sale of donated artworks, to help Eric put a new roof on the new gallery or reimburse the financial burden.

We hope, thru this sale, to bolster the work of Eric, Jill, and the rest of the Companion Gallery family to continue building positive relationships in the ceramic community. And to continue to innovatively approach what it means to be a potter, gallery owner, and curator in our field.

Thank you for considering it,

Justin Rothshank, Mark Arnold, and Tim Kowalczyk

 

As the campaign goes over the next 30 days you will be seeing countless stories of Eric's genuine kindness! I would like to Thank your for taking the time to read this and hope you can support this campaign by either purchasing something or reposting for others to see. 

Thanks, Mark Arnold, and the Companion Gallery Artists
