story:
Who I am and What I do

My name is Tracey Polyflavour and I'm a polymer clay artist living in Paris, France.  I've been making art objects and jewelery with polymer clay since 1991.  This month I really need support.
I'm offering pre-orders for the holiday season on bowls, boxes, bracelets, earrings, clocks, refrigerator magnets and any custom order at prices lower than retail.


    I need to raise 1700€ by the first week of October.

    The funds I raise will be used to buy supplies and pay my back rent.
    Look at photos of finished work and the polymer clay canes for ideas about your custom order!

      The Impact

      Every piece of Polyflavour is hand made with love and care to be cherished and enjoyed forever.  Most of my work is inspired by old timey cartoons and comics from the 1930s and 1940s and I truly enjoy and love working with this material.  I'm inspired by all kinds of art and exquisite design and my passion for detail shows in my work.  Every piece is finished with the Polyflavour insignia and the year it was made.  I think this adds to my work's collectibility.




      The Perks

      Here are a few past bangles.  They are approximately 25mm wide and the opening for your hand is approximately 65mm.




        Please share this with your favorite people!

        Even if you can't contribute, share this with your friends.  I'm on facebook all the time.  I post images on my Divine Temple of Polyflavour page, as well as my new artwork on my Polyflavour page and my personal facebook page.  I love art and I love to inspire others and educate people a little about the vast and marvelous world of visual art.  I really need help to keep it up!

Who I am and What I do My name is Tracey Polyflavour and I'm a polymer clay artist 
living in Paris, France.  I've been making art objects and jewelery with
 polymer clay since 1991.  This month I really need support.I'm 
offering pre-orders for the holiday season on bowls, boxes, bracelets, 
earrings, clocks, refrigerator magnets and any custom order at prices 
lower than retail.
   I need to raise 1700€ by the first week of October.
The funds I raise will be used to buy supplies and pay my back rent.Look at photos of finished work and the polymer clay canes for ideas about your custom order! story:
For decades, one of the largest human rights injustices, was never publicly acknowledged. Even now, we don’t know their stories- who were they and where were they from?

From 1932-1945, hundreds of thousands of women were enslaved by the Japanese military into forced prostitution. Thousands of brothels, or “comfort stations” were constructed throughout Asia and Southeast Asia. Women were kidnapped, tricked, and sold into slavery- replaced as they died. Though Chinese and Korean women made up a large percentage of the women, at least 10% were poor Japanese women. Thousands more were Southeast Asia women, and several hundred were women of European descent. 90% of these women died before the end of World War II. The “comfort stations” continued to operate with/in the US military for another year afterward. There are very few survivors.

After the end of WWII, Japanese officials destroyed all related documents on the system. We no longer have a record of these women- but we refuse to let their stories die. Though many brave women have stepped forward to tell their story, there has been active, systematic efforts by the Japanese government and right wing organizations to downplay and erase these crimes. Our goal is to spread global awareness on this issue- and give voices to the women who suffered and died. They will not be forgotten.

(Photo by Weng San Sit )

The Performance Plan

We are planning two performances in the coming months; one in Tokyo and one in Seoul.

The performance in Seoul will take place on Wednesday May 1st, on the coronation of the new Japanese Emperor.

The performance will take place at the site of 1385th Wednesday Demonstration, a weekly protest in Korea which has been held every Wednesday Since 1992, demanding Japan to address the Comfort Women problems.

The performance in Tokyo will be held in July at a University Campus in the form of a guerrilla performance. We are not announcing the exact time and place due to the growing concerns of possible threat and attacks from anti-movements.

If you want to attend the performance in Tokyo, please contact Ho Jong-suk for the up-to-date information.
j.ho(at)tomorrowgirlstroop.com
You need to donate more than $27 here in order to attend the event.  We consider this as a ticket.


(Photo by Qianwen Jiang)

Both performances are in collaboration with Yoshiko Shimada, a senior artist who has been long dedicated to creating anti- war art and feminist art.

Shimada has been performing her piece “Becoming ‘Japanese comfort’ women statue” since 2012. Through her performance, she visualize and aims to give voice to the Japanese ‘comfort’ women who has been neglected in the popular narrative of Japanese national history. So far, the performance has taken place in many locations including Yasukuni, in front of the Japanese embassy in London, in front of Japanese congress, and in Glendale park LA, where she commemorated the Victims of ‘comfort women’ in collaboration with TGT.

 

(Photo by Nanyi Jiang)

We are Tomorrow Girls Troop, a 4th wave feminist social art collective fighting the prevalent gender inequality issue in Korea and Japan through art.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need funding to be able to hold this event to the best of our ability.

we are also actively seeking funding in Korea and Japan here. ( fund raised here will be used to offset those costs. Feel free to share the information with family and friends who do not speak English as their first language)

Estimated costs include:

  • $750 Hiring videographer in Seoul.
  • $1000 Hiring videographer in Tokyo.
  • $900 Hiring video editor to edit three videos from LA, Tokyo and Seoul.
  • $200 Hiring photographer in Tokyo.
  • $1500 Research/Interview project about how Japanese young people think about comfort women issue.
  • $300 Placards cost in Seoul and Tokyo
  • $200 Props for performance in Seoul and Tokyo
  • $1500 Making webpages and writing journals about "comfort women" issue for young audience in three languages (JP/KR/EN).
  • $1500 for two member's flight (Seoul-Tokyo)+ hotel for 7 days + transportation fee in Tokyo
  • $2000 for flight (LAX-Tokyo) + hotel for 7 days + transportation fee in Tokyo
    Our choreographer/art director lives in Los Angels area.  
    She needs to be in Tokyo to organize this performance and related events.

(Photo by Qianwen Jiang)

The Impact

The artists’ performances aim to overcome the nationalism strongly engraved in the issue, and to seek solidarity beyond the boundaries between the nations in the past and the present.

Through this performance, we wish to educate Japanese youth through art performances, video works, photo works. Due to the intentional erasure of this history from textbooks, many Japanese people remain willfully ignorant or in denial of these crimes.

The forgotten history of comfort women is not one of political importance, but should be recognized as a crime against women internationally. As such, we wish to bring attention and awareness to violence against women still prevalent in the world today. In addition, we would like to create an opportunity for our audience to think about the issue of sexual violence during  wartime that continues all over the world and is not globally condemned, as observed through the still unsolved "comfort women" problem.

We at TGT, would like to realize solidarity and sisterhood across generations and countries. 

 

About Perks

 

End Credit (ED)

Your name will appear on ending credit as a supporter on our "Against Forgetting" performance video.

TGT Original Against Forgetting Sticker
Against forgetting sticker is a placard image that we use for our performance about comfort women.  

(181x75mm) Three images are printed in a chain. Please cut it and use it.

TGT Original No means No Sticker

No means No sticker is a placard image that we used for the "Believe Campaign" to change Japanese sexual assault law in 2017.  The design was by Oasa Duverney, new york based artist. (60mm x 72mm)

TGT Art Work : Hidden Feminist Certificate 

We believes that one way to encourage the use of the word “feminism” and the spread of feminism’s ideals is by thanking the many “hidden feminists” out there, heightening awareness of how people can help support women and equality.  We started the project to send out this certificate to people who we think contribute to women’s issue in japan.
More about this project 



TGT Original Solidarity Pin

"Solidarity" in three languages, Japanese, Korean and English.  
This project aims to call for solidarity across borders and generations.
Silver base, 3 colors, 28mm x 25.8mm


TGT Original Solidarity Tote
"Solidarity" in three languages, Japanese, Korean and English.  
This project aims to call for solidarity across borders and generations.
Size (360mm x 400mm, cotton)

* Bag + pin are very cute together! Please check out our 45$ perk.

 

 

TGT Original Against Forgetting Tote
Against Forgetting Tote bag 
Written in Japanese, English and Korean. 
Size (390mm x 340mm, 10cm, cotton material, ivory color, with pocket)

* Bag + pin are very cute together! Please check out our 45$ perk.

 

TGT Original 21st century feminist tote

21st century feminist tote was designed by the artist, Erica Greenwald for Japanese young feminists.
Large size 480×400×150(mm)   Cotton 100%   Thick and heavy-duty canvas fabric.  (12 once thickness)

TGT Original No Means No T-shirt

Feminist T-shirt & pin for future feminists!  Only 4 left for this design!
This Tshirt is about the same size as GAP Kids XXL (14-16 years old) . 
No means No design is a placard image that we used for the "Believe Campaign" to change Japanese sexual assault law in 2017.  The design was by Oasa Duverney, new york based artist.

 

TGT Original Girls Power T-shirt

Feminist T-shirt & pin for future feminists!  Only 4 left for this design!
This Tshirt is about the same size as GAP Kids XXL (14-16 years old) . 
Girls Power T-shirt design is from a placard that we used for Girls Power Parade 2016 in Omotesando, Tokyo.

 

TGT Original My Body My Rule T-shirt

Only 4 left for this design!  This T-shirt is about the same size as ZARA women's medium size.  Very stretchy, comfortable material.  Cotton 50% Polyester 50% 
My body my rules T-shirt was designed by Brazilian artist Nik Neves for Tomorrow Girls Troop.

 

TGT ART Work: Against Forgetting Photo Print

8.5 x 11 inch color print
Edition 1/50 ~ 25/50

and

11.7 x 16.5 in color print
Edition 1/25 ~ 15/25

Hand written signature from Tomorrow Girls Troop and edition number on the back of print

Photo was taken at February 18, 2–4pm, 2018, Glendale Central Park, LA
Photographer Weng San Sit 


TGT ART Work: Yoshiko Shimada photo print

8.5 x 11 inch color print
Edition 1/50 ~ 25/50

​and

11.7 x 16.5 in color print
Edition 1/25 ~ 15/25

Hand written signature from Tomorrow Girls Troop and edition number on the back of print

Photo was taken at February 18, 2–4pm, 2018, Glendale Central Park, LA
Photographer Weng San Sit 


 

TGT ART Work: Woman in politics A1 print

"A woman’s place is in the house… And the senate"
Color print, A1 size, Edition 1/25.  
This is collaboration work with Elana Mann and online feminist bilingual magazine honeyhands.  
This print was for mid term election in 2018 and exhibited at Pitzer College Art Galleries in Elana Mann's solo show.  There are pinhole on the corners.
More information about this artwork 


TGT ART Work: Gender Equality ​ A1 print

“家でも政治でもジェンダー平等！” literally reads “Gender Equality at Home and in Politics,” a re-interpretation of the English slogan “A woman’s place is in the house… And the senate” for a Japanese audience.
Color print, A1 size, Edition 1/25.  
This is collaboration work with Elana Mann and online feminist bilingual magazine honeyhands.  
This print was made for Japanese election in July 2019 and exhibited at Pitzer College Art Galleries in Elana Mann's solo show.  There are pinhole on the corners.

More information about this artwork 


"MALE FEMINIST IN TRAINING" bumper sticker by Alan Nakagawa

This bumper sticker was donated by LA based artist Alan Nakagawa .

 

Charity Karaoke Party in LA! 

Date & Time: June 21, Fri, 8pm~
Address: 3745 Roberta St, Los Angeles, CA 90031-1645, United States

Join Tomorrow Girls Troop at the artist Young Soon Min's home to sing karaoke and party in support of the upcoming 'Against Forgetting' performances in Seoul and Tokyo!!

‘Against Forgetting' is an art performance that connects the plight of "comfort women" and our current reckoning with sexual harassment.

Come ready to sing and dance in solidarity, or to simply chat & cheer while enjoying snacks and beverages with TGT members and our extended LA community.

$15, $25, $50 $100 tickets are available here!
Snacks, drinks and your name listed on the credits at the end of our video are included with all tickets.
In addition:
$25 tickets come with "Male Feminist in Training" bumper sticker that were made by Alan Nakagawa
$50 tickets come with all of the above and an original TGT solidarity pin.
$100 tickets come with all of the above and a bottle of hand crafted shochu from Kagoshima, Japan (not on sale in the US).

For those who prefer to pay cash, some tickets will be available at the door, but please RSVP on Facebook!
https://www.facebook.com/events/2231426363741685/

We hope to celebrate the effort ‘Against Forgetting’ with you soon~

 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Support our organization in other ways!

    Please support us over at Patreon.
    By being our patreon, you have access to our journal about East Asian Feminism!!


    If you want to know more about Japanese feminism in the past and current...
    Feminism in Japan, by Grace Lee Boggs
    TGT Guide to Resources About the State of Feminism in Japan, Part I
    Was post-war Japanese culture really only created by men? The Post-War Women Appreciation Project, or How TGT Members Get Their Names​

    You can also read TGT members interviews!!  We interviewed our Korean, Japanese, Chinese, and Taiwanese members who lives in all over the world!

    A Feminist Artist on Three Continents - Interview with TGT Member Natsu Kawasaki
    From Objectification to Agency: Interview with TGT member Myeong-soon Kim

    You can read more about us in the FAQ section, or learn about our other projects in the past.
    1. A Woman's Place
    2. Koenji Petition
    3. The Believe Project
    4. Against Forgetting

     

    Please share our campaign with your friends and family- and educate them about "comfort" women.

story:
Water by the Spoonful is a play by Quiara Alegría Hudes. It won the 2012 Pulitzer Prize for Drama. This play will take place at the Royal Theater in the Producers Club in New York City. The performance dates are May 19th -21st. Two performances will start @7pm and the other @4pm. 

In a far corner of the internet, moderator “Haikumom” (aka Odessa Ortiz) leads a chat room for recovering drug addicts, From behind their screens, these individuals who might never encounter each other in real life -- a student, an IRS-pusher, and a financier-- forge a bond as strong as blood. Off the computer, however, in a Puerto Rican neighborhood in North Philly, Odessa Ortiz’s real-life family is falling apart. Her son, Elliot, has returned from Iraq both physically and emotionally broken. Her niece, Yaz, is unable to reconcile her identity as a North Philly girl from the barrio with her upper-crust, intellectual lifestyle. Her sister, who was the mother that Odessa could never be, is dying of cancer. Inventive and timely, Quiara Alegria Hudes’ Pulitzer Prize-winning Water By the Spoonful is a powerful, compassionate look at the meaning of family, and the burdens we must carry to protect it.
 

We- Nick (Elliot), Anne (Odessa), Ashley (Yaz), Tomo (Fountainhead),Tony (Chutes&Ladders), Suzanna (Orangutan) and Jean Carlos (Ghost) have come together along with our Director, Gabriela Montalvo (MFA in Directing from University of Chile) and decided that this play will have the potential to be a unique and creative theater experience. Each of us comes from a different background, whether it be actors training, ethnicity, language and life experiences that will elevate this play beyond ordinary boundaries. This will be a challenge for the actors and the director and this is the perfect play for all of us to explore, learn and grow as artists in today's world. 

In order to get this excellent piece of theater off the ground and on the stage, we need YOU! Your generous donations will go towards theater rental, production design, and marketing.  Being a part of this journey goes towards this unique production that comes with many perks - personalized thank-you notes, video shout-outs,writing lessons, paintings from some of New York's most talented artists and PUERTO RICAN Sandals! 

We can't wait to share it with you.  As a contributor, you can rest assured that you won't be disappointed.  

Thank you!

Inventive and timely, Quiara Alegria Hudes’ Pulitzer Prize-winning Water By the Spoonful is a powerful, compassionate look at the meaning of family, and the burdens we must carry to protect it. We- Nick (Elliot), Anne (Odessa), Ashley (Yaz), Tomo (Fountainhead),Tony (Chutes&Ladders), Suzanna (Orangutan) and Jean Carlos (Ghost) have come together along with our Director, Gabriela Montalvo (MFA in Directing from University of Chile) and decided that this play will have the potential to be a unique and creative theater experience. Each of us comes from a different background, whether it be actors training, ethnicity, language and life experiences that will elevate this play beyond ordinary boundaries. This will be a challenge for the actors and the director and this is the perfect play for all of us to explore, learn and grow as artists in today's world. In order to get this excellent piece of theater off the ground and on the stage, we need YOU! Your generous donations will go towards theater rental, production design, and marketing.  Being a part of this journey goes towards this unique production that comes with many perks - personalized thank-you notes, video shout-outs,writing lessons, paintings from some of New York's most talented artists and PUERTO RICAN Sandals! We can't wait to share it with you.  As a contributor, you can rest assured that you won't be disappointed.  Thank you!

story:
Chroma is a coloring book zine dedicated to letting others color for the sake of fun! Based around the general theme of magic, each artist involved has been commissioned to draw their interpretation of the word "Magic". 

The zine consists of 20 unique lineart pieces that each backer is encouraged to color and share with their interpretation of the original artist's vision. We believe that both color and lineart are equally important for a piece - in that changes to either can drastically alter the final image. It's always interesting to see an artist have their own interpretation of another artist's vision. It allows both artists to appreciate the art from new angles.

Gamblord   
  • Twitter

The majority of the funds will be going towards shipping the tiers to you as well as funding the artists for their contributions. The remaining funds go towards printing the physical books, all taxes and fees involved in transactions across the project, as well as all the tier extras (Bookmarks, prints, stickers, pencils)


Twice each week we'll be revealing the design for the prints, bookmarks and stickers that are included in the tiers in an Indiegogo update and posts on the Chroma Twitter and Tumblr! See higher resolution versions of the released designs here!

Any extra money we raise goes straight back into the zine. The goal we've set is what we need to break even on the project so that all the artists get paid the amount desired for their services. If we break this goal and exceed our expectations, we have plans to possibly include more merchandise in the tier extras (more prints, charms etc) as well as pay the artists more for their contributions.

Our main risk is that we won't sell enough copies of the zine due to the limit of our combined marketing efforts. To break even on the zine and make sure that every artists is paid a decent amount, we've got a rough estimate of copies that need to be sold, hence our Indiegogo goal. If the full amount isn't reached, we will be forced to pay out of pocket to ensure that all the artists are paid fairly. Because of the way we are shipping the zine, it may take a lot longer to ship depending on how many copies are sold. We also may have delays due to unexpected reasons. Rest assured though, we've gone to great lengths planning every aspect of this zine, accounting for as many unexpected variables as possible.


Why does the zine cost that much?

With the purchase of the zine, both digital and physical, you're purchasing the ability to color the artist's work. We've essentially commissioned them for not only the pieces, but the rights to those pieces as well. By most artist's standards this would normally be classed as stealing but all the artists in the zine have agreed to share their work this way for the zine. 

This zine isn't based off of any existing IP meaning the only draw to it is the premise and our combined followings. Since we are all relatively small artists, we only have small followings. As much as we'd like to estimate that we'd sell a million copies of the zine, it just isn't realistic so we've had to be conservative in our estimates so that all the artists still get paid. It rounds out to roughly $1 per artist after tax is taken out.


Why so few artists?

Since this is our first zine in terms of production, we've wanted to keep the scope of the project low so that the risk to the artists isn't too great - having too many artists increases the required amount of copies sold. We didn't want to risk the livelihood of artists just for the sake of increasing the roster. Most of us have been involved in a zine in some shape or form in the past and we know the dangers of an inflated scope. Not to mention the nature and approach we've taken to making this coloring book as well.


Will this be sold after the campaign ends as well?

Only the digital PDF version will available to purchase after the campaign ends - it'll be put up on Gumroad and a link will be provided on the Chroma Zine social media accounts. We'd only consider reprinting the zine if we receive enough attention and  it would be economically possible to do such after the campaign ends.


Why is it invite only?

Again, we didn’t want any harm to possibly come to an artist that just wanted to apply to the zine. We’re using artists that trust us on a personal level because in the worse case scenario we can recover and they would understand. 


Why are you using Indiegogo?

Indiegogo allows us to basically see our goals in real time, we know exactly how many books to print and how many PDF’s will be sold. It’s more of a safety precaution so that we don’t under or over estimate the amount of merch and books that we print in the end.


Where are the profits going?

All the profits are going to the artists that helped make the zine possible. We’re artists ourselves so we understand the need for artists to make money at the end of the day. This zine revolves around these artists allowing others to do what they will with their art so we wanted to make sure they're compensated as such.

Aside from profit the money for the physical copies are going to straight to printing and shipping costs. The books will pay for themselves and any profit after taxes, merch, printing, shipping, and the like will be given to the artists. The curators aren't taking any extra profits, only artists who created a piece will receive compensation. 


When is the physical copy being sent out?

It's estimated two months at the soonest after the Indiegogo finishes we’ll be sending out the printed books! We’re estimating about two or three months after simply because it’ll take around that amount of time to receive the printed copies and ship them all out. As well as all the merchandise that needs to be printed that’s going along with the books.


What if there are delays?

If there are any delays then you'll have our sincerest apologies. Everything we’ve set up is set to a very detailed schedule but unexpected things will always happen. Printing might get delayed with merch, or the books might take a little longer to get fully printed. We'll keep you up to date through Indiegogo updates and the social media accounts if anything happens or changes! We just ask you to bear with us if something happens and we promise to try and give you the best backer experience possible!


I need to contact you!

Go for it! You can contact us at coloringbookzine@gmail.com or DM us on Twitter

We’ll reply as fast as we can and try to help as much as possible!

story:
Simone et le whole shebang est le troisième texte original de l'auteure et comédienne Eugénie Beaudry. Elle s'est entourée d'une équipe extraordinaire pour la production de la pièce à la salle Fred-Barry du Théâtre Denise-Pelletier en avril 2016. Vincent Bilodeau, Louise Bombardier, Robin-Joël Cool et Eugénie Beaudry interpréteront les personnages à la langue acérée de ce texte à l'humour noir et grinçant. Simone et le whole shebang est une production du Laboratoire théâtre, dont Eugénie Beaudry est la directrice artistique et générale. 


Un centre pour personnes âgées, un "parking à vieux" de Fort McMurray, où Simone est "dompée là" de force par sa fille. Simone y rencontre Jessy, un vieux cowboy édenté qui y termine ses jours noyé dans l'alcool. Ils se retrouveront dans l'amour de la musique et le désir que le "party" continue. Jessy finira même par révéler son désir le plus profond à Simone, ce qui la bouleversera au plus haut point et changera leur destiné à tous dans ce décor dénué de charme, au fond des champs gris couverts de suie de pétrole où rien ne pousse. 


Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez

Nous avons besoin d'un modeste montant (2000$) afin de compléter notre budget de production pour assurer aux membres de la production d'être payés adéquatement, puisque pour le Laboratoire théâtre, les conditions de travail des artistes est une priorité. 

Nous vous offrons un partenariat financier et une visibilité dans notre programme, sur nos affiches et notre cartes postales (qui seront distribués à de nombreux endroits stratégiques de la ville). Nous vous offrons également la chance de gagner des paires de billets afin d'assister à notre spectacle. 

L'impact

Le Laboratoire théâtre est, comme son nom l'indique, un lieu d'essai, de création et d'exploration pour artistes de tous horizons. Il s'est donné pour mandat de donner une voix à ceux qu'on n'entend jamais, les laissés pour contre. Dans Gunshot de Lulla West (2011), on assiste à la décente aux enfers d'un frère et d'une soeur musiciens sur la côte qui peinent à survivre de leur art dans une société où les emplois manquent et la pèche est en perte de vitesse. Le Trou (2014) révèle une jeune femme, Sara-Lee, enfermée dans son sous-sol par crainte du monde extérieur, qui essaie de sauver son village à la suite de la fermeture de l'usine locale. Simone et le whole shebang parle de deux personnes âgées en perte d'autonomie qui tentent de trouver un peu de dignité dans un lieu où tout les oublie. 

Oui, le théâtre du Laboratoire est engagé et ses spectacles ont toujours une touche de fraicheur, un bel humour et un langage coloré. Faire découvrir un univers unique et ludique reste l'une de ses priorités. 

Le Laboratoire théâtre a eu une excellente revue de presse pour ses deux premiers spectacles. Obtenir votre appui serait un atout de taille pour poursuivre son mandat. C'est un moyen de soutenir la culture et de s'immerger dans un univers qui suscite la discussion. 

D'autres façons d'aider

PARTAGER!!! 

Assister au spectacle! 

Répandre la nouvelle sur Facebook, par courriel, en en parlant à vos amis!!! 

Merci et au plaisir de vous voir lors du spectacle!

story:
Artist Statement

I majored in English and minored in art at Central Connecticut State University. What started out as a doodling pastime grew into an interesting mental exercise in many mediums. I tell stories with my images, like choreographing each color and shape into a pivotal moment from a strange dream. While each one has its own meaning for me, I invite the viewer to see what is triggered in their own mind; a surreal Rorschach test for the imagination.

Contributors will be supporting my art and my first solo show. The show is at MAC650 Gallery in Middletown, CT. The reception is open to everyone and will be on December 3rd from 5-8. The art will be displayed until December 22nd.

What Contributors Will Receive

  • Anyone who donates $5 dollars will receive one of my Christmas cards.
  • For $20 dollars you will receive a 12x12 print of your choice. (View available prints in the gallery section of this site)
  • For $30 dollars you will receive a 18x18 print of your choice.
  • For $35 dollars you will receive 2 12x12 prints of your choice.
  • For $50 dollars you will receive 2 18x18 prints of your choice.
  • For $300 you will receive an individualized, 30x24 painting.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute but want to support my art, please share the link to my event and Indiegogo page. Also, I would love to see you at the show!

story:
Hi, I'm Clarissa, and for the past 9 years I have been fighting a severely debilitating illness called POTS Syndrome. After years of suffering and round the clock nursing, I was admitted to the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, MN. Because of this treatment, I have gotten well enough to attend school again. I was accepted into the CalArts Animation Summer Residency, which was a dream come true. It was a great experience where I was really able to learn and grow as a professional artist. Unfortunately, it was also quite expensive. My family already has a large amount of medical debt due to my illness and the Mayo Clinic treatment, so I need to pay off my student debt as soon as possible.

That’s where you can help! I’m not asking for donations without a return, and I believe art is the greatest thing I can give back. We have organized an art stream event taking place Saturday, June 27, from 11AM - 6PM PST. We have four artists who will draw whatever your heart desires, we will create custom merchandise and ship it to you, and we will have a raffle for a big prize and a few other fun surprises throughout the stream!

You can find a stream for each artist here:

Tamurakitty, Clarissa, Dylan, Danni

You can request any kind of art*, including vector images, graphics, and photoshops. You request an artist, but we cannot guarantee that artist will be available during the stream. Orders will take longer to process than the stream duration, and larger orders will take additional time (we will contact you immediately if this is the case).

(The stickers are 3in x 4in and are waterproof vinyl, the art prints are 12in x 16in. If you want to mix and match, or want something that Redbubble or Society6 can manufacture, please let us know and we will do our best to accommodate you.)

We would appreciate if you spread the word, thank you for taking the time to check out my campaign!

*We do have the right to refuse/change your request within reason (e.i. it’s extremely graphic, illegal, or more work than the donation could justify).

story:
Hello to all my lovely friends and family! 

As you know I have being training hula hoop for a couple of years now and only until early this year I took a massive step and decided to train full time, with the intentions of applying for a particular circus school called the National Centre for Circus Arts in London. With the competition being so high, unfortunately I did not get accepted into the school. However they have invited me to apply again next year after gaining more experience in certain areas. 

With your financial support I could have a chance to be accepted next year. I need to seriously up my game! After much research, i found a school in Beijing which I was able to tailor to my needs with a main focus on multi hooping, handstands, tumbling and flexibility. Upon a video audition I have been offered a place at Beijing International Art School which will be starting at the end of September. 

I need funding to seek professional guidance to get me at a very high skill level in order to compete in the industry. If I raise enough money I can stay at the school and train full time for 1 year.

This is my passion and I have worked so hard  to get me where I am today, but I need to keep progressing to take my skill to the next level  and become a professional  hula hoop artist. 

With your support I can turn a dream into reality.

Hello to all my lovely friends and family! 

As you know I have being training hula hoop for a couple of years now and only until early this year I took a massive step and decided to train full time, with the intentions of applying for a particular circus school called the National Centre for Circus Arts in London. With the competition being so high, unfortunately I did not get accepted into the school. However they have invited me to apply again next year after gaining more experience in certain areas. 

With your financial support I could have a chance to be accepted next year. I need to seriously up my game! After much research, i found a school in Beijing which I was able to tailor to my needs with a main focus on multi hooping, handstands, tumbling and flexibility. Upon a video audition I have been offered a place at Beijing International Art School which will be starting at the end of September. 


I need funding to seek professional guidance to get me at a very high skill level in order to compete in the industry. If I raise enough money I can stay at the school and train full time for 1 year.

This is my passion and I have worked so hard  to get me where I am today, but I need to keep progressing to take my skill to the next level  and become a professional  hula hoop artist. 

With your support I can turn a dream into reality.

story:
SCROLL DOWN FOR ENGLISH   

 

“La synagogue est l’ultime témoin d’une présence juive ici durant cinq siècles ..mais qui peut disparaître de notre mémoire collective en l’espace d’une génération. “

Raymond Lévy, dernier juif de Reichshoffen


L’artiste
Bienvenue! Mon nom est Ben Jack Nash. Je suis d’origine Britannique mais je vit et travaille à Strasbourg. Mon travail fut, à plusieurs reprises, sélectionné pour des prix d’art importants. J'ai également exposé pour des curateurs, des institutions et des artistes réputés. Mes œuvres furent visibles à l’Arsenal de Venise, à Londres et New York. Vous pouvez regarder mon CV artistique ici.

Je me réjouis fort de pouvoir travailler pour ce projet si important et passionnant.

Le projet

Cette importante campagne de collecte de fonds, largement diffusée,  va permettre de donner réalité à l’installation d’un projet artistique ambitieux et à grande échelle. Le projet redonnera vie à une synagogue abandonnée dans la petite ville alsacienne de Reichshoffen, dans les Vosges du Nord.  L’exposition sera ouvert au public à partir de mars 2018.

Un peu d’histoire : durant près d’un millénaire, l’Alsace a été l’épicentre de la vie juive d’où a émergé la langue Yiddish (yiddish-daitch/ judéo-alsacien), et aussi le fameux foie gras. Interdites dans les villes jusqu’en 1791, les communautés juives se sont essentiellement développées dans les campagnes. Dans les années les plus glorieuses, il y avait quelques 200 synagogues réparties sur cette magnifique région rurale,  et souvent dans des endroits très reculés. Nombre d’entre elles ont été détruites, en partie par les nazis, en partie par dégradation naturelle, alors que les communautés juives peu à peu disparaissaient. 

Bien que  la synagogue de Reichshoffen ait subi des tirs de balle, des incendies et des pillages, elle est une des dernières encore debout.

Avec la création, ce projet ambitieux cherche à redonner un nouveau souffle à cet édifice. Il s’agit d’une installation artistique de grande ampleur réalisée spécialement pour ce site . Il se place en étroite harmonie avec l’histoire, le contexte,la spécificité et l’énergie de cette bâtisse.

Utilisant la sculpture,  la lumière et le mouvement, l’installation contrôlera et transformera la totalité de l’espace intérieur pour en faire un lieu de réflexion, de questionnement et de lien.
Elle interagira et réagira, en particulier avec les vitraux remarquables, les sculptures en pierre et avec d'autres vestiges originaux encore en place, et créera une impression générale d'intemporalité et d’émerveillement.

La plupart des gens, y compris les habitants de la ville, ignorent son histoire, sa pertinence et même son existence. Le projet vise à changer cette méconnaissance. L'architecture du bâtiment rassemble les traditions musulmanes, chrétiennes et juives; un rappel de l'importance de la diversité dans des régions hors des grandes villes.
Elle va aussi permettre à une population rurale de s’intéresser à une installation d’art contemporain de qualité et qui est habituellement accessible au public dans les grandes métropoles.


Le projet a été primé
En février 2017, le projet a obtenu le prix de la meilleure proposition de projet par “La Dinée” prix prestigieux d’art contemporain à Strasbourg (France). L’initiative a été recommandée par un nombre de curateurs de haut niveau et de directeurs de galeries.
Le projet est également fortement soutenu par le Consistoire Israélite du Bas-Rhin, la Région du Grand Est et le centre d’art contemporain Accélérateur de Particules.

A quoi servent les fonds recueillis ?

Le projet est à but non-lucratif et il est motivé uniquement par la passion et l'energie de ceux qui sont impliqués dans sa réalisation. Un projet aussi ambitieux et de cette dimension dans un bâtiment historique, génère forcément de nombreux frais. Le bâtiment est dans un état fragile, sans électricité ni éclairage. En même temps que les coûts de l’installation (matériaux, transport, assistance technique, production, fabrication, impression des catalogues), votre contribution aidera à adapter ce bâtiment abandonné pour lui permettre d’accueillir l’exposition et le public dans des conditions de sécurité.

Si la collecte dépassait les objectifs fixés, les fonds seront utilisés pour la production d’une vidéo éducative qui complétera l’exposition.


Les dates
Le vernissage de l’exposition est prévue en mars 2018. Elle devrait durer 6 mois. Elle accueillera le public mais aussi des visites scolaires, des programmes éducatifs, des visites guidées, des conférences et des symposium d’artistes. Elle donnera lieu à la publication d’un catalogue.

La contrepartie
Si vous acceptez de participer au projet, alors sheynam dank !. Ce qui signifie “merci beaucoup” en “Jeddisch Daitch”. Il est prévu quelques belles récompenses en contrepartie, y compris de superbes tirages limités de photos de l’intérieur de la synagogue prises par l’artiste, Raymond Lévy et la réalisatrice du film Hélène Lücke. Pour de plus importantes contributions, ce sont des paniers de délicieuses spécialités alsaciennes et même la fameuse choucroute alsacienne qui vous attendent.


Jetez un oeil sur la galerie d’images, sous le clip video, pour découvrir les photos disponibles.

 

‘The synagogue is the final witness to a jewish presence that has been here for five hundred years…but which in the space of a single generation could disappear from our collective memory’

Raymond Lévy, the last jew in the village

About the artist

Welcome! My name is Ben Jack Nash and I am a British visual artist based in my studio in Strasbourg, France. I work in sculpture and installation and exhibit both nationally and internationally. My work has been selected for a number of art prizes, commissions and included in exhibitions curated by well-known artists and museum directors in places such as the Venice Arsenale, London, Copenhagen and New York.

I am thrilled to be able to work on this really important and exciting project which is going to push my practise to its outer most limits. So, please join me and be a part of it too!

About the project

Due to start in March 2018, this campaign is for a large scale and ambitious art exhibition that will revive a rural abandoned synagogue putting it back on the map.

For over a thousand years, French Alsace in eastern France wan an epicentre for Jewish life giving rise to the famous Yiddish language "Jeddisch-Daitch" and even foie gras. Forbidden from the cities, jewish communities lived a rural existence. In its heyday there were some 200 synagogues dotted around the idyllic countryside often in far flung places.

Following destruction by the Nazis or through natural degradation when communities disappeared, only a fraction still stand, almost none still function. Despite being shot at, looted and set alight, Reichshoffen synagogue, the host for this project, is one of the few that remain.

Through art, this ambitious project seeks to inject a new lease of life into the building. It will be a large scale art installation exhibition constructed specifically for this site that responds in close harmony with the building’s history, context, character and its energy. Using sculpture, light and movement, it will take over and transform the entire inside space turning it into a place for reflection, question and connection. In particular it will interplay and react to the striking stained glass windows, stone carvings and other original relics still found within creating an overall sense of timelessness and awe.

Most people, including locals are unaware of its history, its relevance and even its existence. This project seeks to change that. The building’s architecture  embraces Muslim, Christian and Jewish traditions; an important reminder of diversity in an area now largely dominated by the far right.

It will also allow a rural population to engage with a museum quality contemporary art installation which can only normally be accessed in the metropolitan cities.

An award winning proposal

In February 2017, the project won the prize for best project proposal at the prestigious contemporary arts award  "La Dînée" in Strasbourg, France. The initiative was recommended by a number of high-profile curators and gallery directors. The project is also currently supported by the Consistoire Israélite du Bas Rhin, the Grand Est district and arts organisation Accélérateur de Particules.

How the money will be spent

This is a not for profit project that depends solely on the passion and energy of those involved. There are of course many costs involved with an ambitious project on this scale and where protecting the historical and delicate nature of the building is vital.  As well as the exhibition costs (materials, transport, technical assistance, production, fabrication, publicity, printing),   your contribution will also go a really long way to help the abandoned building welcome the exhibition by installing elements like electricity and lighting.

Any excess funds will go towards the production of an educational video that will accompany the exhibition.

The exhibition is due to start in March 2018 and expected to last six months. As well as welcoming the public to experience the exhibition it will also be accompanied by school visits, educational programs, guided tours, conferences, artist symposiums and an exhibition catalogue.

Perks

If you would like to be a part of this project then a sheynam dank !. That means thank you very much in Jeddisch Daitch.

There are some really great rewards including stunning limited edition prints of the inside of the synagogue taken by the artist, Raymond Levi and film maker Hélène Lücke. At the other end of the scale there  are food hampers with local delicacies and even some famous regional "choucroute" up for grabs.

Take a look at the image gallery below the video at the top to view the photos available.

 

************************************************************************************

story:
Dye with Dignity at 404 Village Not Found

Howdy! Dye with Dignity is back and better than ever. Bringing silk, dyes, Texas wine, snow cones, beer, juice, and the Wheel of Remorse to the Black Rock Desert. Join us at 404 Village not Found for shenanigans and merriment. Create your own silk art, kick back and relax in our giant monkey hut, eat a snow cone, and spin our Wheel of Remorse. Dye with Dignity, where even standing in line is fun. 

What We Need & What You Get

This year we are looking to maximize our impact on our beautiful city. Our goal is to have dye day in camp, one at the Man, and one in deep playa. To do this requires silk and silk does not come cheaply. Each 11x60 scarf costs us $3.59. A 36x60 sarong is $13.65. Last year we provided 450 scarves and 125 sarongs for our fellow citizens to let loose their creative energy upon. We would like to provide this experience to even more of you! Our goal is 1000 scarves and 100 sarongs. That's a lot of money. A staggering amount of money. So here we are asking for help. At this time we have around 200 scarves and 25 sarongs, so we have a ways to go. All proceeds from this IndieGoGo will be used for silk and dyes. The wine, beer, snow cones, juice, and ice for snow ball fights will be provided by our camp members. This campaign will only go towards the materials needed to provide an art experience to the citizens of Black Rock City.  

Thank you so much for helping us provide this experience! If money is tight for you (as it is us!) please know we have mad love for you too and would greatly appreciate your help on any of our dye days! Post a note, or send an email and we will get back to you with info on volunteer opportunities.

story:
The Journey

Hello!  My name’s Michaela Daystar, and I’m fundraising to become a certified SoulCollage® Facilitator. 

From photography, to painting, to tattooing, I’ve always sought to find and express meaning in my life through art.  I’ve woven this passion into my working life by utilizing art to explore social justice with college students; and into my community life through service to art associations, as a Regional Coordinator for the Global Art Project for Peace (http://www.globalartproject.org/), and volunteering with youth in artistic settings. 

During the six years I’ve guided the leadership development of college students through my job, I’ve developed skill and passion for teaching and mentorship.  I want to bring my passions for art, teaching and mentoring together in dynamic and life-giving ways.  I found that way with SoulCollage®.

Developed in the late 1980’s By Sena Frost, SoulCollage utilizes intuition, imagination and images to foster and deepen one’s understanding of and connection to the many aspects of one’s self through collage (www.soulcollage.com).  Using a meditative process, one creates unique  collages representing different aspects of one’s self, resulting in a deck of beautifully powerful cards.  I’ve worked with SoulCollage® in support of my own development for several months and am excited and inspired by the process—both the artist process of collaging and the deeper self-knowledge it brings. 

From the beginning, I felt a strong desire to share this process with others.  I learned that one can become certified as a SoulCollage® Facilitator through a multi-day training, and knew right away that I needed to do this.  Taking a leap of faith that I will find the support I need, I registered for the November 2013 training.  I’m turning now to my extended community to help me make this happen!

Your support will help me to share this transformative process with the college students I work with, and in the many communities I move through—and if you wish, with you too!  I plan to offer workshops and classes in both the Bay Area where I work, and the Sacramento Valley where I live, to help supplement my income.  The Sacramento Valley currently has no registered SoulCollage® facilitators, so you will be helping to introduce it to a new and wider community. 

Packing My Bags

Over the past few months, I have begun preparing for and investing in SoulCollage.  I've obtained the basic informational and training materials needed to begin creating cards and learning about the process.  I've also participated in on-line forums and trainings on various aspects of SoulCollage, and have arranged to practice facilitating SoulCollage groups in the fall.  These experiences have convinced me to take the next steps of formal training, and to request support to make it happen.

My fundraising goal is $2,500, which will be used for:

--The cost of the facilitator training, training materials/books and travel to the training location  (aprox. $1,500)

--A business license to allow me to offer SoulCollage® workshops and classes ($100)

--Materials needed to begin holding workshops (aprox. $ 800)

--Promotional materials ($100)

Of these expenses, the most critical are those directly connected with the training, so if I am unable to reach my funding goal, all funds raised will go to the training.  If I am blessed enough to exceed my goal, I will be able to attend additional on-line trainings that go deeper into specific aspects and uses of SoulCollage®.  

Expressing My Gratitude:

My art has always been most strongly inspired by the people in my life, and motivated by the desire to share it with them.  So I’m so excited at this opportunity to thank you for your support by creating art for you!  The list of thank you gifts to the right includes original art, and of course, the opportunity to experience the SoulCollage® process yourself.  I would be honored to offer a personalize SoulCollage® workshop for you or a group, or to make a SoulCollage® card in your honor.

Impact and Track Record

Through my years working with students who are passionate about social justice, and through my own exploration of myself in connection with the world, I am convinced that lasting, wide-spread peace and justice must grow from within each person, outward to the world.  We cannot love, respect, protect, and understand others until we can do these things for ourselves.  Thus I wish to contribute to positive change in the world by challenging myself and others to love and understand the self.  SoulCollage is a powerful tool in this process.

While SoulCollage® is new and exciting territory for me, I am well prepared for the journey, and will make good use of the support you give.  Below is a partial list of projects I have designed and successfully carried out:

  • Design and facilitation of three workshops with groups participating in the Global Art Project for Peace, 2012 (www.globalartproject.org)
  • Production of 3 city-wide art exhibits through my role as President of the El Cerrito Art Association (2004-2006)
  • Individual art exhibit of original photography, MC Art Gallery, 2005
  • Design and leadership for The Travelling Solar Circus, an interactive puppet show for kids that taught renewable energy concepts, through the A Different Way to Play summer camp, City of El Cerrito, 2006
  • Co-facilitator for numerous solar cooking workshops to groups in a wide variety of settings, 2005-present

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help share this campaign with your community through the Indiegogo tools, and your social networking sites!
  • Do you know of individuals or groups who would be interested in a SoulCollage® workshop?  Let them know about this campaign!  Folks who donate $300 or above can receive a 4-hour workshop for a group of up to 10 people, which is a discount from what I’ll be charging groups in the future, so it’s a great incentive to pool your donations!

During the six years I’ve guided the leadership development of college students through my job, I’ve developed skill and passion for teaching and mentorship.  I want to bring my passions for art, teaching and mentoring together in dynamic and life-giving ways.  I found that way with SoulCollage®.
Developed in the late 1980’s By Sena Frost, SoulCollage utilizes intuition, imagination and images to foster and deepen one’s understanding of and connection to the many aspects of one’s self through collage (www.soulcollage.com).  Using a meditative process, one creates unique  collages representing different aspects of one’s self, resulting in a deck of beautifully powerful cards.  I’ve worked with SoulCollage® in support of my own development for several months and am excited and inspired by the process—both the artist process of collaging and the deeper self-knowledge it brings. 
From the beginning, I felt a strong desire to share this process with others.  I learned that one can become certified as a SoulCollage® Facilitator through a multi-day training, and knew right away that I needed to do this.  Taking a leap of faith that I will find the support I need, I registered for the November 2013 training.  I’m turning now to my extended community to help me make this happen!
Your support will help me to share this transformative process with the college students I work with, and in the many communities I move through—and if you wish, with you too!  I plan to offer workshops and classes in both the Bay Area where I work, and the Sacramento Valley where I live, to help supplement my income.  The Sacramento Valley currently has no registered SoulCollage® facilitators, so you will be helping to introduce it to a new and wider community. 
Packing My Bags
Over the past few months, I have begun preparing for and investing in SoulCollage.  I've obtained the basic informational and training materials needed to begin creating cards and learning about the process.  I've also participated in on-line forums and trainings on various aspects of SoulCollage, and have arranged to practice facilitating SoulCollage groups in the fall.  These experiences have convinced me to take the next steps of formal training, and to request support to make it happen.
My fundraising goal is $2,500, which will be used for:
--The cost of the facilitator training, training materials/books and travel to the training location  (aprox. $1,500)
--A business license to allow me to offer SoulCollage® workshops and classes ($100)
--Materials needed to begin holding workshops (aprox. $ 800)
--Promotional materials ($100)
Of these expenses, the most critical are those directly connected with the training, so if I am unable to reach my funding goal, all funds raised will go to the training.  If I am blessed enough to exceed my goal, I will be able to attend additional on-line trainings that go deeper into specific aspects and uses of SoulCollage®.  
Expressing My Gratitude:
My art has always been most strongly inspired by the people in my life, and motivated by the desire to share it with them.  So I’m so excited at this opportunity to thank you for your support by creating art for you!  The list of thank you gifts to the right includes original art, and of course, the opportunity to experience the SoulCollage® process yourself.  I would be honored to offer a personalize SoulCollage® workshop for you or a group, or to make a SoulCollage® card in your honor.
Impact and Track Record
Through my years working with students who are passionate about social justice, and through my own exploration of myself in connection with the world, I am convinced that lasting, wide-spread peace and justice must grow from within each person, outward to the world.  We cannot love, respect, protect, and understand others until we can do these things for ourselves.  Thus I wish to contribute to positive change in the world by challenging myself and others to love and understand the self.  SoulCollage is a powerful tool in this process.
While SoulCollage® is new and exciting territory for me, I am well prepared for the journey, and will make good use of the support you give.  Below is a partial list of projects I have designed and successfully carried out:

Design and facilitation of three workshops with groups participating in the Global Art Project for Peace, 2012 (www.globalartproject.org)
Production of 3 city-wide art exhibits through my role as President of the El Cerrito Art Association (2004-2006)
Individual art exhibit of original photography, MC Art Gallery, 2005
Design and leadership for The Travelling Solar Circus, an interactive puppet show for kids that taught renewable energy concepts, through the A Different Way to Play summer camp, City of El Cerrito, 2006
Co-facilitator for numerous solar cooking workshops to groups in a wide variety of settings, 2005-present
Other Ways You Can Help

Please help share this campaign with your community through the Indiegogo tools, and your social networking sites!
Do you know of individuals or groups who would be interested in a SoulCollage® workshop?  Let them know about this campaign!  Folks who donate $300 or above can receive a 4-hour workshop for a group of up to 10 people, which is a discount from what I’ll be charging groups in the future, so it’s a great incentive to pool your donations!

story:
When we say "Schwing!" we don't mean what you think we mean....

Make Studio has the opportunity to move into the historic Schwing Motor Co. Building in Hampden, just in time for our 5th anniversary!

Founded in 2010, Make Studio is a 501(c)3 organization located in Baltimore, MD (www.make-studio.org). Through exhibitions, outreach, and in-studio services for artists with disabilities, we aim to put art and abilities to work to create more inclusive communities for all. 

Our program artists with disabilities are supported in pursuing greater self-sufficiency, community connectedness, and well-being. One artist’s parent said the following about how the studio program has impacted her young adult son:

He now realizes how his art can not only be a source of joy for him, but a source of joy for others, as well as a source of income. This revelation has caused him to enhance his socialization skills, assess his work ethic, and become more of a positive thinker around employment. How does the saying go — ‘Love what you do and you will never have to work a day in your life'

With the starting premise of offering high-quality and meaningful arts programming for individuals, we opened the doors to our first studio in the now defunct Load of Fun building in the Station North Arts District. Since then, as we’ve grown, we have increased our efforts to serve communities. Which leads us to...

Make Studio @ Schwing, which will allow us to immediately grow our studio program for adult artists with disabilities (from 23 up to 35 within a year). But, excitingly, it also gives us the opportunity to establish an art center to serve Baltimoreans of all abilities through events and activities (e.g., community art-making, workshops, lectures, etc.).

Our goal is to create a gathering place for making art, connections, & community! It will be:

  • An attractive, versatile, and functional space for participating artists, staff, visitors, and volunteers in which to carry out the mission of Make Studio;
  • A community asset for its neighborhood, available to nearby residents, community organizations, nonprofit organizations, and others;
  • A resource for the Baltimore area arts community, providing a new venue for collaborations, community-based learning, and for making and showing exceptional art.


We need your help to make this happen!

In a stroke of good luck, just as Make Studio started to really feel the crush of our current space (1,000 sq ft), we discovered that the Schwing Motor Co. Building (close to 5,000 sq ft) was available. AND, we found it that it was exactly the size, configuration, and location, with visibility and accessibility, needed to carry us into the future!

Not so good is that the window for us to make this move is narrow. Schwing's a unique building, in a unique spot, and it's uniquely desirable. As our long-time fans know, the last time we moved it was not by choice - now, although we don't want to rush, this opportunity to get into our dream space has essentially fallen into our laps and we're choosing to take it. But we will lose it if we don't take occupancy by January 1, 2015!

To expand into a space of such a greater size, on relatively short notice, will increase expenses exponentially in the short-term. We need your help to cover the temporary gap between our income and expenses, and to set up our new gallery space.

Your support will go directly towards:

  • Covering the difference between our current space costs and those at Schwing (i.e., rent, utilities)
  • Fitting out the gallery with moveable walls and retail displays, and installing exterior signage
  • Operating costs that are new to us, that we'll encounter in having our own building (e.g., HVAC maintenance, internet service)


Why this move matters

Make Studio is the only program of our kind in the Baltimore area. Within and beyond our studio Make Studio educates the public about the abilities and creative potential of underrepresented and marginalized populations. By bringing together diverse members of the local arts community and showcasing fresh artistic perspectives, we help to dispel pervasive and destructive stereotypes to create positive, radiating impacts in our local communities and beyond.

Even in our smaller digs, we've been able to reach hundreds of individuals annually via activities in our own studio, and many more indirectly through our online presence and activities in the community. Imagine what we can do in a bigger, better space!

With thoughtful modifications, our present space has served us well. However, it cannot keep pace with the amount of referrals we receive for our studio program. (We can serve 7-8 participating artists on a workday right now; interest in our program indicates that we should be serving 12-15.) We've been very creative in making overlapping use of the same space for creation, exhibition, and outreach activities; however, this sharply limits what we can offer and our ability to sell artwork. Furthermore, we're now located up an elevator and down a long hallway from an entrance, making us difficult to locate for visitors and transportation providers (often relied upon by our participating artists).

Our current space is barely adequate for our needs as they are now, and will be lesser so in the near future, as we further our vision of promoting inclusivity via diverse artistic offerings for the community-at-large. In sum, Make Studio needs new quarters.

Risks & Rewards

We recognize that making such a BIG move is a risky endeavor. Although our self-generated income, which will grow as we grow, will largely cover our expenses once we're established at Schwing, it could take us longer than we anticipate to grow it enough to cover the gap. We also know that there will be growing pains along the way, not only in moving and setting up the new space, but related to expanding our community activities.

However, over the last 4 years, we've demonstrated our track record of sustainable growth, and our ability to mindfully balance risk with reward. Since our founding, Make Studio’s revenues have more than doubled, as expenses have stayed relatively low even as we have maintained a high level of service. 

We're still a small and growing organization, but we possess many strengths in the areas of program design and internal evaluation, leadership and governance, and community relationships with great human services and arts partners. Together, these contribute to our capacity to successfully establish our art center. 

With your support to get us in the door, we will immediately open that door to new participating artists, looking to make art, and to visitors, looking to buy art and take part in a full calendar of activities.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to give financially to this effort, we'd still appreciate your support!

  • Let your circle know that Make Studio is growing, and we're looking for new fans, community partners, and participating artists with disabilities to join our fold.
  • Please spread the word about this campaign far and wide! It's very easy to do that with Indiegogo's share tools!
  • Spread the word to your favorite, charitably-minded local business -- sponsorships, with naming opportunities, are available.

In the words of our 1st artist and Star Trek superfan, Jerry "Partyman" Williams: Let's MAKE IT SO!

story:
Land-Escape

[ita] Siamo un collettivo di giovani studenti, lavoratori, artisti e professionisti. Siamo nati e cresciuti ad Alcamo, un paese della Sicilia occidentale. Molto del nostro tempo lo passiamo davanti agli schermi dei computer, dietro l’obbiettivo delle macchine fotografiche, sui tasti o le corde di strumenti musicali; chiusi nei nostri studi, lontani dalle persone, dalla vita. Quando sentiamo l’esigenza di scappare, chiudere gli schermi, spegnere i telefoni, ci rifugiamo nel monte che domina il nostro paese, il monte Bonifato. Nella natura riusciamo a riannodare il rapporto che ci lega alla terra, a sentire finalmente qualcosa, che sia il vento tra gli alberi, i nostri passi sui sentieri, la pioggia che all’improvviso scroscia. Land-escape nasce dall’esigenza di far scoprire i luoghi atavici che ci circondano attraverso performances multimediali che aiutano la percezione delle immagini e dei suoni. Il proscenio di questa fuga sarà la Riserva Naturale del Bosco d’Alcamo. Questo primo momento si terrà il 26 settembre, e vuole essere il momento di lancio di Land-Escape, cosicché i donatori possano verificare di persona il progetto. Per questo evento siamo felici di ospitare la performance audiovisiva di Federico Lupo e Giuseppe Adamo e quella di Leonardo Ruvolo e Shadow Pugilist, la manipolazione di nastri e respiri di Francesco Calandrino, la performance di Oria, l'installazione di Anto Milotta e Dario Di Liberti. Trova maggiori informazioni sugli artisti sul sito www.land-escape.it.

[eng] We are an organization made out of young students, workers, artists and freelances. We were born and raised in Alcamo, a town in western Sicily. We spend a lot of time in front of computer’s screens, behind camera’s lenses, with our hands on keys or strings of musical instruments; inside studios, away from people, from life. When we feel the need to escape, to shut down the screens,  to turn off the phones, we shelter in the mountain that dominates on our town, Monte Bonifato. In the nature we succeed to give new life to the relationship that links us to the earth, we can finally hear something: the wind in the trees, our steps along the paths, the rain that suddenly pours. Land-escape was born to fulfill the need of discovering the ancestral places that surround us and we do this using multimedia performances which help the perception of images and sounds. The proscenium of this escape will be the Riserva Naturale del Bosco d'Alcamo. This first event will be held on September 26, and wants to be the occasion to launch Land-Escape, so every funder can check  himself the project. For this event we are happy to host the audiovisual performance by Federico Lupo and Giuseppe Adamo and the other by Leonardo Ruvolo and Shadow Pugilist, and the manipulation of tapes and breaths  by Francesco Calandrino, the Oria's performance and the installation of Anto Milotta and Dario Di Liberti. More info about the artists at www.land-escape.it.


A cosa servono i soldi - What are the money for?

[ita]La somma che ci auguriamo di raccogliere sarà interamente destinata alla produzione della piattaforma Land-Escape e al primo evento che si terrà il 26 settembre. Crediamo che realizzare il primo evento ancor prima che la campagna di raccolta fondi sia terminata sia il miglior modo per testimoniare la nostra ferma volontà di portare avanti questo progetto. Entrando nello specifico i costi serviranno a finanziare il sito e la realizzazione della campagna di promozione. Per quanto riguarda l’evento le spese maggiori sono quelle da destinare al rimborso spese degli artisti e la sistemazione della location. Un ulteriore parte sarà investita nella realizzazione delle ricompense.

[eng]The amount of money which we hope to raise will be entirely allocated for the production of the platform Land-Escape and for the first event to be held on September 26.  We believe that making the event even before the conclusion of the fundraising campaign is the best way to show our determination to carry on this project. If you support the campaign you will help us to create the website and to realize of the promotional side of the project. for what concerns the event itself, part of the money will be allocated for the artists' reimburses and the arrangement of the location. Another part will be used to produce of the rewards.



Ricompense - Perks 

Per ringraziarti della tua donazione abbiamo pensato di regalarti qualcosa, oltre ad inserire il tuo nome tra i sostenitori nel nostro sito, riceverai alcune ricompense per il sostegno che ci hai dimostrato. I regali li facciamo con le nostre mani e tu potrai scegliere in relazione a quanto vorrai contribuire al progetto.

To thank you for your donation we decided to reward you with a gift, in addition to entering your name among the supporters on our site. We make the gifts with our own hands, and you can select it according to how much you choose to contribute to our project.
