story:
Our Story

Michigan Artisans was born out of the desire of two designers and artisans to have quality representation and opportunities to sell their products. After attending several art fair shows that were ill fit for our products, disorganized or misrepresented, we realized that this idea needed to become a reality. While art fairs and craft shows used to be the best place for artisans to display and sell their goods, in the recent years it has become more of a “flea market” or “swap meet” atmosphere not suited to artists and craftsmen.


Artists tend to know how to create their craft well, but not how to market it, where to sell it or how to design a professional website. This is where Michigan Artisans began in the online format (http://www.michigan-artisans.org). We are both well versed in website design and bring unique attributes to the company from our collective backgrounds. The company is at the stage now where it would like to expand and start to provide a representation service to these artists as well as a gallery space to showcase these artists and their crafts. We represent only artists from the Great Lakes State, promoting Michigan and what it has to offer.

The Impact

Michigan Artisans juries all members of their website community with strict guidelines. Members will be reviewed with a checks and balance system once approved. This keeps the quality of products high as well as a growing variety of new artists. These online vendors will also have the option to join Michigan Artisans in our Gallery Boutique. This helps the company with connecting local artists with the community.


The main goal of the company is connecting artists and designers with the community and the community with local art. Michigan Artisans focuses on quality handmade products from within our state while helping local artists by providing them with the support needed to improve their own businesses. The variety of services offered by Michigan Artisans goes beyond an online community of artists. Aside from the actual storefront to sell vendors’ goods, Michigan Artisans will offer graphic support to artists and the local community, reasonable studio and display space rental fees, event planning services and eventually offer graphic internships to students.


We would like the company to be seen by local artists as a trusted partner for marketing and selling their goods and products. Michigan Artisans would also be seen as a trusted community member and a place to help local community groups plan and organize events. Overall we want the company to be a profitable business that can hold its own in the arts community and will help encourage growth within the community and in local businesses.

What We Need & What You Get

We really feel that Michigan Artisans needs to take our business to the next level. By moving into a physical space to set up our studio & gallery area we believe that we can be more productive and more available to the community. What we lack is the funding to expand into the preferred space and set up shop. A physical presence in the community will keep our plan viable and transparent. Our start-up costs will go toward move-in costs, office equipment, display units, signage and advertising.


Patrons and Angels for our cause will receive a Michigan Artisans Art Supporter t-shirt ($50 donation) or sweatshirt ($100 or more donation) in their choice of size plus an invitation to our exclusive Grand Opening Gala.


In the event we don't meet our goal within the time period provided, we will continue other fund raising and work to meet that goal in a timely fashion. All of our fund raising efforts will be kept current on the website.

Other Ways You Can Help

Everybody knows somebody that would like to support the arts! We are trying to keep Michigan moving forward in economic growth and community arts development. If you don't have any disposable income for a donation you can still spread the word and BUY LOCAL, BUY MICHIGAN.
story_txt:
Our Story
Michigan Artisans was born out of the desire of two designers and artisans to have quality representation and opportunities to sell their products. After attending several art fair shows that were ill fit for our products, disorganized or misrepresented, we realized that this idea needed to become a reality. While art fairs and craft shows used to be the best place for artisans to display and sell their goods, in the recent years it has become more of a “flea market” or “swap meet” atmosphere not suited to artists and craftsmen.

Artists tend to know how to create their craft well, but not how to market it, where to sell it or how to design a professional website. This is where Michigan Artisans began in the online format (http://www.michigan-artisans.org). We are both well versed in website design and bring unique attributes to the company from our collective backgrounds. The company is at the stage now where it would like to expand and start to provide a representation service to these artists as well as a gallery space to showcase these artists and their crafts. We represent only artists from the Great Lakes State, promoting Michigan and what it has to offer.

The Impact
Michigan Artisans juries all members of their website community with strict guidelines. Members will be reviewed with a checks and balance system once approved. This keeps the quality of products high as well as a growing variety of new artists. These online vendors will also have the option to join Michigan Artisans in our Gallery Boutique. This helps the company with connecting local artists with the community.

The main goal of the company is connecting artists and designers with the community and the community with local art. Michigan Artisans focuses on quality handmade products from within our state while helping local artists by providing them with the support needed to improve their own businesses. The variety of services offered by Michigan Artisans goes beyond an online community of artists. Aside from the actual storefront to sell vendors’ goods, Michigan Artisans will offer graphic support to artists and the local community, reasonable studio and display space rental fees, event planning services and eventually offer graphic internships to students. 

We would like the company to be seen by local artists as a trusted partner for marketing and selling their goods and products. Michigan Artisans would also be seen as a trusted community member and a place to help local community groups plan and organize events. Overall we want the company to be a profitable business that can hold its own in the arts community and will help encourage growth within the community and in local businesses. 

What We Need & What You Get
We really feel that Michigan Artisans needs to take our business to the next level. By moving into a physical space to set up our studio & gallery area we believe that we can be more productive and more available to the community. What we lack is the funding to expand into the preferred space and set up shop. A physical presence in the community will keep our plan viable and transparent. Our start-up costs will go toward move-in costs, office equipment, display units, signage and advertising. 

Patrons and Angels for our cause will receive a Michigan Artisans Art Supporter t-shirt ($50 donation) or sweatshirt ($100 or more donation) in their choice of size plus an invitation to our exclusive Grand Opening Gala.

In the event we don't meet our goal within the time period provided, we will continue other fund raising and work to meet that goal in a timely fashion. All of our fund raising efforts will be kept current on the website.

Other Ways You Can Help
Everybody knows somebody that would like to support the arts! We are trying to keep Michigan moving forward in economic growth and community arts development. If you don't have any disposable income for a donation you can still spread the word and BUY LOCAL, BUY MICHIGAN.

story:
footwork seldom pays off in a linear fashion ~

we shake the apple tree & the universe delivers oranges -jc


♥



I closed the fund raising campaign for Wearable Weapons early. 

Things went in a different direction. I got the funding I was seeking.

All the clarity I gained and late nights spent refining this proposal was used to receive the

Eyebeam Residency + Stipend that begins September 1st, 2011 through January 2012. 

I am very excited and grateful to begin this new adventure. 

Please follow this project at wearableweapons.com or through the Eyebeam website updates!

If you have any questions please call (347) 941-1192 or email me at yes@carriemae.com


THANK YOU!


Carrie Mae Rose is a sculptor, performer and interactive installation artist creating Wearable Weapons, Agave Armor, and interactive costumes that awaken the power of vulnerability.  By using materials that can create shock and deadly injury, she brings a heightened sense of caution, reverence, and pushes the boundary of fashion to the absolute limit.  These items are built, worn, and photographed to investigate three of the most primal human necessities: sexuality, beauty, and protection.  They are both a parody and a provocation. Her pieces explore the role of the feminine in our culture of militarization and speak to the influence it is currently having on trends in pop-culture, education, entertainment, and high-fashion.  Her work is built with electricity, sound sensors, open source software, hardware, confiscated scissors (weapons) from airport security, razor blades, and plant fibers.  It integrates iconography, sacred geometry, alchemy, symmetry, fashion, ritual play, and tribal mysticism.  http://wearableweapons.com

Carrie Mae Rose began exhibiting her artwork in Prescott, Jerome, Winslow, and Phoenix, Arizona, before moving to New York City in 2007.  She studied and performed Butoh with Diego Pinon and acrobatic stilt walking with The Carpetbag Brigade Physical Theater Company.  She assisted wearable artist, Latifa Medjdoub, in San Francisco and jewelry designer, Joomi Lim, in New York City.  Her recent studies in the field of interactive technology bring a breadth of understanding to begin building new multimedia costumes and installations. Carrie Mae Rose holds a M.F.A. in Design and Technology from Parsons The New School for Design in New York City and a B.A. from Prescott College in Prescott, Arizona.  Recently in New York she has exhibited work in BETA Spaces, Devotion Gallery, and Elga Wimmer Gallery in Chelsea. She meditates daily and everything about the future inspires her.  http://carriemae.com

story:
GOOD NEWS: we have just had our public preview party 

with photos of the hand-made 'Memory Tiles' created by the elders and line drawings for my row of tiles depicting their wishes for their community's future, hanging on wall in lobby to show where the actual tiles will be permanently installed...

AND

We are able to continue raising funds to complete this project and install the handmade tiles in the Hamilton Madison House Community Center lobby.

We have a fund-raising tile that is a collage of printed photos of the elder's hand-made 'memory tiles'. This printed tile will be available for sale at the community center and online.

AND

Because this project is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas (see above), further donations can be received:

  • by checks made PAYABLE to FRACTURED ATLAS, with the note in memo line: 'Memories and Wishes'.

             Mail checks to:

             Syma- Studio #41

             TI ART STUDIOS

             183 Lorraine Street - 3rd Floor

             Brooklyn, NY 11231

  • OR by credit card through our fiscal sponsor https://www.fracturedatlas.org/donate/6611

 

Although we did not reach our goal on indiegogo, we want to assure you that your contributions have been received with deep gratitude... You made it possible for us to complete the memory tiles and some of the border tiles.

NOW we are looking for funding to complete our project.

Please tell your friends how they can still contribute. Note that Donations by check are still eligible for our 'perks'.

The Hamilton Madison House Seniors and I thank you for any assistance you can give to the Memories and Wishes Project.

Let's see what else can happen with your help...

**********************************************************************

 

Who are these participants? and what will they do?

  • These senior citizens are long-time residents of one of New York City's Lower East Side public housing developments.

  • Some participants will carve, sculpt, and paint 'memory tiles' that they design, to show their favorite Lower East Side memories.

  • Some will press clay into specially made plaster molds to create a row of 'water tiles' to represent their families' immigration to New York City.

  • Some will make border tiles by stamping textures and symbols into damp clay tiles.

  • All will be invited to share their wishes for the future of the neighborhood. I will represent these hopes in the tiles that I will create for this installation.

Who I am:

  • I am a ceramic artist named Syma living in New York City's Lower East Side. My studio workspace is in Brooklyn.
  • My two passions are working with clay and working with people.
  • Currently I am a freelance educator for the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
  • As visiting artist or artist-in-residence, I have helped New York City and Boston area students create hand-made clay tiles for permanent installations in their schools.
  • I have worked with architects and interior designers to design and create low-relief panels and tiles that are installed in public buildings and private homes.

Why I dreamed up this project:

  • This project offers me the chance to put my art-making and my art-teaching passions together in my own community.
  • Funding no longer exists for the pottery program that I directed from 1998-2002 for these seniors, at the Hamilton Madison Community Center.
  • I am excited by the challenge of making art that reflects some of the hopes and dreams these elders hold for their neighborhood.
  • I want to combine my artwork with the tiles created by the community participants; to integrate the parts into a cohesive, meaningful, visually compelling permanent installation.
  • I think that public art can not only tell a story about the community,  it can actually involve members of the community in which the art is placed.

 Why we need your help:

  • The 'Memories and Wishes' project has received some government funding.* This grant award will not cover all of the costs.
  • We need additional financial help to be able to cover costs for time and materials for all of the tile-making and tile-painting workshops; kiln-firings; and the tile installation in the community center lobby.
  • Without additional funding, there will be no actual clay tile-making. A few seniors will be able to simply decorate store-bought pre-made tiles that will be hung in the lobby.
  • Please let this project be all that it can be.

What will your donation fund?  

  • Your donation will allow us to enhance the lobby of the Hamilton Madison Community Center that provides activities for area residents of all ages.
  • Every contribution will allow us to involve more of the interested elders.
  • Every dollar helps.
  • A donation of $25 pays for the materials and time for one senior to make 1/4
    of their memory tile.
  • You will give these elders the chance to tell their stories in clay.
  • You will give these elders the chance to leave a legacy for the future.
  • You can receive gifts for yourself or your friends from our list of 'perks'.

Other ways you can help even if you cannot donate money:

  • We value your assistance even if you cannot donate any money.
  • You can participate by helping us to spread the word about this project and about this fund-raising campaign.
  • Tell your friends and family; tell your neighbors; tell your colleagues and co-workers.
  • If you tell 2 friends, and they tell 2 friends, and they tell 2 friends...
  • Use your favorite social media: use facebook, tweets, and blogs.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools above.
  • Send out emails with this link: http://www.indiegogo.com/memories-and-wishes

Let's see what can happen with your help...


*This project is made possible in part with public funds from the Manhattan Community Arts Fund, supported by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council and administered by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council.

What will your donation fund?

You can receive gifts for yourself or your friends from our list of 'perks'.
Other ways you can help even if you cannot donate money:

We value your assistance even if you cannot donate any money.
You can participate by helping us to spread the word about this project and about this fund-raising campaign.
Tell your friends and family; tell your neighbors; tell your colleagues and co-workers.
If you tell 2 friends, and they tell 2 friends, and they tell 2 friends...
Use your favorite social media: use facebook, tweets, and blogs.
Use the Indiegogo share tools above.
Send out emails with this link: http://www.indiegogo.com/memories-and-wishes

Let's see what can happen with your help...
*This project is made possible in part with public funds from the Manhattan Community Arts Fund, supported by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council and administered by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council.

story:
We are building a MANABIGAMA kiln.   

 We gratefully offer beautiful gifts of wood fired clay.

Who are We?  Tyler Park Center for the Arts is a non-profit community art center with a mission to support artists in a manner that facilitates the sharing of talents through art based educational programs. We foster community engagement with like-minded organizations, schools and individuals.  We have a strong base of volunteers who do everything from performing operational functions to baking food for our fund raising events and coffee house.

Learn more about us at www.TylerParkArts.org

 

                                                                     Introducing

                           The Tyler Park Kiln Project

 

 

MANABIGAMA translates from Japanese as "a beautiful learning kiln"

Designed by potter, John Thies, this type of kiln was chosen for the qualities it lends to the workshop setting. The manabigama is a very efficient kiln, using about 3/4 of a cord of wood to achieve the same beautiful results as traditional firings consuming 3-5 cords of wood. With a 30 cubic foot chamber we can fire lots of artwork, yet this medium sized kiln is not overwhelming for the student new to wood firing. The fired results are sure to please serious professionals proficient at this craft.  

Weighing about six tons, this kiln will be a permanent fixture in Tyler State Park, lasting for years and experienced by many. Students from high schools and colleges, professional artists, and adult students will come from all over our region to participate in this oldest form of firing.

With generous support from individuals, and intrigued approval from the State Park Commission and Newtown Township we laid the foundation for this fascinating kiln. We are fortunate to have government entities sharing our belief that this project is a valued addition to the park atmosphere and surrounding communities!

We will be firing up to 2400 degrees by stoking a flame every ten minutes for 12-16 hours.  Stoneware and porcelain clays will reach a temperature where they become somewhat molten.  It is then that ash from the burning embers travels through the kiln and sticks to the pottery.  Wood ash containing silica melts at high temperatures and forms a glass like surface on areas of the ware inside the kiln.  Where the ash does not land the flame touches up against the clay leaving its mark.  It is a chosen aesthetic unreachable through any other method.

 

WE HAVE ALREADY ACCOMPLISHED SO MUCH!

The kiln site is ready:

The cement pad has been poured

Eight posts support a 24ft x10 ft, volunteer built, shingled structure.

 

 

We need to raise an additional amount of $8,500 to pay for the kiln shelves, angle iron, mortar, ceramic fiber insulation, clay, glaze, and a much needed log splitter. If you help us exceed our goal you will be contributing to our kiln scholarship fund.  In scholarship, we could provide opportunities to deserving underserved students, local teachers, and emerging artists.

To many community art centers, a kiln of this magnitude would be cost prohibitive with final costs approaching $25,000.  We started with a pledge from a local artist, a pile of repurposed bricks, and very hard working volunteers.  Our dreams are within reach! 

Support of our project will be far reaching.  You will help ensure the longevity of our art center as this permanent kiln will be a source of revenue for many years to come.  In helping us you also bring job opportunities to regional artists and opportunities for creative expression to our local population.

 

A gift Idea: We would be happy to send a gift certificate for someone you know who would appreciate the aesthetics of our project!

Local Business Sponsorship We will gratefully include the names of our business Sponsors in our Kiln Manual.  An informative Kiln Manual will be given to each workshop participant.  It will contain key information on the safety and firing protocol of our kiln.  All Business Sponsors at any level will be acknowledged in our Kiln Manual

 

Thank You for your consideration. Please enjoy reviewing our gifts. 

Thanks to Indiegogo for this opportunity to raise funds for our project.  

Please help promote our project by liking us on Facebook and by following us on Twitter.

story:
Short Summary

I am Raffaela Vergata. I have been working in theatre in New York City for the past 5 years. My friends approached me a few months ago with the idea of going to an arts festival in Nevada called Burning man. I had never heard of it but after learning about all the different art that is produced there and the great energy everyone has, I knew I had to be there. 

Burning man encourages everyone to contribute to the festival. This can mean helping others with their project or bringing your own. I chose to bring my own after hearing the theme for the festival this year is fertility. I was full of ideas but chose to design a field of sixty sunflowers for the occasion. 

My intention is to bring life back to the dessert. The sunflowers will be constructed of 3/8" and 1/4" steel rods, 3/4" plastic tubing, colored plastic sheets called Gel (usually used in theatrical lighting) and strings of tiny LED lights to illuminate the flowers at night. The thinner rods will be bent into circles for the flowers heads while the thicker pieces are left straight to represent the flower stems. The plastic tubing acts as a cover for the lights as well as a way to attach the "petals" to the heads. The gel sheets will be cut into petal-like shapes and then attached to flower head rings. 

The "field" will be laid out in a 30'x40' grid. The field will allow participants of Burning Man to walk among the flowers and enjoy the way they play with light. With the hollow heads and colored petals, they will cast long stain glass-like patterns on the dessert. 

I have a great team going with me; Jake Platt, Desiree Burch, Kyle Crose and Patrick Rule. As well as all the flower assembly help at home, this belongs to all of you. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

I am looking to raise $5,000 for materials. The flowers design has been kept as simple as possible but the steel, tubing, gel and lights, still need to be covered.

For a donation or $25 you will receive a thank you card from artist and team. 

For a donation of $50 you can receive a sunflower rendering.

For a donation of $100 you will receive a sunflower of your very own.

For a donation of $300 you will receive an original sunflower, after the festival, with a letter of authenticity from the artist. 

If the entire goal is reached my team and I will head out to the Burning Man festival in a truck packed with the beautiful sunflowers. We will have a day of setup before the festival gates open to all participants, I will spend the week at Burning Man promoting the sunflowers and talking to others about the process. If the goal is not reached however, I will probably have to abandon the project behind. 

The Impact

People are always saying how theatre and art are dying forms of expression. I am committed to proving them wrong by working at not-for-profit theatres all over New York. We can not allow creativity to die with our changing times. Help me save the dream of art and personal expression. We must work as a community to get there. I have seen it work before and I still believe. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in the project but can not contribute, spread the word! Word of mouth is one of the fastest ways, besides the internet, to get the word out.

Also, if you are in the New York, Metropolitan area, my team and I will be holding an in person fundraiser at "The Four-Face Liar" pub 165 west 4th street, New York, NY 10014. July 30, 8:00pm-12:00am. There will be cheap drinks, cute bartenders, prototypes of the sunflowers! Come chat about burning man and find out more about the project. Hope to see you there!

I chose to bring my own after hearing the theme for the festival this year is fertility. I was full of ideas but chose to design a field of sixty sunflowers for the occasion. 
My intention is to bring life back to the dessert. The sunflowers will be constructed of 3/8" and 1/4" steel rods, 3/4" plastic tubing, colored plastic sheets called Gel (usually used in theatrical lighting) and strings of tiny LED lights to illuminate the flowers at night. The thinner rods will be bent into circles for the flowers heads while the thicker pieces are left straight to represent the flower stems. The plastic tubing acts as a cover for the lights as well as a way to attach the "petals" to the heads. The gel sheets will be cut into petal-like shapes and then attached to flower head rings. 
The "field" will be laid out in a 30'x40' grid. The field will allow participants of Burning Man to walk among the flowers and enjoy the way they play with light. With the hollow heads and colored petals, they will cast long stain glass-like patterns on the dessert. 
I have a great team going with me; Jake Platt, Desiree Burch, Kyle Crose and Patrick Rule. As well as all the flower assembly help at home, this belongs to all of you. 
 


What We Need & What You Get
I am looking to raise $5,000 for materials. The flowers design has been kept as simple as possible but the steel, tubing, gel and lights, still need to be covered.
For a donation or $25 you will receive a thank you card from artist and team. 
For a donation of $50 you can receive a sunflower rendering.
For a donation of $100 you will receive a sunflower of your very own.
For a donation of $300 you will receive an original sunflower, after the festival, with a letter of authenticity from the artist. 
If the entire goal is reached my team and I will head out to the Burning Man festival in a truck packed with the beautiful sunflowers. We will have a day of setup before the festival gates open to all participants, I will spend the week at Burning Man promoting the sunflowers and talking to others about the process. If the goal is not reached however, I will probably have to abandon the project behind. 


The Impact
People are always saying how theatre and art are dying forms of expression. I am committed to proving them wrong by working at not-for-profit theatres all over New York. We can not allow creativity to die with our changing times. Help me save the dream of art and personal expression. We must work as a community to get there. I have seen it work before and I still believe. 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you are interested in the project but can not contribute, spread the word! Word of mouth is one of the fastest ways, besides the internet, to get the word out.
Also, if you are in the New York, Metropolitan area, my team and I will be holding an in person fundraiser at "The Four-Face Liar" pub 165 west 4th street, New York, NY 10014. July 30, 8:00pm-12:00am. There will be cheap drinks, cute bartenders, prototypes of the sunflowers! Come chat about burning man and find out more about the project. Hope to see you there!

story:
My Story

My name is Patricia Watts, and I am an independent art curator specializing in art and ecology since 1994. In 1997, I founded ecoartspace, an art and nature center concept in development, and in 1999, was joined by Amy Lipton in New York City. Together we have created a nonprofit bicoastal platform for artists addressing environmental issues, and have curated more than 40 exhibitions, 75 programs, and have worked with more than 400 artists and collaborated with more than 150 organizations. 


This campaign Take me to Constantinople! is a fundraising effort to ensure my attendance at the Inter-Society for the Electronic Arts 2011 Annual Conference, which will be held in Istanbul, Turkey in September. This is really a once in a lifetime opportunity to go to one of the world's "cradles of civilization" to participate on a panel with colleagues from Dubai and Spain. For this conference, I have been invited to present on the panel entitled Public Art of the Sustainable City, and will be discussing green technology based public art works and green public art master plans in North America. While I am there, I will also be able to attend the Istanbul Biennial and do studio visits with Turkish artists.

What I need and What you get

My goal is to raise $2,200 to pay for round trip airfare to Istanbul from Los Angeles or San Francisco and 8/10 nights accommodations. To do this, I am asking you to donate either $5, $40, $50, $75 or $275.


What will you get in return? (click on pink links to see items)

  • For as little as $5 you can get an awesome EARTH sticker for your car.
  • For only $40, you can add "ecovention" to your book collection, a most unique look at artists who transform ecosystems. 
  • For $50 you have the opportunity to own a limited edition print addressing resource extraction and climate issues hand-produced by Justseeds.
  • For $75 you can score an 8X10" original artwork created in 2010 for the DOTEARTH What Matters Most ecoartspace benefit fundraiser.
  • For $275, if you're a wine connoisseur, and this is the last one in a handmade series from 2007, you can claim an Imperial size bottle of Cabernet Sauvignon by an artist from Sonoma County in Northern California (shipping in the continental USA included).

Other Ways You Can Help

I will not be able to make the trip without your help, so please contribute what you can and I will send you your associated ecoart accoutrement. OR, if you cannot contribute financially, please help me spread the word via Facebook or other social media networks.


THANKS FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!

story:
27 Graduating Artists. 1 Show. And YOU.

University of South Florida College of Fine Arts has been home to 27 artists in various disciplines including drawing, painting, sculpture, photography, ceramics, mixed-media, installation and video. From April 25th-30th, 2014, we will emerge from our studios and present you with our seminal exhibition, Prolonged Eye Contact.

With a group as strong and diverse as this year's thesis students, Tampa should take note. Planning and executing an exhibition is a vital experience contributing to the success of emerging artists in the Tampa art community and beyond. Be involved with the success of this exhibition! Support from our Indiegogo campaign will cover the cost of print materials, advertisement, set up, and presenting a large show. Every contribution will be used and deeply appreciated!


$ Situation

Our goal is $1,500 with a deadline of April 3rd. In exchange for help with our costs, we will reward you nicely with our hand-made goods! When you make a contribution through our Indiegogo campaign it is a direct, non-tax-deductible gift and offers us the maximum ease. Contact us if you require information on tax-deductible giving.

We are truly thrilled, as we graduate, to be assembling our work for public view. Prolonged Eye Contact represents the highlight and culmination of our studies at the USF College of The Arts. We welcome your help in making our exhibition a grand success!


WHEN: April 25-30, 2014
Opening Reception: April 25th

DETAILS: Admission is free and open to the public. 

Exhibiting artists are Kirsten Austin, Kristin Beauvois, Kim Burns, Melanie Cotton, Ariel DeWitt, Jacqueline Flavio, Casie Fogle, Jennifer Fritz, Raquel Garabeli, Monica Garret, Jessica Halferty, Jeffery Hansen, Danielle Janney, Richard Montero, Katherine Morrow, Christina Pena, Scott Pierce, Jessica Rice, Ericka Richardson, Jeremy Rivera, Jessica Rovin, Tyler Staggs, Chase Starr, Grace Strattan, Candyce Strayer, John Sullivan, and Aisha Tazi

story:
• Who am I?

Hi, I’m Sara!

I grew up in a rabidly anti-zionist (Neturei Karta) ultra-orthodox Jewish community, and always felt like I was born in the wrong place. I wanted to express myself, decide who I wanted to be. That seemed like an unreachable dream in a community that controlled every aspect of my life, from the length of my skirt to the style of my hair (only braids were allowed), from the things I could say to the books I could read, from the friends I could make to the level of education I was allowed to get. Violence and loneliness were part of my every-day life.

When I was 17, I finally fled to avoid an arranged marriage. I was disowned by my entire  community.

I spent the first ten years of my secular life trying to fit in and learning the basics of day-to-day survival in the big world. But it wasn’t easy nor satisfying.
I then decided to travel to India, where I finally was able to discover who I really was. At that moment, my purpose in life became clear: it was to make art.

I am now an artist living in NYC where I share my work and my story. Most of my work is an exploration of my past and present, and a way to heal from scars that my former life has left in me. I have been included in group shows around the city, including Jewish Art Now, Footsteps Organization, For Locals by Locals Crown Heights, Brooklyn International Performance Art Festival, and I've had one solo show during Bushwick open studios. I give creative expression workshops and I participate in public art projects such as Brooklyn Recycle Project.

I made my dreams of freedom come true, and I hope to inspire other people to pursue theirs, whatever the obstacles might be.


  • What am I trying to do?

I have been granted an awesome opportunity to create my first extensive solo show in a wonderful gallery called Soapbox Gallery The show is opening on August 21st, and I need your help to make it happen!


The gallery’s mission is to stir social change and to create dialogue through the presentation of striking art work. There is no better place for me to show my work and present my struggle towards freedom. Some of the pieces I am creating will be interactive and through this show I hope to inspire other people to change their lives regardless of obstacles and difficulties.

I have a month and a half to purchase material, create new work, and promote this amazing opportunity. A lot to do in a little time!

Please contribute and help me reach my goals! I will spend the raised funds to transport the work to the gallery, and more importantly to buy art material such as heavy rope, wood, sculpting clay, chicken wire, thread, glue, frames, canvases, and hanging materials.

With all this, I will be able to make several sculptures, paintings, multi-media pieces, and two interactive installations that will tell my life story.

Additionally, I will print photographs that people can take with them for free as part of one installation.

Isn’t all this amazing?

I’m putting all my energy into creating a show that will help raise important discussions and hopefully inspire others to take steps towards pursuing a self-determined life. This solo show is also a major opportunity to establish my artistic career and draw attention to my work.

Anything helps!

I hope to hug you at the opening of this show.

Thank you !!

Sara

Find out more about my work at Sara Erenthal Art
Read more about my story in The Jewish Week

story:
After the campaign ends, please visit www.MichaelMarkowsky.com for updates! Follow us on Twitter & Facebook too!

Interview with Jas Johal on Global TV (Thursday, November 7, 2013)
Interview with Lynn Colliar on Global TV (Sunday, November 10, 2013)
Article by Sara Harowitz on Huffington Post (Sunday, November 10, 2013)
Interview with Sara Lapsley on CiTR Radio (Wednesday, November 13, 2013)
Interview with Rick Cluff on CBC Radio (Thursday, December 12, 2013)
Article on CBC News Website (Friday, December 13, 2013)
Interview with Betsy Trumpener on CBC Radio (Wednesday, December 18, 2013)
Article by Robert Mallett in Edmonton Journal (Thursday, December 19, 2013)
Interview by Abbas Somji on CBC TV (Saturday, December 21, 2013)
Article on CBC News Website (Sunday, December 22, 2013)
Interview with Amy Jo Espetveidt on CalgaryIsAwesome.com (Sunday, December 22, 2013)


  • Hire professional Filmmaker Mike Peterson to take the 40 hours of footage shot in the CF-18 (and on the Air Force Base in Cold Lake) and turn it into a 25 minute short film = $2,500
  • Burn DVDs, buy envelopes, mail film to CBC, National Film Board and short film festivals, pay festival entry fees, etc. = $500

  • Have the final 25 minute film professionally Colour Corrected = $800
  • Commission renowned musician and film composer Edo Van Breemen to create an original score and do sound design for the film = $2,000

  • Rent a studio in Vancouver for 3 months ($500/month) = $1,500
  • Purchase art materials (five large 5”x5” canvases, paint, brushes) = $1,500
  • Frame 45 of the 100 drawings ($50/frame) = $2,250

  • Hire a Cinematographer to document the paintings in progress (paintings based on the drawings and video created in the CF-18); visiting the studio 4 times over the course of 3 months = $1,200
  • Hire a professional Video Editor to incorporate this new footage into the short film, potentially expanding it's length to 45 minutes = $1,500

  • Hire a Graphic Designer to design a full-colour 80-page book collecting documentary photos, drawings made in the CF-18 and the resulting paintings = $2,500
  • Commission 2 new texts written by prominent Curators and Art Historians for the book = $1,000

  • Rent a warehouse space to be used as an artist’s studio in Vancouver for 3 months  = $4,500
  • Purchase art materials (a giant 70'x8' roll of canvas, paint, brushes) = $2,500
  • NOTE: If we reach LEVEL #6, the $5,250 raised in LEVEL #3 would be used instead to build a wooden support structure for the large paintings, as well as crates for storage and transportation

  • Tour the film and artwork across Canada, exhibiting in up to 15 museums and/or galleries ($2,000 transportation budget per venue) = $30,000 
  • Michael Markowsky will also craft an inspirational Powerpoint Presentation which he will deliver for FREE while on tour to children in Elementary Schools, Veterans at Legions, students in Universities, etc.

  • Hire Carpenters to advise and assist artist Michael Markowsky to build a giant replica of a CF-18 Hornet fighter plane, made of wood and stretched canvas (the same materials used to build a painting canvas), that children and adults can climb on top of and sit inside of = $7,000
  • Wood and canvas used for the construction of the CF-18, as well as crates for shipping = $3,000

  • Pay an extra $1,500 each to the two original Cinematographers (Oliver McGarvey and Tom Gunia) who generously reduced their fees in order to help get the project off the ground because they believed in it = $3,000
  • Hire a Publicist to help promote the completed project to media outlets across Canada and find additional venues abroad = $5,000
  • Hire Web Designer Alana Kumar to create a permanent website devoted entirely to the project, making documents, video, education materials, etc. available for free = $1,200

  • All money above $73,450 will be divided up equally and donated to the following charities that provide assistance to Canadian military veterans and their families: Royal Canadian Legion, The Hero Fund, (supporting families of fallen soldiers) and the Military Minds Association (supporting veterans suffering from PTSD).

All images created and designed by Michael Markowsky www.michaelmarkowsky.com

story:
Ayasofya’dan Portreler’ in Hikayesi

Merhaba, ismim Haluk Koçoğlu. Belgesel video filmler yapıyorum ve fotoğraf çekiyorum. Bisiklet aktivisti ve veganım. On yıl interaktif multimedya üreten Metropol Multimedya isimli şirketi yönettim. Yapımcılığını yaptığım “Hagia Sophia from Konstantinoupol to İstanbul With Lord John J. Norwich” isimli CD-ROM, Avrupa’da Louvre Müzesi tanıtım CD-ROM’u arkasından ikinci oldu. Amerika’da müze tanıtımı alanında, iki ayrı yarışmada bir ikincilik ve bir birincilik aldı. Benimle ilgili ayrıntılı bilgiyi ve diğer fotoğrafları burada  http://portraitsfromhagiasophia.blogspot.com.tr  bulabilirsiniz.


2010 yılında, “Avrupa Kültür Başkenti İstanbul” sırasında başladığım ‘Ayasofya’dan Portreler’  çalışmam yarım kaldı. Bir sergiye, bir kitaba girecek tek bir fotoğraf karesi için  bazen yüzlerce kare fotoğraf çekmeniz gerekir. Ayasofya gibi, muhteşem ışıklı ama nispeten loş mekanlarda, ışığı çok iyi geçiren diyafram açıklığı yüksek lensler ve daha duyarlı sensörlere sahip fotoğraf makinelerine ihtiyaç duyarsınız. Bunlar elinizde yoksa güzel resimleri kaçırırsınız. Çok düşük perde hızında çektiğiniz fotograflarda, ya karşınızdaki insanlar hareket eder ya siz. Bir sefer, iki sefer, üç sefer... Bir süre sonra pes edersiniz. Ben de öyle yapmıştım.

‘Ayasofya’dan Portreler’ , ilk aşaması ekipman alımı ve iki ay İstanbul Ayasofya'da fotoğraf çekimi olan, ikinci aşaması bu fotograflarla açılacak sergi ve basılacak kitap olan, iki aşamadan oluşan bir çalışma.


Gereksinimler ve kazançlar

‘Ayasofya’dan Portreler’  çalışmasını, imece usulü ile birliikte gerçekleştireceğiz. İlk aşamada siz, vereceğiniz desteklerle, iki ay boyunca iyi bir ekipmanla İstanbul Ayasofya'da çalışmamı sağlayacaksınız, ben size destekleriniz karşılığında fotoğraflarımı imzalayarak göndereceğim. Böylece, bilebildiğim kadarıyla Ayasofya'da daha önce benzeri yapılmamış bir çalışmayı birlikte gerçekleştirmiş olacağız. Sonuçlarını önce sizle paylaşacağım. 

'Ayasofya’dan Portreler’ in gerçekleşmesi için destek verdiğinizde bu çalışmanın da parçası olacaksınız.  Sağda yukarıda, üç farklı destek miktarı ve karşılığında benim size üç farklı teşekkür imkanım var. Desteğinize göre, 20 X 30 boyutunda bir kartpostal, 50 x 75 cm ya da 75 x 100 cm boyutlarında imzalı bir fotoğraf adresinize teslim edilecek, projedeki gelişmelerden haberdar edileceksiniz. Her birinde de, bir sonraki aşamada yapılacak sergi ve kitapta isimleriniz yer alacak. 

Yollayacağım fotoğrafların baskı ve posta ücretleri ile desteklerinizin vergi ve komisyon kesintileri toplamı, yukarıda yer alan hedefimin yarısına yaklaşıyor. Diğer yarısı ile aşağıda listede yazılı ekipmanı satın alarak, iki ay İstanbul’da, Ayasofya’da çalışacağım. Hedefimin aşılması halinde gelen desteği, bu çalışmanın ikinci kısmı olan, sergi ve kitap için kullanacağım. Aşağıda ihtiyaç duyduğum ekipman ve linkleri var:

Geniş açı objektif/  696 USD  http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/search?Ntt=pentax+15+mm&N=0&InitialSearch=yes&sts=ma&Top+Nav-Search=

Normal objektif/  1300 USD  http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/search?Ntt=31mm+pentax&N=0&InitialSearch=yes&sts=ma&Top+Nav-Search=

Tele objektif/  1040 USD  http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/search?Ntt=77mm+pentax+limited&N=0&InitialSearch=yes&sts=ma&Top+Nav-Search=

Kamera /  1200 USD  http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/search?Ntt=pentax+k-3&N=0&InitialSearch=yes&sts=ps

I need your support to be able to finalize my photography project “Portraits from Hagia Sophia” which has been pending due to limited equipment. One of my previous productions, an interactive work “Hagia Sophia from Konstantinoupolis to Istanbul with Lord John J. Norwich” was granted awards in various competitions. Your support will be thankfully reciprocated with autographed photographs per sizes listed on the upper right section. Contributors’ names will be acknowledged at the related exhibition and the book to be printed. Please share with friends to avail the realization of this “Portraits from Hagia Sophia” project. Thank you!

Λόγω έλλειψης εξοπλισμού, δεν κατέστη δυνατόν να ολοκληρωθεί η φωτογραφική μου εργασία με τίτλο: "Πορτρέτα από την Αγιά Σοφιά", γι’ αυτό θα ήθελα να την φέρω εις πέρας με την δική σας υποστήριξη και βοήθεια. Παλαιότερα, για την παραγωγή του διαδραστικού έργου μου με τίτλο: "Hagia Sophia from Konstantinoupolis to İstanbul with Lord John J. Norwitch” το έργο μου κέρδισε βραβεία σε διάφορους διαγωνισμούς στον τομέα της παρουσίασης μουσείου. Για τη δική σας συνεισφορά, θα σας ευχαριστήσω στέλνοντάς σας ενυπόγραφες φωτογραφίες, οι οποίες θα εμφανίζονται στην δεξιά στήλη της σελίδας. Επιπλέον, τα ονόματά σας θα συμπεριληφθούν και στην έκθεση αλλά και στο βιβλίο που θα γίνουν αναφορικά με το συγκεκριμένο έργο μου. Θα σας παρακαλούσα να μοιραστείτε την προσπάθειά μου με τους ανθρώπους που θα μπορούσαν να συνεισφέρουν, ώστε να συμβάλουμε όλοι μαζί στην υλοποίηση του έργου "Πορτρέτα από την Αγιά Σοφιά". Σας ευχαριστώ.

    Bu çalışmaya destek olmak için,

    lütfen arkadaşlarınızı da bu çalışmadan haberdar ediniz.

    Hepinize şimdiden teşekkür ederim.
story_txt:
Ayasofya’dan Portreler’ in Hikayesi

Merhaba,
ismim Haluk Koçoğlu. Belgesel video filmler yapıyorum ve fotoğraf çekiyorum. Bisiklet
aktivisti ve veganım. On yıl interaktif multimedya üreten Metropol Multimedya
isimli şirketi yönettim. Yapımcılığını yaptığım “Hagia Sophia from
Konstantinoupol to İstanbul With Lord John J. Norwich” isimli CD-ROM, Avrupa’da
Louvre Müzesi tanıtım CD-ROM’u arkasından ikinci oldu. Amerika’da müze tanıtımı
alanında, iki ayrı yarışmada bir ikincilik ve bir birincilik aldı. Benimle ilgili
ayrıntılı bilgiyi ve diğer fotoğrafları burada 
http://portraitsfromhagiasophia.blogspot.com.tr  bulabilirsiniz.2010
yılında, “Avrupa Kültür Başkenti İstanbul” sırasında başladığım ‘Ayasofya’dan
Portreler’  çalışmam yarım
kaldı. Bir sergiye, bir kitaba girecek tek bir fotoğraf karesi için  bazen yüzlerce kare fotoğraf çekmeniz
gerekir. Ayasofya gibi, muhteşem ışıklı ama nispeten loş mekanlarda, ışığı
çok iyi geçiren diyafram açıklığı yüksek lensler ve daha duyarlı sensörlere
sahip fotoğraf makinelerine ihtiyaç duyarsınız. Bunlar elinizde yoksa güzel
resimleri kaçırırsınız. Çok düşük perde hızında çektiğiniz fotograflarda, ya karşınızdaki insanlar hareket eder ya siz. Bir sefer, iki sefer, üç sefer... Bir süre sonra pes
edersiniz. Ben de öyle yapmıştım.‘Ayasofya’dan Portreler’ , ilk aşaması ekipman alımı ve iki ay İstanbul Ayasofya'da fotoğraf çekimi olan, ikinci aşaması bu fotograflarla açılacak sergi ve basılacak kitap olan, iki aşamadan oluşan bir çalışma.Gereksinimler ve kazançlar

‘Ayasofya’dan Portreler’  çalışmasını, imece usulü ile birliikte gerçekleştireceğiz. İlk aşamada siz, vereceğiniz desteklerle, iki ay boyunca iyi bir ekipmanla İstanbul Ayasofya'da çalışmamı sağlayacaksınız, ben size destekleriniz karşılığında fotoğraflarımı imzalayarak göndereceğim. Böylece, bilebildiğim kadarıyla Ayasofya'da daha önce benzeri yapılmamış bir çalışmayı birlikte gerçekleştirmiş olacağız. Sonuçlarını önce sizle paylaşacağım. 'Ayasofya’dan Portreler’ in gerçekleşmesi için destek verdiğinizde bu çalışmanın da parçası olacaksınız.  Sağda yukarıda, üç farklı destek miktarı ve karşılığında benim size üç farklı teşekkür imkanım var. Desteğinize göre, 20 X 30 boyutunda bir kartpostal, 50 x 75 cm ya da 75 x 100 cm boyutlarında imzalı bir fotoğraf adresinize teslim edilecek, projedeki gelişmelerden haberdar edileceksiniz. Her birinde de, bir sonraki aşamada yapılacak sergi ve kitapta isimleriniz yer alacak. Yollayacağım fotoğrafların baskı ve posta ücretleri ile desteklerinizin vergi ve komisyon kesintileri toplamı, yukarıda yer alan hedefimin yarısına yaklaşıyor. Diğer yarısı ile aşağıda listede yazılı ekipmanı satın alarak, iki ay İstanbul’da, Ayasofya’da çalışacağım. Hedefimin aşılması halinde gelen desteği, bu çalışmanın ikinci kısmı olan, sergi ve kitap için kullanacağım. Aşağıda ihtiyaç duyduğum ekipman ve linkleri var:Geniş açı objektif/  696 USD  http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/search?Ntt=pentax+15+mm&N=0&InitialSearch=yes&sts=ma&Top+Nav-Search=Normal objektif/  1300 USD  http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/search?Ntt=31mm+pentax&N=0&InitialSearch=yes&sts=ma&Top+Nav-Search=
Tele objektif/  1040 USD  http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/search?Ntt=77mm+pentax+limited&N=0&InitialSearch=yes&sts=ma&Top+Nav-Search=
Kamera /  1200 USD  http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/search?Ntt=pentax+k-3&N=0&InitialSearch=yes&sts=psI need your support to be able to finalize my photography project “Portraits from Hagia Sophia” which has been pending due to limited equipment. One of my previous productions, an interactive work “Hagia Sophia from Konstantinoupolis to Istanbul with Lord John J. Norwich” was granted awards in various competitions. Your support will be thankfully reciprocated with autographed photographs per sizes listed on the upper right section. Contributors’ names will be acknowledged at the related exhibition and the book to be printed. Please share with friends to avail the realization of this “Portraits from Hagia Sophia” project. Thank you!Λόγω έλλειψης εξοπλισμού, δεν κατέστη δυνατόν να ολοκληρωθεί η φωτογραφική μου εργασία με τίτλο: "Πορτρέτα από την Αγιά Σοφιά", γι’ αυτό θα ήθελα να την φέρω εις πέρας με την δική σας υποστήριξη και βοήθεια. story:
Hi there! My name is Estela Semeco and I'm an artist from Atlanta, Georgia. I got my Christmas wish this year and was accepted into the very first Beta Program at the LungA School in Seyðisfjörður, Iceland! This is an enormous opportunity for me to create brand spanking new work in a remote location that allows me to experiment and explore what it means to be an artist.  

This March I will be heading to the beautifully tiny mountain valley town for the four week art program and I need your help to make it happen! Every donation will go towards the cost of tuition, flights, buses, food, and boarding. PLUS, there will be some heart huggingly charming rewards for those who contribute! 

For others that can only help by sharing this campaign, I will forever be in love with you. I wouldn't be where I am now without the consistent support of my friends and family.

story:
Clique aqui para ver a campanha em português

About Me

My name is Renê Nascimento. I am a Brazilian born artist currently residing in New York City. I have a degree from the School of Fine Arts in Minas Gerais Brazil and I have studied in renowned art centers like Parque Lage, Rio de Janeiro, FAAP, São Paulo, and The Artists League of New York. I have been fortunate enough to make a career out of my passion for painting. I have painted for several presidents and dignitaries around the world such as Brazil former president José Sarney and Minister Marcos Villaca; and my artwork has been exhibited in galleries and public spaces around the world for over 25 years. Read more about Renê's story.

Bikes Around The World

                                 (See larger images and descriptions of paintings below)

What We Need & What You Get

Our funding goal for this campaign is $10,000. By reaching our goal we will be able to add 5 more paintings to the series. For every $2,000 under our goal or past our goal we will either add or subtract 1 painting from the next set.

After fulfilling the perks, 10% of the funds will be donated to www.peopleforbikes.org and the remaining balance will be used for materials to continue the series and for my workspace, since I will not be painting any other commissioned work during that time.

We want to give everyone a chance to own a part of the series and to help with the cause, so to the right of this page you will find perks at every level

How it All Started

Since one of the most popular series of paintings in my 25 year career was NYC Bikes, I did not want to just start a new series of bicycle paintings without giving back to the community that initially inspired my first series. So, I partnered with People For Bikes - the largest organization dedicated to improving the future of bicycling. Together, we ran a bicycle photo contest to find photos that I could paint for this new series. We had almost 1,000 submissions from all over the world.

The initial idea was to just paint 5 paintings (shown below) from the winning photos submitted and to create prints from the paintings and then donate 10% of sales back to www.peopleforbikes.org, but after receiving so many inspiring beautiful bicycle photos from around the world I realized I shouldn’t stop there.

Then it came to me...

the larger the series of paintings, the bigger impact we can have in bicycling communities around the world. Why stop at 5 when there are 192 countries in the world, all of which are impacted by bicycling in one way or another?

As a result, “Bikes Around The World” was born.

Each time we add to the “Bikes Around The World” series we will donate 10% of the funds raised to a different bicycle organization—for this campaign it will go to www.peopleforbikes.org

We now need your help to create the world’s largest series of bicycle paintings, “Bikes Around The World,” with the ultimate goal of painting at least 1 bike in each country—that’s a total of 192 paintings. We will do this through a succession of crowdfunding campaigns.  The more money we raise for each campaign, the more paintings will be added to the series. 

“Life is a great big canvas, and you should throw all the paint you can on it.” – Danny Kaye

Here are larger images and descriptions of the first 5 paintings from the "Bikes Around The World" series that you will choose from for the perks.    

       

                                        NEW WINNER

"Nothing compares to the simple pleasure of riding a bike" - John F. Kennedy

Participating Brands

We would like to Thank the following brands for their support in spreading the word about "Bikes Around The World" to their community. 

The Impact

PeopleForBikes.org is dedicated to channeling that passion to improve the future of bicycling. The goal is to gather a million names of support, to speak with one, powerful voice—to make bicycling safer, more convenient and appealing for everyone. We believe that life is far more enjoyable when it’s experienced on two wheels, and they believe that by coming together, we can all make our world a better place to ride.

"At PeopleForBikes.org, we're all about promoting the beauty, fun, and joy of bicycling. Rene's paintings perfectly capture this spirit, which is why we're asking our 700,000 supporters to participate in the campaign." - Bruno Maier, Sr. Vice President, PeopleforBikes.org

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute to the campaign, you can still help us out in two ways…

    1. Use the sharing tools above to share this campaign with your networks.  
    2. Sign the PeopleForBikes.org pledge below.

                             

 FAQs

1. Does the artist Renê paint anything else besides bicycles? Yes, Renê paints a variety of subjects, more of Renê's work could be found by going to www.paintingsbyrene.com

2. Do you ship internationally? Yes, please check the bottom of each perk for additional shipping cost for international shipments.

3. How do I add the fee for international shipping? If you've already made a pledge, please hit the 'Contribute Now' button to add the additional shipping costs. Use the same email address you used to pledge so we can match the payment during fulfillment.

4. I picked a perk that offers choices. How do I make my selection? Please add your choice when paying. If you forget, we will email you after the campaign is over to confirm your choice.

5. I have a question and need to speak to someone about my pledge. Feel free to contact us at support@paintingsbyrene.com, we'll do our best to respond within 24hrs.   

6. How will the prints be shipped? All prints will be rolled and shipped in durable cardboard tubes. 

7. What if the print arrives damaged? All shipments will include insurance, if your print arrives damaged contact us at support@paintingsbyrene.com within 24 hrs after recieving the print.

story:
You can't tell anyone...

SECRET RESTAURANT is an art project by Bob Dornberger and Jim Piatt, is an aggressively marketed, 16 sq. ft partially subterranean restaurant open only a few days per year. 

When is it?

In concert with the High Desert Test Sites 2013 Program, the project runs from Oct. 12-19 2013.

Where is it?

We are currently looking in Wonder Valley, CA.  Its about 29 miles east of Joshua Tree National Monument.

Diners will be forced to stoop down to get their food, and no seating will be provided. We're still working out the menu, but we are leaning toward rabbit. The unique earthen roof and camouflage techniques keep the restaurant hard to find on satellite maps, while arrow boards, night-time lighting and ‘sign flippers’ along HWY 62 bring patrons in from the street.

This is quite an ambitious undertaking, from hiring talented sign flippers to the custom fabrication of eye-catching signage, to the excavation of the restaurant 'building' itself.  That's why we need your help.

We are finalizing the location right now, and basic logistics are already underway.  One of the costliest line items is the steel sheet piling we are sinking into the ground.

What if I can't go?  

Please spread the word, register for the $75.00 book reward, or just grab some stickers.

story:
Berlin or Bust

My name is Tim Kirsch, I am a young graphic designer from Melbourne, Australia. I have come across many job opportunities over in Berlin or Amsterdam, unfortunately am looked over because i am all the way over here in Australia. Your contribution will go towards getting me a laptop, so I am able to work on the road, and a ticket to Berlin, so I can finally meet my dream of living and working there!

www.timkirsch.com.au

What is Needed

Finer detaill:

The goal is to hopefully hit $3500, this is basically a jumping off point, any contributions over would GREATLY help me with getting there and extending my stay for as long as possible!

What You Get

For being completely generous and amazing, i am offering prints of my work! WOW! These will be numbered and signed, and may even feature a little thank you note.

See below for more deets!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some folks just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • It would be a great help if people could get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • There are share tools around, and facebook and instagram are always a huge help!
